headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Full Year and Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Steve, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Full Year and Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Steve, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, David Rosato, Kirk Walters and Jeff Hoyt are here with me to review the fourth quarter and the full year 2014 results. Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements o
componenttext: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, David Rosato, Kirk Walters and Jeff Hoyt are here with me to review the fourth quarter and the full year 2014 results. Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 on this presentation, which is posted in our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. Let me start by noting that we have completed the transition of our Chief Financial Officer position effective January 1, 2015. As announced last April, Kirk Walters has transitio
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. Let me start by noting that we have completed the transition of our Chief Financial Officer position effective January 1, 2015. As announced last April, Kirk Walters has transitioned out of the role for family reasons, and he has been succeeded by David Rosato. I appreciate how effectively Kirk and David have worked together to complete the transition seamlessly. Kirk remains an executive officer heading up Corporate Development of Strategic Planning and continues to be a member of the management committee. He also remains as a member of the Board of Directors of the company and the bank. I would like to take this opportunity to thank Kirk for all of his outstanding  steady contributions in his previous role and look forward to continuing to leverage his broad industry experience and deep operational expertise in his new role. Thank you, Kirk. 
As has been our custom, in addition to reviewing our fourth quarter and full year results, I will outline on our goals for 2015. Our performance for 2014 once again demonstrated the benefits of our deep customer relationships, product breath and product initiatives. We continue to build the business for the long term and made significant investments in talent, products and services. This included adding a better and wealth management team based in Hartford, Connecticut and a considerable number of the experienced bankers in Massachusetts. We also continued to evaluate the best ways to serve our customers and grow our businesses as evidenced by the announcement of the Merchant Services joint venture in July. 
Slide 2 provides an overview of our 2014 results. We are pleased to report full year operating earnings of $245 million, a 2% increase from 2013. On a per share basis, operating earnings were $0.82, a 6% increase from the prior year and marks the fifth consecutive year of growth in operating earnings per share. We are building on the momentum generated in recent years through our focus on growing loans and deposits, which in turn creates new opportunities and deepens existing relationships. Compare to 2013, loans and deposits increased 9% and 16%, respectively. Organic deposits had very solid growth of $1.1 billion or 5%. As we further state the relationship in the New York and Massachusetts market, our deposit base will continue to see growth. 
Net interest income increased 3% from the prior year despite a net interest margin declining 22 basis points. This decline was primarily due to the impact of strong loan originations at rates lower than our existing portfolio. Noninterest income excluding the $20.6 million gain on the Merchant Services joint venture in the second quarter of this year declined $12 million or 3% just in lower gains on residential mortgage sales. We were especially pleased that expense levels remained flat compared to the prior year considering the continued impact of the strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance cost. This focus on effective expense management improved our operating leverage during the year as evidenced by an improvement in the efficiency ratio to 62.1% from 62.3%. Asset quality continued to be exceptional. Net charge-offs in 2014 of only 12 basis points is the lowest level in over 5 years. This is a reflection of dedication to strong underwriting standards, the economic strength of the region we operate in and the long-term relationships we have with our customers. 
On Slide 3, we have provided a snapshot of last year's goals compared to actual results. In general, we were in line with most of our expectations. Net interest income was below goal primarily as a result of loan growth in the net interest margin coming in near the lower end of the targeted range. Noninterest income, excluding the $20.6 million gain on the Merchant Services joint venture, was also below the targeted range primarily attributable to lower gains on residential mortgage sales and insurance revenues. 
On Slide 4, we provide more detail behind the increase in net interest income from 2013. Strong originated loan growth drove net interest income higher by $65 million. This increase was partially offset by the runoff in the acquired loan portfolio resulting in declines in accretion of $46 million. As we have mentioned before, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing loss accretion on the acquired portfolio is a positive sign looking ahead. The acquired loan portfolio ended the year at $1.1 billion, down nearly $500 million from 2013 and represents less than 5% of total loan portfolio. 
On Slide 5, you can see our annual net interest margin results, which declined 22 basis points to 3.09%. The margin was impacted by declining benchmark interest rates and tightening credit spreads over the course of the year. New loan volume and mix negatively impacted the margin by year 21 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. 
On Slide 6, we provide additional detail behind the change in noninterest income from 2013. As I mentioned before, excluding the 2014 gain on the Merchant Services joint venture, noninterest income declined 3% from the prior period. The decline was driven by lower gains on the sales of residential mortgage loans and acquired loans. Partially offsetting these declines were an increase in operating leases as well as strong results by our wealth management business, driven by a 12% increase in investment management revenues. 
On Slide 7, we provided additional color around the expenses. As I mentioned earlier, we were especially pleased with the results were flat compared to the prior year. 
Moving on to Slide 8. Our primary goals are listed for 2015. As I referenced earlier, we remain committed to investing strategically in the franchise. The breath of products and services we provide and the exceptional talent we have attracted will enable us to build new customer relationships and deepen existing ones. These ongoing investments in the combination with our large and attractive markets as well as an unwavering commitment to relationship-based banking have driven and will continue to drive growth. 
With that background in mind, let me outline our goals. First is to grow loans at a high single to go low double-digit rate. Second is to grow deposits in the mid- to high single digits. Next is to grow net interest income in the low to mid-single digits. Embedded in this goal is an expectation for a net interest margin in the range of 2.85% to 2.95%. Another goal is to grow noninterest income in the low single digits after adjusting for the 2014 gain on the Merchant Services joint venture. We will continue to tightly control costs by keeping our operating expenses essentially flat within the range of $835 million to $845 million. Our final goal is to maintain excellent credit quality and strong capital levels. These goals reflect an assumption that interest rates remain at or near current levels. We look forward to executing the opportunities that we have created to achieve these goals. With that, I will pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. With respect to our fourth quarter performance, please turn to Slide 9 for an overview. Operating earnings were $65.1 million or $0.22 per share compared to $63 million or $0.21 per share in the third quarter. I will discuss the other res
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. With respect to our fourth quarter performance, please turn to Slide 9 for an overview. Operating earnings were $65.1 million or $0.22 per share compared to $63 million or $0.21 per share in the third quarter. I will discuss the other results shown on this overview in greater detail on subsequence slides. 
Moving to Slide 10. We provide detail behind the link to quarter change in net interest income. The overall results between the 2 quarters were generally consistent. Strong originated loan growth resulted in a $2.2 million increase in net interest income from the third quarter, while a decline in accretion from runoff in the acquired portfolio as well as increased deposit volume lowered net interest income by $1.9 million and $1.5 million, respectively. As Jack mentioned earlier, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing loss accretion on the acquired portfolio, is a positive sign looking to the quarters ahead. 
On Slide 11, you can see a breakdown of the elements contributing to our quarterly net interest margin results, which declined 5 basis points to 3%. The primary driver of this decline was new loan volume, which negatively impacted the margin by 5 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. 
Slide 12 provides a breakdown of the increase in loans. The loan portfolio grew $638 million or 10% annualized. This marks our 17th consecutive quarter of loan growth and is a testament to our relationship managers and customers. These results were achieved through leveraging in our expanded footprint as well as progress in our heritage markets. Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $767 million. As in prior quarters, growth was well-balanced from a product and geographic perspective. Commercial real estate contributed $174 million of the total originated loan growth while C&I contributed $380 million. Within C&I, we saw a particular strength in our asset-based lending and equipment finance businesses. The commercial portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages in the consumer portfolio contributed $203 million and $10 million of originated loan growth, respectively. The growth in residential mortgages is driven in part by strong originations and lower prepayments. We experienced acquired loan runoff of $129 million this quarter compared to $98 million in the third quarter and $137 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. The increase in runoff from the third quarter was primarily driven by the payoffs of 2 large loans. 
Slide 13 shows a breakdown of the elements contributing to the increase in deposits from the third quarter. Organic deposits increased $472 million or 8% on an annualized basis as retail and commercial deposits grew $304 million and $168 million, respectively. Total deposits increased $877 million, supported by brokered deposit growth of $405 million. As we previous -- as we have discussed previously, we are underway commercial deposits and continue to make changes to further emphasize deposit gathering. We firmly believe that deposits are an important part of customer relationships, and our ongoing focus remains on growing organic deposits. 
On Slide 14, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income grew 3% in the third quarter, driven by net security gains of $2.5 million, of which $2.3 million was from the call of a single acquired a security as well as increased customer interest rate swap income of $1.4 million. Partially offsetting these increases was $2.2 million in lower insurance revenues from a seasonally strong third quarter. 
On Slide 15, we illustrate the key components of changes of noninterest expense during the quarter. Similar to the full year results discussed earlier, expenses remained flat. As we have mentioned before, we continue to tightly control expenses, while investing in revenue-producing initiatives and covering the higher cost of regulatory compliance. As a reminder, payroll taxes, 401(k) matches and winter-related operational expenses are highest in the first quarter of the year. Accordingly, based on historical experience, expenses are expected to be approximately $5 million higher next quarter. 
The next slide details our efficiency ratio over in the last 5 quarters. The efficiency ratio improved for the third consecutive quarter as we remain very focused on improving operating leverage. Slide 17 and 18 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Once again, we did see an improvement in nonperforming assets this quarter. Originated nonperforming assets as a percentage of originated loan and REO at 88 basis points remains well below our peer group and top 50 banks and is down from 108 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2013. 
Looking at Slide 18, net charge-offs remained low at 13 basis points, consistent with last quarter and improved from 18 basis points 1 year ago. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets. Slide 19 highlights our ability to grow both sides of the balance sheet. We continue to make progress on loan and deposit growth on a per share basis, while maintaining excellent credit quality. Over the past year, loans per share and deposits per share have grown at compound annual rate of 10% and 17%, respectively. As shown on Slide 20, operating return on average assets increased for the third consecutive quarter to 75 basis points. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the ultra-low interest environment and some initiatives, which are still ramping up to more normal levels of productivity. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses. 
Slide 21 illustrates the continued improvement in our return on average tangible equity over recent quarters. We expect to see continued progress over time on this metric as we improve profitability. On Slide 22, capital levels at the holding company and the bank remain strong, especially in light of our low-risk business model with a tangible common equity ratio at 7.5%, Tier 1 common at 9.8% and total risk base capital at 12.2%. 
Slide 23 illustrates our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we remain asset-sensitive, though slightly less so than last quarter. Year-over-year, we are slightly more asset-sensitive. We remain well positioned for an eventual rise in short-term rates. Now I'll pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. As we move into 2015, we are fortunate to have significant opportunities before us, which can and should provide earnings growth for the years to come. We look to sustain momentum through continued investments and talent, products and se
componenttext: Thank you, David. As we move into 2015, we are fortunate to have significant opportunities before us, which can and should provide earnings growth for the years to come. We look to sustain momentum through continued investments and talent, products and services, while remaining vigilant on expense management. We are committed to successfully building this organization for the long-term and delivering value to both customers and shareholders. This concludes our presentation. Now we'll be happy to answer any questions you may have. Operator, we are ready for questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttextpreview: If you can talk a little bit about the deposit growth trends, specifically the brokered deposits are still a significant portion of your deposit growth. It looks like half of the deposit growth this quarter was brokered. So I want to get your updated thou
componenttext: If you can talk a little bit about the deposit growth trends, specifically the brokered deposits are still a significant portion of your deposit growth. It looks like half of the deposit growth this quarter was brokered. So I want to get your updated thoughts on your plans to continue to drive growth with a brokered product and then your -- expectation for how much you could still see growth there. And then separately, what caused,which you's are putting the brokered deposits on the balance sheet at.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. It's David. So in 2014, we had just around $2.5 billion of brokered deposits growth. And we really built position that as a transition year for us as we continue to build out our commercial deposit gathering capabilities. The -- our expectatio
componenttext: Sure, John. It's David. So in 2014, we had just around $2.5 billion of brokered deposits growth. And we really built position that as a transition year for us as we continue to build out our commercial deposit gathering capabilities. The -- our expectation for 2015, you would see a significant reduction in the reliance on brokered deposits. We -- in the last half of 2014, we continue to see incremental improvements in commercial deposit gathering and we would expect that to continue. The -- from a cost basis, the cost are very similar to what we discussed last quarter. The -- most of those deposits are in the form of money market deposits with an average cost of around 17 basis points. And the -- we also have a laddered CD portfolio of brokered deposits, which has an average cost of about 65 basis points at the end of the year.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then how does that play to your expectation for overall deposit cost in coming quarters?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then how does that play to your expectation for overall deposit cost in coming quarters?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the brokered deposits are actually lowering our overall cost of deposits because of the largest component of that is coming in at 17 basis points. Our fourth quarter deposit costs were 34 basis points. In total, that was up 1 basis point quarter-ove
componenttext: Well, the brokered deposits are actually lowering our overall cost of deposits because of the largest component of that is coming in at 17 basis points. Our fourth quarter deposit costs were 34 basis points. In total, that was up 1 basis point quarter-over-quarter. The -- so there is a positive impact from the brokered deposits activity that we did in 2014, not a negative impact.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then lastly, in terms of loan yields, just wanted to get a little bit detail on what yields you're putting on new loan production by portfolio.
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then lastly, in terms of loan yields, just wanted to get a little bit detail on what yields you're putting on new loan production by portfolio.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a pretty -- as you know, we got many portfolios. As I think, first, as we always address this issue, we talk mainly about spreads, and we've been monitory spreads forever. But certainly, through '14 and into '15, we have noticed that spreads have c
componenttext: That's a pretty -- as you know, we got many portfolios. As I think, first, as we always address this issue, we talk mainly about spreads, and we've been monitory spreads forever. But certainly, through '14 and into '15, we have noticed that spreads have come in, in the second half of '14 generally. And while not in every portfolio, there is some modest 25-basis-point pressure in most of the portfolios. So running from a commercial real estate through middle-market C&I and a there are some places like ABL and mortgage warehouse, where spreads are holding or actually improving slightly, business banking and holding. But on the larger portfolios of commercial real estate and C&I, they continue to show pressure.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Dave Rochester from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Dave Rochester from Deutsche Bank.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick 1 on your margin guidance. It looks like in order to hit that middle of the range of $290 million, you're expecting maybe about 4 basis points of pressure for quarter through the year. Are you expecting that loan yields coming down or you're going
componenttext: A quick 1 on your margin guidance. It looks like in order to hit that middle of the range of $290 million, you're expecting maybe about 4 basis points of pressure for quarter through the year. Are you expecting that loan yields coming down or you're going to drive that bulk of the pressure in addition of some of the run off of the lower cost brokered deposits that you're talking about? Is there any accretion roll off or debt issuance in that at all?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: The primary driver around the margin guidance is the driver in 2014. And it's just the loan growth, the new business loan growth, going on at rates lower than the total portfolio yield. So there's not an expectation that our funding cost will have any mat
componenttext: The primary driver around the margin guidance is the driver in 2014. And it's just the loan growth, the new business loan growth, going on at rates lower than the total portfolio yield. So there's not an expectation that our funding cost will have any material change at all. It's an asset issue. And on the asset side, it's primarily almost exclusively on the loan side rather than the investment portfolio side.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And the switching to capital with the growth that you're talking about, the high single-digit, low double-digit loan growth you're expecting, would you expect capital ratios could continue to decline through 2015 just given the trend we've seen r
componenttext: Got you. And the switching to capital with the growth that you're talking about, the high single-digit, low double-digit loan growth you're expecting, would you expect capital ratios could continue to decline through 2015 just given the trend we've seen recently? And if so, is there any thought to supplement Tier 1 with preferred since you have added definitely the capacity to do that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dave. You did see TCE come down about 40 basis points over the course of 2014. We would expect TCE to again come down incrementally as 2015 unfolds. The -- we do have the capacity to do Tier 1 not trust preferred, preferred stock. We don't currently
componenttext: Sure, Dave. You did see TCE come down about 40 basis points over the course of 2014. We would expect TCE to again come down incrementally as 2015 unfolds. The -- we do have the capacity to do Tier 1 not trust preferred, preferred stock. We don't currently have plans to do that. But depending on the growth of the balance sheet, it could make sense as we have none in our capital structure today.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And can you talk about maybe some of the targets in the capital ratios over the next couple of years of TCE? Maybe Tier 1 capital? Anything you guys have to share there?
componenttext: Okay. And can you talk about maybe some of the targets in the capital ratios over the next couple of years of TCE? Maybe Tier 1 capital? Anything you guys have to share there?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we -- from a TCE perspective, which is where more normally ask questions, we could see TCE fall from the 7.5% at year-end down towards around 7% over the course of the year. That would imply growth of around $2.5 billion or so in risk-weighted as
componenttext: Sure. So we -- from a TCE perspective, which is where more normally ask questions, we could see TCE fall from the 7.5% at year-end down towards around 7% over the course of the year. That would imply growth of around $2.5 billion or so in risk-weighted assets, maybe just slightly above that. And that -- you would see our Tier 1 -- our leverage ratio runs at about 40 basis points higher than TCE. And you would see a consistent change there as well. From an operating target perspective, we have the ability to bring our capital ratios down within about a 50-basis-point range. So we -- our ratios at year-end are in the neighborhood of about 50 basis points higher than our long-term operating target.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttext: And so if we're seeing the Tier 1 capital ratio of somewhere on the, I guess, the high 9s here, we should expect maybe 50 bps to come off of that. And so that could be in the low 9s for the end of this year? And so that goes to your point, if you have any more growth than what you're talking, are you at the higher end of your range, maybe it makes sense to issue some preferred to move that Tier 1 capital ratio out?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- what we ended the year at 1 O2, if I recall the high in the year was probably around 105 or so, maybe at the end of the first quarter. And we talked about bringing it down incrementally over the year. That's about where our levels is. We really are
componenttext: The -- what we ended the year at 1 O2, if I recall the high in the year was probably around 105 or so, maybe at the end of the first quarter. And we talked about bringing it down incrementally over the year. That's about where our levels is. We really are working that message that I think that is most important, is we're really working the levers that we can to bring our loan-to-deposit ratio down to 100 or even better below. It takes time to do that. So depending how the year unfolds, loan growth relative to deposit growth, we could see that metric deteriorate a little bit over the course of the year. But our expectation would be to do everything we can to bring it back down as close to 100 as possible.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the other part of that is you did the math right, and we're not certainly uncomfortable getting up in that 105% range where we've been, and I would think of it as a range. But as David just said, we certainly have focus on growing the deposits acr
componenttext: I think the other part of that is you did the math right, and we're not certainly uncomfortable getting up in that 105% range where we've been, and I would think of it as a range. But as David just said, we certainly have focus on growing the deposits across the different business lines and the different markets. We've talked many times before about the opportunities in New York and Massachusetts, just growing both retail and commercial deposits and we're doing so very nicely. So it's -- like everything, it's something we watch and manage, but we have initiatives and things in motion to keep that in the right place.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay, on the expense side, the 2015 guidance calls for a fairly modest increase in expenses and relative to the revenue guidance implies a better efficiency ratio in 2015 but still quite a little bit of room to improve. My question here is for yo
componenttext: Got you. Okay, on the expense side, the 2015 guidance calls for a fairly modest increase in expenses and relative to the revenue guidance implies a better efficiency ratio in 2015 but still quite a little bit of room to improve. My question here is for you, David. As the recently appointed CFO, what's your assessment of the expense base of the company? And is there an ability to reduce the overall level of expense and make a more meaningful drive on the efficiency ratio lower?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: My overall assessment of the company's expense base is not necessarily informed because of the position I'm now in. I work for 7.5 years and I've seen some significant changes in the way we think about expenses. And I've seen significant expenses come out
componenttext: My overall assessment of the company's expense base is not necessarily informed because of the position I'm now in. I work for 7.5 years and I've seen some significant changes in the way we think about expenses. And I've seen significant expenses come out of our cost structure. My mind goes back to the -- what we call the IMA process that we've talked about before. Our expense management, oversight committee, which has been in place since the end of 2011. We -- if that committee as the control on expenses and has been very successful over the last couple of years. That's what I attribute our success on maintaining the expense base to date. I think they are -- we have ability, as a company, to continue to hold expenses flat and my expectation would be that we will. And it's just -- but I think of it because there's been so much done today as increment -- continued incremental improvement in the way we think Canada expenses, not that I walked in the door as in this new position and think that there's a large things that will -- that we could take out of the expense base.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So maybe what I'm hearing, as you think much of the heavy lifting has been done, and there's not much room for factor trim per se.
componenttext: So maybe what I'm hearing, as you think much of the heavy lifting has been done, and there's not much room for factor trim per se.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say that it's a fair assessment. I mean,...
componenttext: I would say that it's a fair assessment. I mean,...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean -- I just got to respond to that, Steve. I mean, we've done a lot of heavy lifting. We closed a lot of branches. We've trained a lot of areas, we worked a lot of contract term. We've consolidated a lot of real estate occupancy levels. And because w
componenttext: I mean -- I just got to respond to that, Steve. I mean, we've done a lot of heavy lifting. We closed a lot of branches. We've trained a lot of areas, we worked a lot of contract term. We've consolidated a lot of real estate occupancy levels. And because we did all of that lifting, we were able to take on teams to drive revenues and growing markets and enabled to deal with the increased regulatory burden around the BSA and compliance, and, et cetera, and test stress testing. So when you look at our flat earnings -- and when we look at it, we feel very, very good about having achieved that, given all of the pressure to invest in those 2 areas. And when we think about our IMA process and think about how we are moving forward and the way we worked this year's budget. There's plenty of the heavy lifting going forward to do exactly the same type of things. We are still -- we still have plans to reduce and close some branches. Were still consolidating some real estate where we can. We are still working contracts very hard. So I think as David said, this is something that's in motion. It's been in motion and it's going to stay in motion as long as we're here. But maybe to the other side of your question, I think we all feel very good about the growth and the way we are building the company for the long term as we say. And to do some draconian things, we absolutely think that we would be damaging the prospects for achieving the goals we have on the other side. We do -- we want to do things very thoughtfully and stay disciplined.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful color, Jack. Maybe 1 final question. On the loan growth where you delivered 9% in 2014 and as we look to the 2015 guidance, what gives you more confidence or confidence that you can grow at the same or even better level in 2015? And m
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful color, Jack. Maybe 1 final question. On the loan growth where you delivered 9% in 2014 and as we look to the 2015 guidance, what gives you more confidence or confidence that you can grow at the same or even better level in 2015? And maybe talk about some of the businesses that you're looking to drive the loan growth this year.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, I would -- just go to the general confidence, I start with -- if you look at '14 and you look across the different business lines, we really have some really nice growth across geographies in the portfolios and across specialty businesses. So
componenttext: Sure. Well, I would -- just go to the general confidence, I start with -- if you look at '14 and you look across the different business lines, we really have some really nice growth across geographies in the portfolios and across specialty businesses. So we have -- we brought and built talent. We have had some talents for a long time, and all of these teams in the market are executing. So if we look at 2012, '13 and '14 and you see the growth that we've achieved in the portfolios and it really is in a very diversified kind of manner. So that as we went into our planning cycle this year and we work with Jeff -- and then managers in the commercial banking area, we went segment by segment, and we look at our pipelines and we looked at where the teams are in terms of momentum and built our plans around that. So as very detailed as you can imagine. It was very specific to the different geographies. The 1 big challenge that strikes me that I would mention is commercial real estate. We're seeing growth next year. But it's been a big struggle this year. And except for New York where we've continued to make very nice progress, that's been a tough 1. We are expecting to make progress in other parts of our franchise next year, particularly Boston. So it really is diversified. It's across-the-board. And hopefully, you can hear where the confidence comes from.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I have a question for Jack on the in-store branches. One of your peers, BOK Financial, exited their in-store branches basically making say that those -- it is not a great place to build relationships for the clients. Can you just address how you guys view
componenttext: I have a question for Jack on the in-store branches. One of your peers, BOK Financial, exited their in-store branches basically making say that those -- it is not a great place to build relationships for the clients. Can you just address how you guys view in-store branches as being a better use of your locations?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously, I don't know the company or the example that you're giving so we'll just talk about us. We are very happy with the continued development of our in-store branches and kind of grow to kind of the question around the relationship building. S
componenttext: Sure. Obviously, I don't know the company or the example that you're giving so we'll just talk about us. We are very happy with the continued development of our in-store branches and kind of grow to kind of the question around the relationship building. So there's a lot there, but -- so if you look at our results over time in Connecticut, we have the largest deposit on average deposit -- excuse me, the largest average deposit per in-store branch in the nation in Connecticut. What we acquired in New York is coming -- continues to come along nicely. And so our comfort with our in-store results and our confidence as thinking about moving forward comes from a lot from our experience and our success to date. In building relationships, first thing that comes to my mind is we look at the activity of our customers that use the in stores and how they interact with the company on all fronts. And they are identified as in-store because of -- because that's where they primarily due their business, but they often transact with us in other branches as well including traditional. In addition to that, we origin 8 out of the in-store platforms, a lot of residential and home equity loans this year, '14, particularly home loans. So we set up the in-store branches with 2 private offices, so that customers, if they do engage with us and are interested in that type of transaction, we can bring them back, give them, close the door, give them privacy and pursue that and we do a lot of training of our staff to be able to take that application and work with that customer. And that's what builds the relationship, right? So we sell our full product set through our in-store branches. I think that differentiates us from many that be in that area. We service a small-business loans and small business customers in the branches. Many of our customers, we find like in the weekend hours. We just had our added retail banking on Lombardi today. We talked about the story about the very happy customer, who was someone else's customers was in our store and heard our folks promoting home equity over the loudspeaker and actually came in and deal a loan on with us on a Saturday. And incrementally, that's the kind of thing that is going to help us move someone else's customer in our shop. So we're very pleased with our in-store results and prospects for the future. We just opened up several new ones in New York under our contract with Stop & Shop as in Brooklyn and we're looking forward to that coming online.

componenttext: Sure. I would say, the answer there is we are constantly looking at all our markets. And many of our market leaders periodically suggest to see opportunities that we evaluate. Generally, in the -- our existing kind of legacy footprints, we're well represented and not emphasizing taking on new opportunities. But sometimes, in some markets, there are better locations and maybe cheaper locations that do become available. So we don't close our mind in any of that, that make those of our activity in the last few years and I think will go forward, you could expect New York and Boston would be the larger markets, we're were underrepresented in terms of market share, we're growing our share and we are growing our other brands and we look for opportunities there.

componenttext: Yes, we do. And we're actually very pleased with how the joint venture is developing on these first few -- the first 6 months, I guess, roughly since we closed. And particularly, as you get into larger enterprises that needs a stronger technology, stronger product set there. And we have had very nice success over the last 6 months in moving some business into the joint venture, and we're all happy with that. We got approximately $500,000 in the fourth quarter in revenue from the joint venture.

componenttext: It's a little more front-end loaded. The first quarter, we usually lose about 5 basis points just the day count out. And then you would see that normalized. And the way I would characterize 2015 that would be a much steady year margin. Those still margin pressure with a rate of decline on a quarterly basis through the year should moderate.

componenttext: Okay, great. And that's helpful. I guess, one of the questions around rates. I know you talked about how the rate sensitivity had dropped quarter-over-quarter it was a pretty far off than what was [indiscernible] I'm serious sort of how do you expect the rate sensitivity to [indiscernible] through the year given sort of your loan to deposit growth outlook.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think you -- we will see our rate sensitivity where we ended the year or incrementally increase and kind of go back to where we were at mid-year or at the end of the third quarter, which was the low 40s. The -- again, one of the big issues will be what'
componenttext: I think you -- we will see our rate sensitivity where we ended the year or incrementally increase and kind of go back to where we were at mid-year or at the end of the third quarter, which was the low 40s. The -- again, one of the big issues will be what's happened in rates just in the last couple of weeks, whether that is here to stay for all of 2015 or rates back up a little bit. What I would add is the -- in the fourth quarter of every year, we go through and look at all of our model assumptions. And we tuned our model a little bit, a little more conservatively, around some of our deposit assumptions. And that was a driver as well with the roughly $10 million decrease in up 100 sensitivity. So some of that was not balance sheet driven. It was model driven.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a question about credit quality. I mean, clearly your credit losses are very low and have been over a quite period of time. But in terms of your goal, you talked about maintaining excellent credit quality. So I was curious how once you think ab
componenttext: I just had a question about credit quality. I mean, clearly your credit losses are very low and have been over a quite period of time. But in terms of your goal, you talked about maintaining excellent credit quality. So I was curious how once you think about the seasoning of your loan portfolio, generally that seems to be a term associated with largely consumer loans. But to the extent that you've grown more quickly than the market has and those loans mature, would you expect there to be upward pressure on your loss provision? Or do you expect the loss provisions I mean relatively -- that. How do you think about that and charge-off rates as well?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Basically, I would say, we feel the -- if you look forward, if you look back and look at that tight range of our net charge-off ratios over the last few years, we would expect it to look in a similar range as we go forward. And so when we make that statem
componenttext: Basically, I would say, we feel the -- if you look forward, if you look back and look at that tight range of our net charge-off ratios over the last few years, we would expect it to look in a similar range as we go forward. And so when we make that statement, we expect to continue a strong credit quality, that's kind of the context. We have a long heritage of being very disciplined underwriters. The people that are involved with our underwriting as we moved through this growth period are the same folks that have been involved for many years. We've got a very seasoned teams of that work very closely together, and everybody takes a lot of pride in being very, very thoughtful about what we do. So we do expect it to continue with good results. We are not concerned about the growth that has occurred and whether our fundamentals have changed at all. We're very comfortable with what we've been putting on the books.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we shouldn't expect any sort of front-loaded bubble, if you will, in charge-offs. Again, on a relatively low this, but some sort of front-loaded bubble?
componenttext: So we shouldn't expect any sort of front-loaded bubble, if you will, in charge-offs. Again, on a relatively low this, but some sort of front-loaded bubble?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, not at all. I think, again if you -- in the way I think about it is 12 basis points was a low. If I remember right in over the last number of years. We've had a few quarters where we might have credit that is trouble and it creates a lumpiness, my ter
componenttext: No, not at all. I think, again if you -- in the way I think about it is 12 basis points was a low. If I remember right in over the last number of years. We've had a few quarters where we might have credit that is trouble and it creates a lumpiness, my term, in the results. But again, if you look back over quarter-by-quarter, our net charge-off ratio within that range, that's where we would expect it to be.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttext: Okay. So just curious, if there's any update going on there.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're trying to get to -- we had very strong growth in commercial deposits this year, which is probably right. The clearest way to giving any indication that we are being successful. And the programs that we're doing so, we've mentioned incentives, w
componenttext: Yes. We're trying to get to -- we had very strong growth in commercial deposits this year, which is probably right. The clearest way to giving any indication that we are being successful. And the programs that we're doing so, we've mentioned incentives, we are not planning any dramatic shift there. We have increased focus on incentives on deposits gathering in the past and we'll keep that consistent moving forward. And then, we talked about the fact that every opportunity we get to look at a credit event or other event without any relationships. We're closely monitoring our return in equity and profitability levels and that's a strong tool for us to be working with the relationship managers to be cross-selling generally, including gathering deposits. So above 10% commercial deposit growth, I think on the midteens this year and we're recently looking for that to continue.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay and then my last question is just tied to the gain that the security gains. And you give some color on that, $2.3 million. Can you just talk about that? Is there some sort of a time based that you realized? Or is just some context around that will be
componenttext: Okay and then my last question is just tied to the gain that the security gains. And you give some color on that, $2.3 million. Can you just talk about that? Is there some sort of a time based that you realized? Or is just some context around that will be helpful?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Sameer. It's David. To put it in context, you really never see security gains come out of our company. That's not something you see in the quarterly results. This was 1 security that came from an acquired institution. It was a security that isn't of
componenttext: Sure, Sameer. It's David. To put it in context, you really never see security gains come out of our company. That's not something you see in the quarterly results. This was 1 security that came from an acquired institution. It was a security that isn't of the nature that we would normally hold. And it the acquisition was a time where there was not much demand for this type of security in the market. So we decided to hold it rather than fire sell it at times of acquisition. It had a low cost basis on it from purchase accounting. And the security was called last quarter and paid off at bar and that's what generated what we would call a one-time-gain. We have no other securities at this nature on the balance sheet.

componenttext: Very consistent with the trends you saw this year. The -- when we think about the products and we think about the geography, I wouldn't expect any significant changes other than probably our mortgage warehouse business. That grew more than expectations in the fourth quarter. It's up about $81 million if I recall. And it ran higher in the fourth quarter than we were expecting. So away from mortgage warehouse coming off, I think you'll see consistent growth in '15 relative to '14.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Full Year and Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Steve, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Full Year and Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Steve, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, David Rosato, Kirk Walters and Jeff Hoyt are here with me to review the fourth quarter and full year 2014 results. Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Sl
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, David Rosato, Kirk Walters and Jeff Hoyt are here with me to review the fourth quarter and full year 2014 results. Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted in our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. Let me start by noting that we have completed the transition of our Chief Financial Officer position, effective January 1, 2015. As announced last April, Kirk Walters has transiti
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. Let me start by noting that we have completed the transition of our Chief Financial Officer position, effective January 1, 2015. As announced last April, Kirk Walters has transitioned out of the role for family reasons, and he has been succeeded by David Rosato. I appreciate how effectively Kirk and David have worked together to complete the transition seamlessly. Kirk remains an executive officer heading up Corporate Development and Strategic Planning, and continues to be a member of the Management Committee. He also remains as a member of the Board of Directors of the company and the bank.
I would like to take this opportunity to thank Kirk for all of his outstanding contributions in his previous role, and look forward to continuing to leverage his broad industry experience and deep operational expertise in his new role. Thank you, Kirk.
As has been our custom, in addition to reviewing the fourth quarter and full year results, I will outline our goals for 2015. Our performance for 2014 once again demonstrated the benefits of our deep customer relationships, product breadth and ongoing strategic initiatives. We continue to build the business for the long term, and made significant investments in talent, products and services. This included adding a veteran wealth management team based in Hartford, Connecticut and a considerable number of experienced commercial bankers in Massachusetts. We also continue to evaluate the best ways to serve our customers and grow our businesses, as evidenced by the announcement of the Merchant Services joint venture in July.
Slide 2 provides an overview of our 2014 results. We are pleased to report full year operating earnings of $245 million, a 2% increase from 2013. On a per share basis, operating earnings were $0.82, a 6% increase from the prior year, and marks the fifth consecutive year of growth in operating earnings per share. We are building on the momentum generated in recent years through our focus on growing loans and deposits, which in turn creates new opportunities and deepens existing relationships.
Compared to 2013, loans and deposits increased 9% and 16%, respectively. Organic deposits had very solid growth of $1.1 billion or 5%. As we further strengthen relationships in the New York and Massachusetts markets, our deposit base will continue to see growth.
Net interest income increased 3% from the prior year, despite the net interest margin declining 22 basis points. This decline was primarily due to the impact of strong loan originations at rates lower than our existing portfolio. Noninterest income, excluding the $20.6 million gain on the Merchant Services joint venture in the second quarter of this year, declined $12 million, or 3%, due to lower gains on residential mortgage sales.
We were especially pleased that expense levels remained flat compared to the prior year, considering the continued impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance costs. This focus on effective expense management improved our operating leverage during the year, as evidenced by an improvement in the efficiency ratio to 62.1% from 62.3%.
Asset quality continued to be exceptional. Net charge-offs in 2014 of only 12 basis points is the lowest level in over 5 years. This is a reflection of dedication to strong underwriting standards, the economic strength of the region we operate in and the long-term relationships we have with our customers.
On Slide 3, we have provided a snapshot of last year's goals compared to actual results. In general, we were in line with most of our expectations. Net interest income was below goal, primarily as a result of loan growth in the net interest margin coming in near the lower end of the targeted range. Noninterest income, excluding the $20.6 million gain on the Merchant Services joint venture, was also below the targeted range, primarily attributable to lower gains on residential mortgage sales and insurance revenues.
On Slide 4, we provided more detail behind the increase in net interest income from 2013. Strong originated loan growth drove net interest income higher by $65 million. This increase was partially offset by the runoff in the acquired loan portfolio resulting in declines in accretion of $46 million. As we have mentioned before, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing loss accretion on the acquired portfolio is a positive sign looking ahead. The acquired loan portfolio ended the year at $1.1 billion, down nearly $500 million from 2013, and represents less than 5% of total loan portfolio.
On Slide 5, you can see our annual net interest margin results, which declined 22 basis points to 3.09%. The margin was impacted by declining benchmark interest rates and tightening credit spreads over the course of the year. New loan volume and mix negatively impacted the margin by 21 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield.
On Slide 6, we provide additional detail behind the change in noninterest income from 2013. As I mentioned before, excluding the 2014 gain on the Merchant Services joint venture, noninterest income declined 3% from the prior period. The decline was driven by lower gains on the sales of residential mortgage loans and acquired loans. Partially offsetting these declines were an increase in operating leases as well as strong results by our wealth management business, driven by a 12% increase in investment management revenues.
On Slide 7, we provided additional color around expenses. As I mentioned earlier, we were especially pleased with results were flat compared to the prior year.
Moving on to Slide 8. Our primary goals are listed for 2015. As I referenced earlier, we remain committed to investing strategically in the franchise. The breadth of products and services we provide and the exceptional talent we have attracted will enable us to build new customer relationships and deepen existing ones. These ongoing investments, in combination with our large and attractive markets as well as an unwavering commitment to relationship-based banking, have driven and will continue to drive growth.
With that background in mind, let me outline our goals: first is to grow loans at a high single- to low double-digit rate; second is to grow deposits in the mid- to high single digits; next is to grow net interest income in the low to mid-single digits. Embedded in this goal is an expectation for a net interest margin in the range of 2.85% to 2.95%. Another goal is to grow noninterest income in the low single digits after adjusting for the 2014 gain on the Merchant Services joint venture. We will continue to tightly control costs by keeping our operating expenses essentially flat within the range of $835 million to $845 million. The final goal is to maintain excellent credit quality and strong capital levels.
These goals reflect an assumption that interest rates remain at or near current levels. We look forward to executing on the opportunities that we have created to achieve these goals.
With that, I will pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. With respect to our fourth quarter performance, please turn to Slide 9 for an overview. Operating earnings were $65.1 million, or $0.22 per share, compared to $63 million, or $0.21 per share, in the third quarter. I will discuss the other
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. With respect to our fourth quarter performance, please turn to Slide 9 for an overview. Operating earnings were $65.1 million, or $0.22 per share, compared to $63 million, or $0.21 per share, in the third quarter. I will discuss the other results shown on this overview in greater detail on subsequent slides.
Moving to Slide 10. We provide detail behind the linked-quarter change in net interest income. The overall results between the 2 quarters were generally consistent. Strong originated loan growth resulted in a $2.2 million increase in net interest income from the third quarter, while a decline in accretion from runoff in the acquired portfolio as well as increased deposit volume lowered net interest income by $1.9 million and $1.5 million, respectively. As Jack mentioned earlier, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing loss accretion on the acquired portfolio is a positive sign looking to the quarters ahead.
On Slide 11, you can see a breakdown of the elements contributing to our quarterly net interest margin results, which declined 5 basis points to 3%. The primary driver of this decline was new loan volume, which negatively impacted the margin by 5 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield.
Slide 12 provides a breakdown of the increase in loans. The loan portfolio grew $638 million or 10% annualized. This marks our 17th consecutive quarter of loan growth, and is a testament to our relationship managers and customers. These results were achieved through leveraging in our expanded footprint as well as progress in our heritage markets.
Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $767 million. As in prior quarters, growth was well-balanced from a product and geographic perspective. Commercial real estate contributed $174 million of the total originated loan growth, while C&I contributed $380 million. Within C&I, we saw a particular strength in our asset-based lending and equipment finance businesses. The commercial portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry.
Residential mortgages in the consumer portfolio contributed $203 million and $10 million of originated loan growth, respectively. The growth in residential mortgages was driven in part by strong originations and lower prepayments.
We experienced acquired loan runoff of $129 million this quarter, compared to $98 million in the third quarter and $137 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. The increase in runoff from the third quarter was primarily driven by the payoffs of 2 large loans.
Slide 13 shows a breakdown of the elements contributing to the increase in deposits from the third quarter. Organic deposits increased $472 million or 8% on an annualized basis, as retail and commercial deposits grew $304 million and $168 million, respectively.
Total deposits increased $877 million, supported by brokered deposit growth of $405 million. As we previous -- as we have discussed previously, we are underweight commercial deposits and continue to make changes to further emphasize deposit gathering. We firmly believe that deposits are an important part of customer relationships, and our ongoing focus remains on growing organic deposits.
On Slide 14, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income grew 3% in the third quarter, driven by net security gains of $2.5 million, of which $2.3 million was from the call of a single acquired security as well as increased customer interest rate swap income of $1.4 million. Partially offsetting these increases was $2.2 million in lower insurance revenues from a seasonally strong third quarter.
On Slide 15, we illustrate the key components of changes in noninterest expense during the quarter. Similar to the full year results discussed earlier, expenses remained flat. As we have mentioned before, we continue to tightly control expenses, while investing in revenue-producing initiatives and covering the higher costs of regulatory compliance. As a reminder, payroll taxes, 401(k) matches and winter-related operational expenses are highest in the first quarter of the year. Accordingly, based on historical experience, expenses are expected to be approximately $5 million higher next quarter.
The next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. The efficiency ratio improved for the third consecutive quarter as we remain very focused on improving operating leverage. Slide 17 and 18 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Once again, we did see an improvement in nonperforming assets this quarter. Originated nonperforming assets as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 88 basis points remains well below our peer group and top 50 banks and is down from 108 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2013.
Looking at Slide 18, net charge-offs remained low at 13 basis points, consistent with last quarter and improved from 18 basis points 1 year ago. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets. Slide 19 highlights our ability to grow both sides of the balance sheet. We continue to make progress on loan and deposit growth on a per share basis, while maintaining excellent credit quality.
Over the past year, loans per share and deposits per share have grown at compound annual rates of 10% and 17%, respectively. As shown on Slide 20, operating return on average assets increased for the third consecutive quarter to 75 basis points. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the ultra-low interest rate environment and some initiatives, which are still ramping up to more normal levels of productivity. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses.
Slide 21 illustrates the continued improvement in our return on average tangible equity over recent quarters. We expect to see continued progress, over time, on this metric as we improve profitability.
On Slide 22, capital levels at the holding company and the bank remained strong, especially in light of our low-risk business model with a tangible common equity ratio at 7.5%, Tier 1 common at 9.8% and total risk-based capital at 12.2%.
Slide 23 illustrates our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twists. As you can see, we remain asset-sensitive, though slightly less so than last quarter. Year-over-year, we are slightly more asset-sensitive. We remain well-positioned for an eventual rise in short-term rates.
Now I'll pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. As we move into 2015, we are fortunate to have significant opportunities before us, which can and should provide earnings growth for the years to come. We look to sustain momentum through continued investments and talent, products and se
componenttext:
Thank you, David. As we move into 2015, we are fortunate to have significant opportunities before us, which can and should provide earnings growth for the years to come. We look to sustain momentum through continued investments and talent, products and services, while remaining vigilant on expense management. We are committed to successfully building this organization for the long-term and delivering value to both customers and shareholders.
This concludes our presentation. Now we'll be happy to answer any questions that you may have. Operator, we are ready for questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Please stand by for your first question, and it's from the line of John Pancari from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Please stand by for your first question, and it's from the line of John Pancari from Evercore ISI.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: If you can talk a little bit about deposit growth trends, specifically the brokered deposits are still a significant portion of your deposit growth. It looks like about half of the deposit growth this quarter was brokered. So I wanted to get your updated
componenttext: If you can talk a little bit about deposit growth trends, specifically the brokered deposits are still a significant portion of your deposit growth. It looks like about half of the deposit growth this quarter was brokered. So I wanted to get your updated thoughts on your plans to continue to drive growth with the brokered product and then your -- just your overall expectation for how much you could still see growth there. And then separately, what cost at which you're putting the brokered deposits on the balance sheet at?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, John. It's David. So in 2014, we had just around $2.5 billion of brokered deposit growth. And we really built our position that as a transition year for us as we continue to build out our commercial deposit gathering capabilities. The -- our expecta
componenttext: Sure, John. It's David. So in 2014, we had just around $2.5 billion of brokered deposit growth. And we really built our position that as a transition year for us as we continue to build out our commercial deposit gathering capabilities. The -- our expectation for 2015, you would see a significant reduction in the reliance on brokered deposits. We -- in the last half of 2014, we continued to see incremental improvements in commercial deposit gathering and we would expect that to continue. The -- from a cost basis, the costs are very similar to what we discussed last quarter. The -- most of those deposits are in the form of money market deposits with an average cost of around 17 basis points. And the -- we also have a laddered CD portfolio of brokered deposits, which has an average cost of about 65 basis points at the end of the year.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then how does that play into your expectation for overall deposit cost in coming quarters?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then how does that play into your expectation for overall deposit cost in coming quarters?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the brokered deposits are actually lowering our overall cost of deposits because of the largest component of that is coming in at 17 basis points. Our fourth quarter deposit costs were 34 basis points. In total, that was up 1 basis point, quarter-ov
componenttext: Well, the brokered deposits are actually lowering our overall cost of deposits because of the largest component of that is coming in at 17 basis points. Our fourth quarter deposit costs were 34 basis points. In total, that was up 1 basis point, quarter-over-quarter. The -- so there is a positive impact from the brokered deposit activity that we did in 2014, not a negative impact.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then lastly, in terms of loan yields, just wanted to get a little bit detail on what yields you're putting on new loan production by portfolio.
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then lastly, in terms of loan yields, just wanted to get a little bit detail on what yields you're putting on new loan production by portfolio.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's a pretty -- as you know, we got many portfolios. And I think, first, as we always address this issue, we talk mainly about spreads, and we've been monitoring spreads forever. But certainly, through '14 and into '15, we have noticed that spreads hav
componenttext: That's a pretty -- as you know, we got many portfolios. And I think, first, as we always address this issue, we talk mainly about spreads, and we've been monitoring spreads forever. But certainly, through '14 and into '15, we have noticed that spreads have come in, in the second half of '14, generally. And while not in every portfolio, there is some modest 25-basis-point pressure in most of the portfolios. So running from a commercial real estate through middle-market C&I, and there are some places, like ABL and mortgage warehouse, where spreads are holding or actually improving slightly, business banking and holding. But on the larger portfolios of commercial real estate and C&I, they continue to show pressure.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Dave Rochester from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Dave Rochester from Deutsche Bank.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick one on your margin guidance. It looks like, in order to hit the middle of that range of $290 million, you're expecting maybe about 4 basis points of pressure per quarter through the year. Are you expecting that loan yields coming down or going to
componenttext: A quick one on your margin guidance. It looks like, in order to hit the middle of that range of $290 million, you're expecting maybe about 4 basis points of pressure per quarter through the year. Are you expecting that loan yields coming down or going to drive that bulk of that pressure in addition to maybe some of the run-off of the lower-cost brokered deposits that you're talking about? Is there any accretion roll-off taken in that or debt issuance in that, at all?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: The primary driver around the margin guidance is the driver in 2014. And it's just the loan growth, the new business loan growth going on at rates lower than the total portfolio yield. So there's not an expectation that our funding costs will have any mat
componenttext: The primary driver around the margin guidance is the driver in 2014. And it's just the loan growth, the new business loan growth going on at rates lower than the total portfolio yield. So there's not an expectation that our funding costs will have any material change, at all. It's an asset issue. And on the asset side, it's primarily almost exclusively on the loan side rather than the investment portfolio side.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. And switching to capital with the growth that you're talking about, the high single-digit, low double-digit loan growth you're expecting, would you expect capital ratios could continue to decline through 2015, just given the trend that we've seen
componenttext: Got you. And switching to capital with the growth that you're talking about, the high single-digit, low double-digit loan growth you're expecting, would you expect capital ratios could continue to decline through 2015, just given the trend that we've seen recently? And if so, is there any thought to supplement any Tier 1 with preferred, since you definitely have the capacity to do that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Dave. You did see TCE come down about 40 basis points over the course of 2014. We would expect TCE to again come down incrementally as 2015 unfolds. The -- we do have the capacity to do Tier 1 -- not trust preferred, preferred stock. We don't curren
componenttext: Sure, Dave. You did see TCE come down about 40 basis points over the course of 2014. We would expect TCE to again come down incrementally as 2015 unfolds. The -- we do have the capacity to do Tier 1 -- not trust preferred, preferred stock. We don't currently have plans to do that. But depending on the growth of the balance sheet, it could make sense as we have none in our capital structure today.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you talk about maybe some of the targets on the capital ratios over the next couple of years of TCE, maybe Tier 1 capital? Anything that you, guys, have to share there?
componenttext: Okay. And could you talk about maybe some of the targets on the capital ratios over the next couple of years of TCE, maybe Tier 1 capital? Anything that you, guys, have to share there?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So from a TCE perspective, which is where we're most normally asked questions, we could see TCE fall from the 7.5% at year-end, down towards around 7% over the course of the year. That would imply growth of around $2.5 billion or so in risk-weighted
componenttext: Sure. So from a TCE perspective, which is where we're most normally asked questions, we could see TCE fall from the 7.5% at year-end, down towards around 7% over the course of the year. That would imply growth of around $2.5 billion or so in risk-weighted assets, maybe just slightly above that. And that would -- you would see our Tier 1 -- or our leverage ratio runs about 40 basis points higher than TCE, and you would see a consistent change there, as well. From an operating target perspective, we have the ability to bring our capital ratios down within about a 50-basis-point range. So we're -- our ratios at year-end are in the neighborhood of about 50 basis points higher than our long-term operating target.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015

componenttext: And so if we're seeing a Tier 1 capital ratio of somewhere on the, I guess, the high 9s here, we should expect maybe 50 bps to come off of that. And so that could be in the low 9s by the end of this year? And so that goes to your point, if you have any more growth than what you're talking about or you end up at the higher end of your range, maybe it makes sense to issue some preferred to move that Tier 1 capital ratio out?
