headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a question about credit quality. I mean, clearly, your credit losses are very low and have been over quite a period of time. But in terms of your goals, you talked about maintaining excellent credit quality. So I was curious how one should thin
componenttext: I just had a question about credit quality. I mean, clearly, your credit losses are very low and have been over quite a period of time. But in terms of your goals, you talked about maintaining excellent credit quality. So I was curious how one should think about the seasoning of your loan portfolio. Generally, that seems to be a term associated with, largely, consumer loans. But to the extent that you've grown more quickly than the market has and those loans mature, would you expect there to be upward pressure on your loss provisions? Or do you expect those loss provisions to be in a relatively tight band? How do you think about that and charge-off rates, as well?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Basically, I would say we feel the -- if you look forward -- if you look back and look at the tight range of our net charge-off ratios over the last few years, we would expect it to look in a similar range as we go forward. And so when we make the stateme
componenttext: Basically, I would say we feel the -- if you look forward -- if you look back and look at the tight range of our net charge-off ratios over the last few years, we would expect it to look in a similar range as we go forward. And so when we make the statement we expect to continue strong credit quality, that's kind of the context. We have a long heritage of being very disciplined underwriters. The people that are involved with our underwriting as we've moved through this growth period are the same folks that have been involved for many years. We've got very seasoned teams that work very closely together. And everybody takes a lot of pride in being very, very thoughtful about what we do. So we do expect it to continue that with good results. We are not concerned about the growth that has occurred and whether our fundamentals have changed at all. We're very comfortable with what we've been putting on the books.

componenttext: No, not at all. I think, again, if you -- the way I think about it is 12 basis points was a low. But again, if you look back over, quarter-by-quarter, our net charge-off ratio within that range, that's where we would expect it to be.

componenttext: Yes. Sorry, we were trying to get you -- we had very strong growth in commercial deposits this year, which is probably right. The clearest way to give you an indication that we are being successful in the programs that we're doing. So, we've mentioned incentives; we are not planning any dramatic shift there. We have increased focus on incentives on deposit-gathering in the past and we'll keep that consistent moving forward. And then we've talked about the fact that every opportunity we get to look at a credit event or other event with our relationships, we're closely monitoring return on equity and profitability levels, and that's a strong tool for us to be working with the relationship managers to be cross-selling generally, including gathering deposits. So above 10% commercial deposit growth, I think that's at mid-teens this year, and we're certainly looking for that to continue.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just my last question was tied to the gain that -- the security gain. And you gave some color on that, $2.3 million. Could you just talk about that? Was that some sort of time-based gain that you realized? Or just some context around that w
componenttext: Okay. And then just my last question was tied to the gain that -- the security gain. And you gave some color on that, $2.3 million. Could you just talk about that? Was that some sort of time-based gain that you realized? Or just some context around that would be helpful.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Sameer. It's David. To put it in context, you really never see security gains come out of our company. That's not something you see in the quarterly results. This was one security that came from an acquired institution. It was a security that isn't
componenttext: Sure, Sameer. It's David. To put it in context, you really never see security gains come out of our company. That's not something you see in the quarterly results. This was one security that came from an acquired institution. It was a security that isn't of the nature that we would normally hold. And it -- the acquisition was a time where there was not much demand for this type of security in the market. So we decided to hold it rather than fire sell it at the time of acquisition. It had a low cost basis on it from purchase accounting. And the security was called last quarter and paid off at par, and that's what generated what we would call a one-time gain. We have no other securities of this nature on the balance sheet.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kate, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being reco
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kate, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President with Investor Relations for People's United Financial, Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Hoyt, our controller, as well as other members of management are here with me to review the first
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Hoyt, our controller, as well as other members of management are here with me to review the first quarter of 2015 results.
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations.
With that, I'll turnover the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good morning. We appreciate everybody joining us today. Our performance this quarter is an encouraging start to the year, especially given the persistent low interest rate environment as well as the severe winter weather across our mark
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good morning. We appreciate everybody joining us today. Our performance this quarter is an encouraging start to the year, especially given the persistent low interest rate environment as well as the severe winter weather across our markets.
Results once again benefited from the investments we have made and continued to make in talent, products and services, within our large and attractive markets.
During the quarter, I spent a great deal of time visiting customers across our franchise and came away impressed with the opportunities we have to further deepen these relationships through cross-selling efforts. Our breath of products and services, superior customer service and local knowledge, uniquely positions us to not only meet the expanding needs of current customers, but also forge new relationships.
These visits reaffirm for me the value we provide to customers and the significant opportunities we have before us.
Turning to the overview of the quarter, on Slide 2, operating earnings increased 12% from a year ago to $63 million, making the highest level of operating earnings we have had in the first quarter of any year.
Revenues increased 1% from the fourth quarter, as noninterest income was higher and net interest income was flat. As a reminder, net interest income, along with net interest margin, were unfavorably impacted by 2 fewer calendar days in the first quarter.
In comparison to the prior year quarter, revenues increased 3%, driven by improvements in both net interest income and non-interest income.
As expected, operating expenses were modestly higher as compared to the fourth quarter, due to traditionally higher first quarter payroll-related and winter-related operational cost.
However, we were pleased operating expense levels remained flat compared to the prior year quarter, especially considering the continued impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance cost.
The efficiency ratio increased slightly to 61.9% in the first quarter from 61.3% last quarter, reflecting higher revenues and the seasonal uptick in operating expenses.
However, the ratio improved from 63.9% in the prior year quarter. While the first quarter is typically a seasonally lower period, we achieved solid annualized loan growth of 5%. This marks the 18th consecutive quarter of loan growth. We are pleased with the success of our deposit gathering initiatives, as evidenced by organic deposit growth of $1 billion in the quarter, which represents more than 17% growth on an annualized basis.
As we further develop our franchise-wide cross-sell and deposit gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. Asset quality was once again exceptional as net charge-offs and nonperforming assets improved from already low levels.
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter change and net interest income. Higher average balances and strong originated loan growth increased to net -- increased net interest income by $3.4 million and $2.8 million, respecti
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter change and net interest income. Higher average balances and strong originated loan growth increased to net -- increased net interest income by $3.4 million and $2.8 million, respectively. The largest offset to these increases was a $3.3 million reduction in net interest income due to 2 fewer calendar days in the first quarter.  Additionally, a decline in accretion from run-off in the acquired loan portfolio and increased deposit volume lowered net interest margin by $1.7 million and $1.1 million, respectively.
As mentioned on previous calls, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing lost accretion on the acquired portfolio is a positive sign looking to the quarters ahead.
On Slide 4, net interest margin for the first quarter was 2.91%, a decline of 9 basis points from the fourth quarter. As we mentioned on our last earnings call, fewer calendar days impacted the margin by 5 basis points in the first quarter. 
Additionally, new loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 2 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield.  We continue to expect the full year 2015 margin to be within the range of 2.85% to 2.95% as outlined in January.
Slide 5 provides a breakdown of the increase in loans. The loan portfolio grew $337 million, or 5% annualized. Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $430 million. As in previous quarters, growth was well-balanced from a product and geographic perspective.
C&I contributed $240 million of the total originated loan growth, while commercial real estate contributed $118 million. Within C&I, we experienced particular strength in our mortgage warehouse lending business.
The commercial portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages contributed $129 million of originated loan growth in the first quarter. Approximately 90% of the residential mortgage originations helped our investments where high-grade adjustable rate mortgages.
In addition, the residential mortgage portfolio is strong -- the residential mortgage pipeline is strong and ended the quarter at the highest level in 2 years. We experienced acquired loan run-off of $93 million this quarter, compared to $129 million in the fourth quarter, and $114 million in prior -- in the prior year quarter. The balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $958 million.
Slide 6 shows the growth in deposits by segment from the fourth quarter. Deposits increased over $1 billion, or 15.5% on an annualized basis, as commercial and retail deposits grew $635 million and $377 million, respectively. Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.6 billion, unchanged from the end of the fourth quarter. As such, the deposit growth in the first quarter was organically driven.
We experienced strong growth across all geographies and all business lines. Just as a reminder, the first and fourth quarters are typically our strongest quarters for deposits. It is worth noting that our loan-to-deposit ratio was 99% at March 31 and our cost of deposits came down 1 basis point in the quarter.
Overall, we are very pleased with the progress we are making gathering deposits. We firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships and we continue to focus on organic deposit growth.
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income grew 3% from the fourth quarter, and was primarily driven by strong commercial banking lending fees, higher customer interest rate swap income as well as gains on the sale of loans, which was primarily driven by the sale of 1 loan from the acquired portfolio. The increase in noninterest income was partially offset by the absence of security gains and lower bank service charges.
As you will recall in the fourth quarter, the net security gain resulted from the call of a single acquired security.
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes to non-interest expense during the quarter. Nonoperating expenses increased over $5 million, which is mainly attributable to branch closure costs. We closed 8 branches during the first quarter as we continue to optimize our branch delivery channel.
Since the beginning of 2011, we have closed 44 branches, which were mostly traditional branches. During the same period, we opened 24 branches, many of which are more cost-efficient in-store branches.
We expect to close approximately 10 more branches during the remainder of the year as well as to look for opportunities to reduce real estate cost further by consolidating other facilities. We are committed to branches, as they provide valuable support to revenue-generating activities across all of our business lines.
From an operating perspective, expenses increased $4.5 million from the fourth quarter. Compensation and benefits increased $6.6 million, primarily due to traditionally higher first quarter payroll related and benefit cost, while occupancy and equipment cost increased $2.4 million, of which approximately 1/2 was due to higher snow removal cost.
As we have mentioned before, we continued to tightly control expenses while investing in revenue-producing initiatives and covering the higher cost of regulatory compliance.
The next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. While the ratio ticked up slightly in the first quarter, the results are still generally consistent with recent quarters, and improved from the first quarter of 2014.
An important area of focus for the organization is to continue to improve operating leverage through revenue growth and effective expense management.
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Once again, we did see an improvement in nonperforming assets this quarter. Originated nonperforming assets, as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 80 basis points, remains below our peer group and top 50 banks, and has improved from 100 basis points in the first quarter of 2014.
Looking at Slide 11, net charge-offs remained low at 11 basis points and improved from 13 basis points last quarter and 12 basis points 1 year ago. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets.
Slide 12 highlights our ability to grow both sides of the balance sheet. We continued to make progress on loan and deposit growth on a per share basis, while maintaining excellent asset quality. Over the past year, loans per share and deposits per share have grown at compound annual rates of 9% and 14%, respectively.
As shown on Slide 13, operating return on average assets decreased 4 basis points from last quarter, but improved 2 basis points from the first quarter of 2014. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment and the effective initiatives that have not yet attained expected levels of operating leverage. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses.
Slide 14 illustrates our return on average tangible equity. As profitability improves, we expect to see continued progress on this metric over time as we have seen in recent quarters.
Turning to Slide 15. We are comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank remained strong, especially in light of our low-risk business model. Effective this quarter, our capital ratios are calculated in accordance with Basal III capital rules. Additionally, our leverage ratio benefited due to our charter change as the denominator changed from period end total assets to quarterly average assets.
Slide 16 illustrates our interest rate profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twists. As you can see, we are a bit more asset sensitive as compared to last quarter, primarily due to a loan mix -- due to our loan mix trending towards floating rate loans as well as the strong deposit growth that we achieved in the quarter.
Now, I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. During the quarter, we received our national banking association charter. We believe this charter is best aligned to our commercial banking model.Additionally, we are pleased to announce the board voted to raise the dividend to an annual
componenttext:
Thanks, David. During the quarter, we received our national banking association charter. We believe this charter is best aligned to our commercial banking model.
Additionally, we are pleased to announce the board voted to raise the dividend to an annual rate of $0.67 per share. This marks the 22nd consecutive year the dividend has been increased, which reflects the continued commitment to delivering value to our shareholders through the consistent return of capital.
While the first quarter was an encouraging start to the year, the focus will remain on our most important objective, which is improving profitability. We feel terrific about the progress made in recent years in growing the company, and look to build upon this momentum to enhance returns while continuing to successfully position the franchise for the long term.
This concludes our presentation. Now, I'll be happy to answer any questions you may have. Operator, we're ready for questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question in the queue comes from Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015

componenttext: A couple of questions for you. So first of all, in terms of the deposit growth, obviously, very strong in this quarter. componenttext: We don't expect negative C&I growth next quarter. Mortgage warehouse was up and a lot of activity at the end of the year. It's moderated a little bit through the month here, but it's holding up pretty nicely. So I think there's just a lot more volume right now in the business, given what's gone on in the market. And we've also been very successful in supporting a large number of our customers with increases in lines and an opportunity to grow those relationships. So the combination of what's going on in the business and kind of growing the business, if you will, has benefited us.

Was wondering -- it sounds like it was just clean and organic. I didn't want to check to see if there was any deposit promotions involved or whether you've -- you guys are now incentivizing the workforce to deposit gather?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the biggest piece of it is our continued focus on deposit gathering and cross-selling. And we have, as we've said in the past, changed and strengthened the incentives around deposit gathering across the company. So that's been in place. There
componenttext: Yes. I think the biggest piece of it is our continued focus on deposit gathering and cross-selling. And we have, as we've said in the past, changed and strengthened the incentives around deposit gathering across the company. So that's been in place. There was no unusual move this quarter or even last, so those things are taking hold, I would say. And I think that's a big part of the progress we've made. We do have and have had a campaign around CDs and across the markets and we've gathered a modest amount of CDs from that campaign. And I'd say kind of in expectation not a big part of the increase. And we've also -- we always have some type of sales campaign and focus. Right now, we're promoting opening of checking accounts and offering customers $100 for that. And we have an e-checking campaign that's going out to appeal to folks to that are more technology-oriented to use a low-cost checking account. So we're always working at that on both ends, guess, incentives and campaigns. But I think it's more result progress results over time.

componenttextpreview: Yes. They're actually -- you know, I think in the script we had the number of branches over the last 4 years. And we've been working at closing branches within post proximity to other branches for a while now when we've been watching attrition. And we wat
componenttext: Yes. They're actually -- you know, I think in the script we had the number of branches over the last 4 years. And we've been working at closing branches within post proximity to other branches for a while now when we've been watching attrition. And we watched the traffic pattern of customers. So if you originated your deposit at branch A, but you're actually do business in branch A, B and C and what percentage of deposit base is going where. And so we plan out that the transitions and communicate with customers very well and we have experienced very little fallout so far. As we go on through the continued effort to optimize the branches, the question will become, at what distances branch to branch, does that stream the retention of that customer? So far, we're doing very, very well. And our assumptions is that -- and our experience have we have been retaining in the 80%, 90% range on those deposits.

componenttext: Sure. And actually it did not. When we built our budget, we made assumption that in 2015, there would only be 1 Fed tightening of 25 basis points. Now the reality is the kind of wrap went lower in January, back up in fiery, and come halfway down again. componenttext: Okay. Okay. Or are there certain triggers that would caution to the one way or the other on how you're managing your interest rate risk?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. We're -- I would say our overall goal is to keep a moderate amount of assets sensitivity. And we would define that we have today as a moderate amount. We don't talk much about long-term risk to changes in interest rate, but we have -- we are neutral t
componenttext: No. We're -- I would say our overall goal is to keep a moderate amount of assets sensitivity. And we would define that we have today as a moderate amount. We don't talk much about long-term risk to changes in interest rate, but we have -- we are neutral to about the first 150 basis point of rate increases from mark-to-market basis. So long term, we are neutral, short-term, we're trying to remain asset sensitive. And we're not looking to date to drive our asset sensitivity substantially higher.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, I would say, no real change at all. There are some modest changes from different competitors. The biggest thing I guess that comes to my mind is on the commercial real estate, we are seeing more competitive pressure that comes from the larger i
componenttext: Yes. Sure, I would say, no real change at all. There are some modest changes from different competitors. The biggest thing I guess that comes to my mind is on the commercial real estate, we are seeing more competitive pressure that comes from the larger institutional lenders that are doing longer fix rate loans than we have an appetite for. So we lose business there competitively. And I don't know, on a smaller impact, dollar-wise, we continued to see pressure from smaller banks in certain local markets that are willing, again, to do longer-term fixed-rate deals than we have an appetite for.

componenttext: I'm not sure, to tell you the truth, I think it has more to do with our commercial RM's being more comfortable introducing our swap experts to their customers. I also think just the lower level of interest rates is prompting more activity. Customers want to hedge and lock in lower rates for longer and are willing to embrace interest rate swaps as the mechanism to do that. And that works for us. So that we're doing less fixed-rate, long-term fixed-rate lending in this environment, so it suits our interest rate risk profile that we're trying to maintain.

componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kate, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being reco
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kate, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial, Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Hoyt, our Controller, as well as other members of management are here with me to review the first
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Hoyt, our Controller, as well as other members of management are here with me to review the first quarter of 2015 results.
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements of Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good morning. We appreciate everybody joining us today. Our performance this quarter is an encouraging start to the year, especially given the persistent low interest rate environment as well as the severe winter weather across our mark
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good morning. We appreciate everybody joining us today. Our performance this quarter is an encouraging start to the year, especially given the persistent low interest rate environment as well as the severe winter weather across our markets.
Results, once again, benefited from the investments we have made and continued to make in talent, products and services within our large and attractive markets.
During the quarter, I spent a great deal of time visiting customers across our franchise and came away impressed with the opportunities we have to further deepen these relationships through cross-selling efforts. Our breadth of products and services, superior customer service and local knowledge, uniquely position us to not only meet the expanding needs of current customers, but also forge new relationships. These visits reaffirm for me the value we provide to customers and the significant opportunities we have before us.
Turning to the overview of the quarter on Slide 2, operating earnings increased 12% from a year ago to $63 million, making the highest level of operating earnings we have had in the first quarter of any year.
Revenues increased 1% from the fourth quarter, as noninterest income was higher and net interest income was flat. As a reminder, net interest income, along with net interest margin, were unfavorably impacted by 2 fewer calendar days in the first quarter.
In comparison to the prior year quarter, revenues increased 3%, driven by improvements in both net interest income and noninterest income.
As expected, operating expenses were modestly higher as compared to the fourth quarter, due to traditionally higher first quarter payroll-related and winter-related operational cost.
However, we were pleased operating expense levels remained flat compared to the prior year quarter, especially considering the continued impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance cost.
The efficiency ratio increased slightly to 61.9% in the first quarter from 61.3% last quarter, reflecting higher revenues and the seasonal uptick in operating expenses. However, the ratio improved from 63.9% in the prior year quarter. While the first quarter is typically a seasonally lower period, we achieved solid annualized loan growth of 5%. This marks the 18th consecutive quarter of loan growth. We are pleased with the success of our deposit gathering initiatives as evidenced by organic deposit growth of $1 billion in the quarter, which represents more than 17% growth on an annualized basis.
As we further develop our franchise-wide, cross-sell and deposit-gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. Asset quality was, once again, exceptional as net charge-offs and nonperforming assets improved from already low levels.
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter change and net interest income. Higher average balances and strong originated loan growth increased to net -- increased net interest income by $3.4 million and $2.8 million, respecti
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter change and net interest income. Higher average balances and strong originated loan growth increased to net -- increased net interest income by $3.4 million and $2.8 million, respectively. The largest offset to these increases was a $3.3 million reduction in net interest income due to 2 fewer calendar days in the first quarter.  Additionally, a decline in accretion from run-off in the acquired loan portfolio and increased deposit volume lowered net interest margin by $1.7 million and $1.1 million, respectively.
As mentioned on previous calls, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing lost accretion on the acquired portfolio is a positive sign looking to the quarters ahead.
On Slide 4, net interest margin for the first quarter was 2.91%, a decline of 9 basis points from the fourth quarter. As we mentioned on our last earnings call, fewer calendar days impacted the margin by 5 basis points in the first quarter. Additionally, new loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 2 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield.  We continue to expect the full year 2015 margin to be within the range of 2.85% to 2.95% as outlined in January.
Slide 5 provides a breakdown of the increase in loans. The loan portfolio grew $337 million or 5% annualized. Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $430 million. As in previous quarters, growth was well balanced from a product and geographic perspective.
C&I contributed $240 million of the total originated loan growth, while commercial real estate contributed $118 million. Within C&I, we experienced particular strength in our mortgage warehouse lending business.
The commercial portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages contributed $129 million of originated loan growth in the first quarter. Approximately 90% of the residential mortgage originations helped our investment where high-grade adjustable rate mortgages.
In addition, the residential mortgage portfolio is strong -- the residential mortgage pipeline is strong and ended the quarter at the highest level in 2 years. We experienced acquired loan run-off of $93 million this quarter compared to $129 million in the fourth quarter and $114 million in prior -- in the prior year quarter. The balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $958 million.
Slide 6 shows the growth in deposits by segment from the fourth quarter. Deposits increased over $1 billion or 15.5% on an annualized basis, as commercial and retail deposits grew $635 million and $377 million, respectively. Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.6 billion, unchanged from the end of the fourth quarter. As such, the deposit growth in the first quarter was organically driven. We experienced strong growth across all geographies and all business lines. 
Just as a reminder, the first and fourth quarters are typically our strongest quarters for deposits. It is worth noting that our loan-to-deposit ratio was 99% at March 31 and our cost of deposits came down 1 basis point in the quarter.
Overall, we are very pleased with the progress we are making, gathering deposits. We firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships, and we continue to focus on organic deposit growth.
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income grew 3% from the fourth quarter and was primarily driven by strong commercial banking lending fees, higher customer interest rate swap income as well as gains on the sale of loans, which was primarily driven by the sale of 1 loan from the acquired portfolio. The increase in noninterest income was partially offset by the absence of security gains and lower bank service charges. As you will recall in the fourth quarter, the net security gain resulted from the call of a single acquired security.
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes and noninterest expense during the quarter. Nonoperating expenses increased over $5 million, which is mainly attributable to branch closure costs. We closed 8 branches during the first quarter as we continue to optimize our branch delivery channel.
Since the beginning of 2011, we have closed 44 branches, which were mostly traditional branches. During the same period, we opened 24 branches, many of which are more cost-efficient in-store branches.
We expect to close approximately 10 more branches during the remainder of the year as well as to look for opportunities to reduce real estate cost further by consolidating other facilities. We are committed to branches as they provide valuable support to revenue-generating activities across all of our business lines.
From an operating perspective, expenses increased $4.5 million from the fourth quarter. Compensation and benefits increased $6.6 million, primarily due to traditionally higher first quarter payroll-related and benefit cost, while occupancy and equipment cost increased $2.4 million, of which approximately 1/2 was due to higher snow removal cost. As we have mentioned before, we continued to tightly control expenses, while investing in revenue-producing initiatives and covering the higher cost of regulatory compliance.
The next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. While the ratio ticked up slightly in the first quarter, the results are still generally consistent with recent quarters and improved from the first quarter of 2014.
An important area of focus for the organization is to continue to improve operating leverage through revenue growth and effective expense management.
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Once again, we did see an improvement in nonperforming assets this quarter. Originated nonperforming assets, as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 80 basis points, remains below our peer group and top 50 banks and has improved from 100 basis points in the first quarter of 2014.
Looking at Slide 11, net charge-offs remained low at 11 basis points and improved from 13 basis points last quarter and 12 basis points 1 year ago. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets.
Slide 12 highlights our ability to grow both sides of the balance sheet. We continue to make progress on loan and deposit growth on a per share basis, while maintaining excellent asset quality. Over the past year, loans per share and deposits per share have grown at compound annual rates of 9% and 14%, respectively.
As shown on Slide 13, operating return on average assets decreased 4 basis points from last quarter, but improved 2 basis points from the first quarter of 2014. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment and the effective initiative that have not yet attained expected levels of operating leverage. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses.
Slide 14 illustrates our return on average tangible equity. As profitability improves, we expect to see continued progress on this metric over time as we have seen in recent quarters.
Turning to Slide 15. We are comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank remained strong, especially in light of our low-risk business model. Effective this quarter, our capital ratios are calculated in accordance with Basel III capital rep -- capital rules. Additionally, our leverage ratio benefited due to our charter change as the denominator changed from period end total assets to quarterly average assets.
Slide 16 illustrates our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we are a bit more asset-sensitive as compared to last quarter, primarily due to a loan mix -- our loan -- due to our loan mix trending towards floating rate loans as well as the strong deposit growth that we achieved in the quarter.
Now I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. During the quarter, we received our national banking association charter. We believe this charter is best aligned to our commercial banking model.Additionally, we are pleased to announce the board voted to raise the dividend to an annu
componenttext:
Thank you, David. During the quarter, we received our national banking association charter. We believe this charter is best aligned to our commercial banking model.
Additionally, we are pleased to announce the board voted to raise the dividend to an annual rate of $0.67 per share. This marks the 22nd consecutive year the dividend has been increased, which reflects our continued commitment to delivering value to our shareholders through the consistent return of capital.
While the first quarter was an encouraging start to the year, the focus will remain on our most important objective, which is improving profitability. We feel terrific about the progress made in recent years in growing the company and look to build upon this momentum to enhance returns, while continuing to successfully position the franchise for the long term.
This concludes our presentation. So now we'll be happy to answer any questions you may have. Operator, we're ready for questions.

componenttext: We don't expect negative C&I growth next quarter. Mortgage warehouse was up and a lot of activity at the end of the year. It's moderated a little bit through the month here, but it's holding up pretty nicely. So I think there's just a lot more volume right now in the business, given what's gone on in the market. And we've also been very successful in supporting a large number of our customers with increases in lines and an opportunity to grow those relationships. So the combination of what's going on in the business and kind of growing the business, if you will, has benefited us.

componenttext: Yes. I think the biggest piece of it is our continued focus on deposit gathering and cross-selling. And we have, as we've said in the past, changed and strengthened the incentives around deposit gathering across the company. So that's been in place. There was no unusual move this quarter or even last. So those things are taking hold, I would say, and I think that's a big part of the progress we've made. We do have and have had a campaign around CDs and across the markets, and we've gathered a modest amount of CDs from that campaign. And I'd say kind of in expectations and not a big part of the increase. And we've also -- we always have some type of sales campaign and focus. Right now, we're promoting opening of checking accounts and offering customers $100 for that. And we have an e-checking campaign that's going out to appeal to folks to -- that are more technology-oriented to use a low-cost checking account. So we're always working at that on both ends, I guess, incentives and campaigns. But I think it's more a result progress that results from that over time.

componenttext: Yes. They're actually -- So I think in the script, we had the number of branches over the last 4 years. And we've been working at closing branches within close proximity to other branches for a while now when we've been watching attrition, and we watched the traffic pattern of customers. So if you originated your deposit at branch A, but you actually do business in branch A, B and C, and what percentage of the deposit base is going where? And so we plan out that the transitions and communicate with customers very well, and we have experienced very little fallout so far. As we go on through the continued effort to optimize the branches, the question will become, at what distances, branch to branch, does the strain, the retention of that customer? So far, we're doing very, very well. And our assumptions is that -- and our experience has been that we're retaining in the 80% to 90% range on those deposits.

componenttext: Sure. And actually it did not, Collyn. When we built our budget, we made the assumption that, in 2015, there would only be 1 Fed tightening of 25 basis points. And we made the assumption that, that would occur in the middle of the fourth quarter. So that rates today are pretty much where they were at year-end when we finalized our budget. Now the reality is they kind of wrap -- went lower in January, backed up in February and have come halfway down again. And we're unchanged on -- from when we built the budget. So that gives us the comfort that our margin guidance should remain intact.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015

componenttext: Okay, okay. And then just kind of overall, Dave, how you're thinking about the balance sheet. Do you -- is the objective to try to maintain this -- I mean, you kind of have hovered in that mid- to high single-digit range of NII pick up, I guess in like in up 200 scenario. Is that sort of where you want to keep the balance sheet? Are there certain triggers that would cost you to go one way or the other on how you're managing your interest rate risk?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. We're -- I would say, our overall goal is to keep a moderate amount of asset sensitivity, and we would define what we have today as a moderate amount. We don't talk much about long-term risk to changes in interest rates, but we have -- we are neutral
componenttext: No. We're -- I would say, our overall goal is to keep a moderate amount of asset sensitivity, and we would define what we have today as a moderate amount. We don't talk much about long-term risk to changes in interest rates, but we have -- we are neutral to about the first 150 basis point of rate increases from a mark-to-market basis. So long term, we're neutral. Short-term, we're trying to remain asset-sensitive. And we're not looking today to drive our asset sensitivity substantially higher.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015

componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Collyn, This is Jack. I would say, no real change at all. There are some modest changes from different competitors. The biggest thing, I guess, that comes to my mind is, on the commercial real estate, we are seeing more competitive pressure tha
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Collyn, This is Jack. I would say, no real change at all. There are some modest changes from different competitors. The biggest thing, I guess, that comes to my mind is, on the commercial real estate, we are seeing more competitive pressure that comes from the larger institutional lenders that are doing longer fix rate loans than we have an appetite for. So we lose business there competitively. And I know on a smaller impact, dollar-wise, we continue to see pressure from smaller banks in certain local markets that are willing, again, to do longer-term fixed rate deals than we have an appetite for.

componenttext: I'm not sure, to tell you the truth. I think it has more to do with our commercial RM's being more comfortable introducing our swap experts to their customers. I also think just the lower level of interest rates is prompting more activity. Customers want to hedge and lock in lower rates for longer and are willing to embrace interest rate swaps as the mechanism to do that. And that works for us. So that we're doing less fixed rate -- long-term fixed rate lending in this environment. So it suits our interest rate risk profile that we're trying to maintain.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kate, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being reco
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc. First Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Kate, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial, Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Dave Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Hoyt, our Controller, as well as other members of management are here with me to review the first q
componenttext:
Thank you. Good morning, and thank you for joining us today. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Dave Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Jeff Hoyt, our Controller, as well as other members of management are here with me to review the first quarter of 2015 results.
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good morning. We appreciate everybody joining us today. Our performance this quarter is an encouraging start to the year, especially given the persistent low interest rate environment as well as the severe winter weather across our mark
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good morning. We appreciate everybody joining us today. Our performance this quarter is an encouraging start to the year, especially given the persistent low interest rate environment as well as the severe winter weather across our markets.
Results, once again, benefited from the investments we have made and continue to make in talent, products and services within our large and attractive markets.
During the quarter, I spent a great deal of time visiting customers across our franchise and came away impressed with the opportunities we have to further deepen these relationships through cross-selling efforts. Our breadth of products and services, superior customer service and the local knowledge uniquely position us to not only meet the expanding needs of current customers, but also forge new relationships. These visits reaffirm for me the value we provide to customers and the significant opportunities we have before us.
Turning to the overview of the quarter on Slide 2, operating earnings increased 12% from a year ago to $63 million, making the highest level of operating earnings we have had in the first quarter of any year.
Revenues increased 1% from the fourth quarter, as noninterest income was higher and net interest income was flat. As a reminder, net interest income, along with net interest margin, were unfavorably impacted by 2 fewer calendar days in the first quarter.
In comparison to the prior year quarter, revenues increased 3%, driven by improvements in both net interest income and noninterest income.
As expected, operating expenses were modestly higher as compared to the fourth quarter, due to traditionally higher first quarter payroll-related and winter-related operational costs.
However, we were pleased operating expense levels remained flat compared to the prior year quarter, especially considering the continued impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance costs.
The efficiency ratio increased slightly to 61.9% in the first quarter from 61.3% last quarter, reflecting higher revenues and the seasonal uptick in operating expenses. However, the ratio improved from 63.9% in the prior year quarter. While the first quarter is typically seasonally slower period, we achieved solid annualized loan growth of 5%. This marks the 18th consecutive quarter of loan growth. We are pleased with the success of our deposit gathering initiatives as evidenced by organic deposit growth of $1 billion in the quarter, which represents more than 17% growth on an annualized basis.
As we further develop our franchise-wide, cross-sell and deposit-gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. Asset quality was, once again, exceptional as net charge-offs and nonperforming assets improved from already low levels.
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter change in net interest income. Higher average balances and strong originated loan growth increased to net -- increased net interest income by $3.4 million and $2.8 million, respectiv
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter change in net interest income. Higher average balances and strong originated loan growth increased to net -- increased net interest income by $3.4 million and $2.8 million, respectively. The largest offset to these increases was a $3.3 million reduction in net interest income due to 2 fewer calendar days in the first quarter. Additionally, a decline in accretion from run-off in the acquired loan portfolio and increased deposit volume lowered net interest margin by $1.7 million and $1.1 million, respectively.
As mentioned on previous calls, growth in net interest income from the originated portfolio outpacing lost accretion on the acquired portfolio is a positive sign looking to the quarters ahead.
On Slide 4, net interest margin for the first quarter was 2.91%, a decline of 9 basis points from the fourth quarter. As we mentioned on our last earnings call, fewer calendar days impacted the margin by 5 basis points in the first quarter. Additionally, new loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 2 basis points, as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield.  We continue to expect the full year 2015 margin to be within the range of 2.85% to 2.95% as outlined in January.
Slide 5 provides a breakdown of the increase in loans. The loan portfolio grew $337 million or 5% annualized. Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $430 million. As in previous quarters, growth was well balanced from a product and geographic perspective.
C&I contributed $240 million of the total originated loan growth, while commercial real estate contributed $118 million. Within C&I, we experienced particular strength in our mortgage warehouse lending business.
The commercial portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages contributed $129 million of originated loan growth in the first quarter. Approximately 90% of the residential mortgage originations held for investment were high-grade adjustable rate mortgages.
In addition, the residential mortgage portfolio is strong -- the residential mortgage pipeline is strong and ended the quarter at the highest level in 2 years. We experienced acquired loan run-off of $93 million this quarter, compared to $129 million in the fourth quarter and $114 million in prior -- in the prior year quarter. The balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $958 million.
Slide 6 shows the growth in deposits by segment from the fourth quarter. Deposits increased over $1 billion or 15.5% on an annualized basis, as commercial and retail deposits grew $635 million and $377 million, respectively. Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.6 billion, unchanged from the end of the fourth quarter. As such, the deposit growth in the first quarter was organically driven. We experienced strong growth across all geographies and all business lines. 
Just as a reminder, the first and fourth quarters are typically our strongest quarters for deposits. It is worth noting that our loan-to-deposit ratio was 99% at March 31 and our cost of deposits came down 1 basis point in the quarter.
Overall, we are very pleased with the progress we are making gathering deposits. We firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships, and we continue to focus on organic deposit growth.
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income grew 3% from the fourth quarter and was primarily driven by strong commercial banking lending fees, higher customer interest rate swap income, as well as gains on the sale of loans, which was primarily driven by the sale of one loan from the acquired portfolio. The increase in noninterest income was partially offset by the absence of security gains and lower bank service charges. As you will recall in the fourth quarter, the net security gain resulted from the call of a single acquired security.
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes in noninterest expense during the quarter. Nonoperating expenses increased over $5 million, which is mainly attributable to branch closure costs. We closed 8 branches during the first quarter, as we continue to optimize our branch delivery channel.
Since the beginning of 2011, we have closed 44 branches, which were mostly traditional branches. During the same period, we opened 24 branches, many of which are more cost-efficient, in-store branches.
We expect to close approximately 10 more branches during the remainder of the year, as well as to look for opportunities to reduce real estate costs further by consolidating other facilities. We are committed to branches as they provide valuable support to revenue-generating activities across all of our business lines.
From an operating perspective, expenses increased $4.5 million from the fourth quarter. Compensation and benefits increased $6.6 million, primarily due to traditionally higher first quarter payroll-related and benefit costs, while occupancy and equipment costs increased $2.4 million, of which approximately 1/2 was due to higher snow removal costs. As we have mentioned before, we continue to tightly control expenses, while investing in revenue-producing initiatives and covering the higher costs of regulatory compliance.
The next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. While the ratio ticked up slightly in the first quarter, the results are still generally consistent with recent quarters and improved from the first quarter of 2014.
An important area of focus for the organization is to continue to improve operating leverage through revenue growth and effective expense management.
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Once again, we did see an improvement in nonperforming assets this quarter. Originated nonperforming assets, as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 80 basis points, remains below our peer group and top 50 banks, and has improved from 100 basis points in the first quarter 2014.
Looking at Slide 11, net charge-offs remained low at 11 basis points and improved from 13 basis points last quarter and 12 basis points 1 year ago. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets.
Slide 12 highlights our ability to grow both sides of the balance sheet. We continue to make progress on loan and deposit growth on a per share basis, while maintaining excellent asset quality. Over the past year, loans per share and deposits per share have grown at compound annual rates of 9% and 14%, respectively.
As shown on Slide 13, operating return on average assets decreased 4 basis points from last quarter, but improved 2 basis points from the first quarter of 2014. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment and the effective initiatives that have not yet attained expected levels of operating leverage. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses.
Slide 14 illustrates our return on average tangible equity. As profitability improves, we expect to see continued progress on this metric over time, as we have seen in recent quarters.
Turning to Slide 15. We are comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank remain strong, especially in light of our low-risk business model. Effective this quarter, our capital ratios are calculated in accordance with Basel III capital rep -- capital rules. Additionally, our leverage ratio benefited due to our charter change, as the denominator changed from period end total assets to quarterly average assets.
Slide 16 illustrates our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twists. As you can see, we are a bit more asset-sensitive as compared to last quarter, primarily due to a loan mix -- our loan -- due to our loan mix trending towards floating rate loans, as well as the strong deposit growth that we achieved in the quarter.
Now I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. During the quarter, we received our national banking association charter. We believe this charter is best aligned to our commercial banking model.Additionally, we are pleased to announce the board voted to raise the dividend to an annu
componenttext:
Thank you, David. During the quarter, we received our national banking association charter. We believe this charter is best aligned to our commercial banking model.
Additionally, we are pleased to announce the board voted to raise the dividend to an annual rate of $0.67 per share. This marks the 22nd consecutive year the dividend has been increased, which reflects our continued commitment to delivering value to our shareholders through the consistent return of capital.
While the first quarter was an encouraging start to the year, the focus will remain on our most important objective, which is improving profitability. We feel terrific about the progress made in recent years in growing the company and look to build upon this momentum to enhance returns, while continuing to successfully position the franchise for the long term.
This concludes our presentation. And now we'd be happy to answer any questions you may have. Operator, we're ready for questions.

componenttextpreview: We don't expect negative C&I growth next quarter. Mortgage warehouse was up and a lot of activity at the end of the year. It's moderated a little bit through the month here, but is holding up pretty nicely. So I think there's just a lot more volume right
componenttext: We don't expect negative C&I growth next quarter. Mortgage warehouse was up and a lot of activity at the end of the year. It's moderated a little bit through the month here, but is holding up pretty nicely. So I think there's just a lot more volume right now in the business, given what's gone on in the market. And we've also been very successful in supporting a large number of our customers with increases in lines and an opportunity to grow those relationships. So the combination of what's going on in the business and kind of growing the business, if you will, has benefited us.

componenttext: So just wanted to follow up on the deposit growth, which obviously pretty good this quarter without the help of broker deposits. Was wondering -- it sounds like it was just clean and organic. I was -- but I did want to check to see if there was any deposit promotions involved? Or whether you've -- you guys are now incentivizing the workforce to deposit gather?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the biggest piece of it is our continued focus on deposit gathering and in cross-selling. And we have, as we've said in the past, changed and strengthened the incentives around deposit gathering across the company. So that's been in place. Wa
componenttext: Yes. I think the biggest piece of it is our continued focus on deposit gathering and in cross-selling. And we have, as we've said in the past, changed and strengthened the incentives around deposit gathering across the company. So that's been in place. Was no unusual move this quarter or even last. So those things are taking hold, I would say, and I think that's a big part of the progress we've made. We do have and have had a campaign around CDs and across the markets, and we've gathered a modest amount of CDs from that campaign. I'd say kind of in expectations and not a big part of the increase. And we've also -- we always have some type of sales campaign and focus. Right now, we're promoting an opening of checking accounts and offering customers $100 for that. And we have an e-checking campaign that's going out to appeal to folks who -- that are more technology-oriented to use a low-cost checking account. So we're always working at that, and on both ends, I guess, incentives and campaigns. But I think it's more a result of progress that results from that over time.

componenttext: Okay, understood. And just following up on that, the branch closures, I think you said there was 11 this quarter, and there's more on the way. That, what I would think, would kind of -- would hurt your organic deposit growth. What's the sense there in terms of -- are you able to overcome that, the loss of -- like what are deposit attrition assumptions around the branch closures?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. They're actually -- So I think in the script, we had the number of branches over the last 4 years. And we've been working at closing branches within close proximity to other branches for a while now. And we've been watching attrition, and we watch th
componenttext: Yes. They're actually -- So I think in the script, we had the number of branches over the last 4 years. And we've been working at closing branches within close proximity to other branches for a while now. And we've been watching attrition, and we watch the traffic pattern of customers. So if you originated your deposit at branch A, but you actually do business in branch A, B and C, and what percentage of the deposit base is going where? And so we plan out the transitions and communicate with customers very well, and we have experienced very little fallout so far. As we go on through the continued effort to optimize the branches, the question will become, at what distances, branch to branch, does that strain the retention of that customer? And so far, we're doing very, very well. And our assumptions is that -- and our experience has been that we're retaining in the 80% to 90% range on those deposits.

componenttext: Sure. And actually it did not, Collyn. When we built our budget, we made the assumption that, in 2015, there would only be one Fed tightening of 25 basis points. And we made the assumption that, that would occur in the middle of the fourth quarter. So that -- rates today are pretty much where they were at year-end when we finalized our budget. Now the reality is they kind of wrap -- went lower in January, backed up in February and have come halfway down again. And were unchanged on -- from when we built the budget. So that gives us the comfort that our margin guidance should remain intact.

componenttext: Okay, okay. And then just kind of overall, Dave, how you're thinking about the balance sheet. Do you -- or is the objective to try to maintain this -- I mean, you kind of have hovered in that mid- to high single-digit range of NII pick up, I guess, in like an up 200 scenario. Is that sort of where you want to keep the balance sheet? Are there certain triggers that would cause you to go one way or the other on how you're managing your interest rate risk?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. We're -- I would say, our overall goal is to keep a moderate amount of asset sensitivity, and we would define what we have today as a moderate amount. We don't talk much about long-term risk to changes in interest rates. But we have -- we are neutral
componenttext: No. We're -- I would say, our overall goal is to keep a moderate amount of asset sensitivity, and we would define what we have today as a moderate amount. We don't talk much about long-term risk to changes in interest rates. But we have -- we are neutral to about the first 150 basis point of rate increases from a mark-to-market basis. So long term, we're neutral. Short-term, we're trying to remain asset-sensitive. And we're not looking today to drive our asset sensitivity substantially higher.

componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Collyn, This is Jack. I would say, no real change at all. There are some modest changes from different competitors. The biggest thing, I guess, that comes to my mind is, in the commercial real estate, we are seeing more competitive pressure tha
componenttext: Yes. Sure, Collyn, This is Jack. I would say, no real change at all. There are some modest changes from different competitors. The biggest thing, I guess, that comes to my mind is, in the commercial real estate, we are seeing more competitive pressure that comes from the larger institutional lenders that are doing longer fixed rate loans than we have an appetite for. So we lose business there competitively. And kind of on a smaller impact, dollar-wise, we continue to see pressure from smaller banks in certain local markets that are willing, again, to do longer-term fixed rate deals than we have an appetite for.

componenttext: I'm not sure, to tell you the truth. I think it has more to do with our commercial RMs being more comfortable introducing our swap experts to their customers. I also think just the lower level of interest rates is prompting more activity. Customers want to hedge and lock in lower rates for longer and are willing to embrace interest rate swaps as the mechanism to do that. And that works for us. So that we're doing less fixed rate -- long-term fixed rate lending in this environment. So it suits our interest rate risk profile that we're trying to maintain.
