headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitley and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recor
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitley and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our second quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice Pre
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our second quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice President; and Jeff Hoyt, our Controller. 
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate everyone joining us today. As I often do, I'd spend time during the quarter following on with customers. These visits always provide me with a great sense of how well we are meeting their needs. T
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate everyone joining us today. As I often do, I'd spend time during the quarter following on with customers. These visits always provide me with a great sense of how well we are meeting their needs. The feedback I continually receive from customers is how our approach to relationship banking differentiates us in the market. In fact, we recently were recognized with an excellence award Associates in delivering exceptional service quality to small and middle-market businesses. While our extensive suite of products is comparable to larger banks, we also have a long history of focusing on relationship management at the local level. This combination uniquely positions us in our large and attractive markets and resonates deeply with customers. This enables us to broaden existing relationships and foster new ones, hoping to generate momentum across the franchise. We look to sustain this momentum and not only continuing to invest in talent, products and services, but also by showcasing our strengths to a wider audience through our new marketing campaign. The know-how starts with knowing new campaigns starting at the end of June and focuses on our ability to understand the needs of customers and the breadth of products and service offered by our commercial, wealth management and consumer businesses. If you reside in one of our markets, I'm sure you've already seen one of our new television spots, billboards or print ads. 
Now turning to the overview of the quarter on Slide 2. Our performance in the second quarter reflects this continued momentum. We grew loans 9% on an annualized basis, marking the 19th consecutive quarter of growth while at the same time, maintaining excellent asset quality. In addition, we are pleased with the continued progress in gathering organic deposits as evidenced by the 5% annualized growth during the quarter. As we maintain emphasis on our franchise wide, cross-sell and deposit gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. Our continued focus on improving profitability drove a 6% increase in operating earnings from the prior year quarter. These results bring our operating earnings through the first half of the year to $127 million, a 9% increase from the same period in 2014. Revenues decreased slightly from the first quarter as a result of modestly lowered noninterest income, partially offset by higher net interest income. As discussed in the conference call in April, we expected noninterest income to moderate in subsequent quarters from a very strong first quarter results. In comparison to the prior year quarter, revenues on the -- on an operating basis increased 2%, driven by improvements in both net interest income and noninterest income. As expected, operating expenses improved from the first quarter, primarily resulting from lower compensation and benefits costs. On a year-over-year basis, operating expenses were slightly higher. However, we remain confident in our ability to control costs despite the ongoing impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance costs. 
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the first quarter. Strong originated loan growth and higher average balances and yields from the securities portfolio increased net interest in
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. 
On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the first quarter. Strong originated loan growth and higher average balances and yields from the securities portfolio increased net interest income by $1.7 million and $1.5 million, respectively. Net interest income also benefited by $1.7 million from an additional calendar day in the second quarter. The largest offset to these improvements was a $1.4 million reduction in net interest income from higher deposit costs and volumes. Additionally, a decline in accretion from runoff in the acquired loan portfolio forward net interest income by $1 million. 
On Slide 4, net interest margin for the second quarter was 288, a decline of 3 basis points from the first quarter. New loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 4 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. In addition, the margin was lowered by 2 basis points from higher deposit volumes and costs. Contributing to the slightly higher cost of funds in the quarter where successful CB campaigns in the retail bank that targeted new customers drove increased foot traffic into the branches. Margin benefited by 2 basis points from an additional calendar day in the second quarter and 1 basis point from higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio. 
Turning to Slide 5. Loan portfolio grew $633 million or 9% annualized from the first quarter. Originated loan growth through the quarter totaled $691 million. As in prior quarters, growth was well-balanced from a product and geographic perspective. C&I contributed $375 million of the total originated loan growth, while commercial real estate contributed $149 million. Within C&I, we experienced strength across several categories, including traditional C&I, asset based lending and most notably, in our mortgage warehouse lending business. The portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages had another strong quarter with $151 million of originated along growth. Similar with recent quarters, most of the newly-originated residential mortgages retained in our portfolio were hybrid adjustable-rate mortgages. The recent addition of a veteran sales manager and seasoned residential loan officers in our newer markets helped drive growth. This is another example of a targeted strategic investment in talent. We experienced acquired loan runoff of $58 million this quarter compared to $93 million in the first quarter. The remaining balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $900 million. 
Slide 6 shows the growth in deposits by segment from the first quarter. Deposits increased $285 million or 4% on an annualized basis. Commercial deposits grew $310 million and retail deposits, in line with historical second quarter patterns, declined slightly as expected. Brokered deposits ended the quarter at $2.6 billion, down $13 million from the end of the first quarter. As such, the deposit growth in the second quarter was once again organically driven. Overall, we are very pleased with the progress we are making gathering deposits. We firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships and we continue to focus on organic deposit growth. 
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income decreased 7% from the first quarter. As discussed on our conference call in April, we expected noninterest income would moderate in subsequent quarters. As such, commercial banking lending fees and customer interest rate swap income were down from very strong first quarter levels. Insurance revenues were also lower due to seasonal nature of insurance renewals. In addition, as you will recall, the first quarter benefited from the sale of 1 acquired loan. These decreases in noninterest income were partially offset by higher gains on sales of residential mortgages as well as higher bank service charges. 
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes in noninterest expense during the quarter. Nonoperating expenses decreased $3 million from the first quarter, which is mainly attributable to lower branch closure costs. Although branch closure costs were lower compared to last quarter, we did close 10 branches, bringing the year-to-date total to 18 as we continue to optimize our branch delivery channel. Since the beginning of 2011, we have closed 54 branches, which were mostly traditional branches. During the same period, we opened 24 branches,  most of which are more cost efficient in-store branches. In addition to optimizing the branch footprint, we have begun to install new technology in our branches to improve efficiencies and further reduce costs moving forward. From an operating perspective, expenses decreased $2.8 million from the first quarter. As expected, compensation and benefits decreased $5.1 million, resulting from lower payroll-related and benefit costs, which are traditionally higher in the first quarter. In addition, the quarter benefited from nearly $2 million in lower occupancy and equipment costs. Largest offset to these improvements was a $1.5 million increase in professional and outside services, increases primarily related to costs associated with a number of initiatives focused on enhancing our product offerings and processes. As we have mentioned before, we continue to tightly control expenses while investing in revenue producing initiatives and covering the higher costs of regulatory compliance. 
Next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. The ratio improved from both the most recent quarter and the second quarter of 2014. Important area of focus for the organization is to continue to improve operating leverage with revenue growth and effective expense management. 
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Originated nonperforming assets, as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 83 basis points, remains below the peer group and top 50 banks, and has improved from 96 basis points in the second quarter of 2014.  Looking at Slide 11. Net charge-offs for the quarter were 5 basis points, an improvement from recent quarters and the lowest level in over 8 years. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets, in our view, that conservative underwriting is vital for sustainable value creation. 
As shown on Slide 12, operating return on average assets decreased 1 basis point and 2 basis points, respectively, from last quarter and the second quarter of 2014. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses. 
Slide 13 illustrates our return on average tangible equity. While this metric is down slightly from recent quarters, as profitability improves, we expect to see continued progress over time as we have seen in previous quarters. 
Turning to Slide 14. We remain comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank continue to be strong, especially in light of our diversified business mix and history of exceptional Credit Risk Management. 
Slide 15 displays our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we are a bit more asset-sensitive as compared to last quarter, primarily due to a loan mix trending towards floating rate loans. At June 30, 41% of the loan portfolio was either 1 month LIBOR or prime based, 70% of these loans being 1 month LIBOR-based. 
Now, I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we are optimistic we can sustain momentum by continuing to build and deepen relationships across our large and attractive markets. We remain committed to building the business for the long-ter
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we are optimistic we can sustain momentum by continuing to build and deepen relationships across our large and attractive markets. We remain committed to building the business for the long-term and well-positioned to deliver value to both customers and shareholders. 
This concludes our presentation. I will be happy to answer any questions that you may have. Operator, we are ready for questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Ramsey, FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Ramsey, FBR Capital Markets.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about the mix of retail versus in the store branches. I know you guys have continued, as you mentioned, sort of shift that mix. What do you see is the optimal mix of retail versus or full service versus in-st
componenttext: I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about the mix of retail versus in the store branches. I know you guys have continued, as you mentioned, sort of shift that mix. What do you see is the optimal mix of retail versus or full service versus in-store?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way to think about that, if you think about our Connecticut and New York franchises, that's where we have the in-store footprint with Stop & Shop, north of that in Massachusetts, in the northern pieces, we only have one, actually, to my
componenttext: Well, I think the way to think about that, if you think about our Connecticut and New York franchises, that's where we have the in-store footprint with Stop & Shop, north of that in Massachusetts, in the northern pieces, we only have one, actually, to my knowledge and recollection. So when you think about where we do have in-stores, we think of it in a watch traffic pattern, many, many of our customers use both. So they'll use an in-store and a traditional. And so we like the idea of, sometimes we call a hub and spoke kind of thing but if you think about it, when somebody's taking advantage of the convenience of 7 days and extended hours, but at the same time, maybe there the traditional branch and uses the drive-up and that kind of thing, it's really how they play together. And I don't know that we really think of it, say, as a percentage in terms of optimization as much as how both types of branches working within a particular market. Naturally, the kind of geographic and access particulars are different, unique in each place. But what we do find very successful is the combined convenience of both.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's also important to remind everyone that our in-store branches are full-service. They offer every product and service that the traditional branches do as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that we will continue to keep working on it. I think David's remark, we laid out the numbers that we've done over the last few years. And as we continue to move ahead with that, we learn more and more about how to effectively retain the customers,
componenttext: I think that we will continue to keep working on it. I think David's remark, we laid out the numbers that we've done over the last few years. And as we continue to move ahead with that, we learn more and more about how to effectively retain the customers, which we feel very good about our execution on that. And we also are kind of in that process, learning how, again, looking at traffic patterns and how the customers interact with us, learning just how far we can go geographically with executing on that. And other thing is, the technology and the interaction, engagement with the customer keeps changing and evolving and I'm sure that our take on how far we should go and what would be the, say, the next branch that would seem to make sense will be impacted by that as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in selling new technology in the branches in the prepared remarks, you just don't elaborate a little bit on some of the technology you guys have been rolling out?
componenttext: You mentioned in selling new technology in the branches in the prepared remarks, you just don't elaborate a little bit on some of the technology you guys have been rolling out?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So one of the key things that we're using is a machine called the cash recycler. So people can make deposits in cash and withdraw cash out of the same unit and it doesn't require a teller's involvement. And we're also image enabled ATMs that allow them to
componenttext: So one of the key things that we're using is a machine called the cash recycler. So people can make deposits in cash and withdraw cash out of the same unit and it doesn't require a teller's involvement. And we're also image enabled ATMs that allow them to, again, kind of walk up to the ATM, place the check on the screen, make the deposit without needing assistance. So the technology is allowing us to reevaluate staffing needs and the time of staffing needs. And that's the gist of it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Casey Haire with Jefferies.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So just wanted to touch on the loan growth outlook. Obviously, a nice quarter here. You guys are attracting nicely towards your guide on the year. Just curious, how is it looking in the second half of the year? Is any chance for acceleration based on pipe
componenttext: So just wanted to touch on the loan growth outlook. Obviously, a nice quarter here. You guys are attracting nicely towards your guide on the year. Just curious, how is it looking in the second half of the year? Is any chance for acceleration based on pipeline strength at June 30? And where you're seeing the most -- where are the pipelines strongest by product?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes, we are -- we're feeling very good about the second half and the pipelines are actually up in the second quarter compared to the first. And that's maybe the first indicator. And the second is that, our third and fourth quarters, historically, are s
componenttext: So yes, we are -- we're feeling very good about the second half and the pipelines are actually up in the second quarter compared to the first. And that's maybe the first indicator. And the second is that, our third and fourth quarters, historically, are stronger in terms of originations. And I would say, we continue to be most encouraged across the core C&I middle market activity and that's across the footprint. We're a little slower, but okay in the equipment finance business. And ABL is making nice progress. Mortgage warehouse is -- got some all time, line utilization high. And so that's very active. We don't see that moderating right away, although we certainly consider it something that could be volatile, depending on mortgage rates. And at least, probably, the area where it's slowest. And pipelines are a little encouraging there, but that market has been slower than we anticipated the last few years. Mostly, a competitive situation, I think.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then, just switching gears to expenses. Nice leverage this quarter. I was a little surprised to see the other noninterest expense line to actually rise. componenttext: Yes, the other noninterest expense. The write-down was $6 million last quarter, it's only $3 million this quarter and yet, the other line is up. So I'm just curious, what was driving that? And what is the kind of a good run rate for that other line going forward?

componenttext: The advertising was up in the quarter in conjunction with the campaign that Jack talked about at the beginning of his comments. And also, in the first quarter, we had a little better experience on REO sales. But the advertising is just a timing issue, so no real uptick in that line item is expected.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then, just lastly. On the asset sensitivity front. The brokered deposits, $2.6 billion. If memory serves, I think that had an average term around 9 months, which is obviously gives you a nice lag on the funding side when rates rise. B
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then, just lastly. On the asset sensitivity front. The brokered deposits, $2.6 billion. If memory serves, I think that had an average term around 9 months, which is obviously gives you a nice lag on the funding side when rates rise. But I'm just curious, what would be your expectation for the simulation at that 9-month point? Meaning, once those -- that market funding has to reprice, does the NII simulation pace like a headwind where you become liability sensitive?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would say is that those brokered deposits are a combination of money markets as well as CDs. And it's the CD that have the term in them. But when we model and produce our interest rate risk result, we assume 100% sensitivity, 100% repricing o
componenttext: Well, what I would say is that those brokered deposits are a combination of money markets as well as CDs. And it's the CD that have the term in them. But when we model and produce our interest rate risk result, we assume 100% sensitivity, 100% repricing of the money markets immediately upon a change in the Fed target rate. And the CDs are also 100%, so it doesn't happen until -- it only happens as the book rolls. Both of those are all $2.6 billion brokered deposits, it's 100% [indiscernible] sensitivity assumed.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. I guess, what I'm getting at is like, I know you guys are showing asset-sensitive for the first 12 months. My point is, once you reach that 9-month mark, is -- does the balance sheet become liability sensitive?
componenttext: Okay, understood. I guess, what I'm getting at is like, I know you guys are showing asset-sensitive for the first 12 months. My point is, once you reach that 9-month mark, is -- does the balance sheet become liability sensitive?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. If we roll forward our models, we remain asset-sensitive.
componenttext: No. If we roll forward our models, we remain asset-sensitive.

componenttext: Yes. So probably be modest increases in our securities portfolio in the third quarter and maybe into the fourth quarter. We're only about 15.5% or so of the total assets. And the other thing about that portfolio is there -- it's a relatively short or moderately short duration portfolio, especially when you back out the long-term munis that we have in our HTM account.

componenttext: Yes. No, we actually are hopeful that loan spreads have stabilized. We saw that occur in the second quarter. And we have our fingers crossed that it continues. And at some point, starts to widen. The downward pressure we've been fighting, it seems to be abating.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with a few questions on the deposit costs. On call this morning, they indicated other banks in their market were pushing up market rates being paid for deposits. When we look at your deposit costs, they were up, particularly time deposit
componenttext: I wanted to start with a few questions on the deposit costs. On call this morning, they indicated other banks in their market were pushing up market rates being paid for deposits. When we look at your deposit costs, they were up, particularly time deposits. Are you guys responding also to what other banks are doing? You're offering a better rate? Or are you one of the banks that's actually pushing up market rates, given you need to fund loan growth?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would definitely be the former and then -- and I wouldn't even necessarily say we're responding to what other banks are doing. We've done a couple of things. You saw our overall deposit costs go up 2 basis points. We did and we referenced it in my comm
componenttext: It would definitely be the former and then -- and I wouldn't even necessarily say we're responding to what other banks are doing. We've done a couple of things. You saw our overall deposit costs go up 2 basis points. We did and we referenced it in my comments. We have run a few CD port or CD campaigns over the course of the second quarter and we did a little in the first quarter as well. It's -- what we're trying to do is, a, lock in a little term money, but also, to drive activity into the branches. One of the things that we hope is unique about us is that to open up a CD with us, you're required to open up a DDA relationship as well. And what we find is that we actually grow our DDA balances at a faster pace when we run those CD campaigns. And we're having -- if we're driving the most growth in our newer markets of Mass and New York as well.

componenttext: I think that's probably fair, Steve. But I also -- if you think about continued growth and growing net interest income, we're certainly trying to grow the fee businesses. componenttext: Sure. Well, the comment was, in general, across all of those portfolios, in the second quarter, we saw loan spreads stabilize. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Collyn, I don't have an exact number, but I will -- let me take sort of broad range around what I think it is. So that portfolio is almost exclusively hybrid ARMs. So the most popular products for us or the only products we offer, are 5 1, 7 1 and 10 1s.
componenttext: Collyn, I don't have an exact number, but I will -- let me take sort of broad range around what I think it is. So that portfolio is almost exclusively hybrid ARMs. So the most popular products for us or the only products we offer, are 5 1, 7 1 and 10 1s. And we've had those products for years now. So it's a very seasoned portfolio. The top of my head, I would think that the average duration of that portfolio is between 3 and 3.5 years. We also have about -- between 600 million and 700 million of hybrid ARMs that, once they became floaters, they haven't pre-paid off, which is contrary to what used to happen. It's just a function of how low rates are. So we have a large part of that portfolio that is also tied to either 1 year treasury or 1 year LIBOR as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Okay, and is that really what's driving sort of the justification of the thought to not have any, if I'm looking at it right, not having any long-term borrowings on the balance sheet?

componenttext: Well, there's a couple of things. I mean, we have a little bit of long-term borrowings. And some of that in the form of capital markets transactions, for instance. We have a $500 million, about 2.5-year old 10-year note, that's outstanding as a holding company. But most of the liabilities in our treasury unit, meaning, excluding our retail CD deposit base, are fairly short. It's a function of short duration assets, pretty much across-the-board. Whether you look in our securities portfolio or residential loan portfolio and the growing amount of floating rate assets that we've been generating. Meaning, growth in C&I, our mortgage warehouse business entirely, floats off 1 month LIBOR, our ABL is a 1 month LIBOR portfolio.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Finances all short.
componenttext: Finances all short.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Right. Equipment finances, very short. Our home equity portfolio is all prime based. So we have a nice mismatch at the short end of the curve where we have quite a bit more assets and liabilities, and that's the big driver in our asset sensitivity. And we don't feel we need to increase the asset sensitivity by doing long-term borrowings at this point. And it's been the right decision for years now.

componenttext: Sure. I'll see -- let me talk a little bit about what we're doing. I don't really think that's what's most important. And that's been -- our efforts have been in place for up 2 years now or so, where we really impressed upon our relationship managers the need to raise the commercial deposits because we've been undersized in commercial deposits as an institution for a long period of time. And so we did a couple of things there. We increased incentives for deposits but more importantly, we put in profitability models that lenders need to submit with every loan request. So it's looking at the totality of the relationship, both the loan, the -- all the fee income businesses as well as the deposits. And the deposits are a large component of the profitability. So we changed focus on that across the organization and that's what we're seeing flow through. The commercial growth in the quarter was $310 million, to give you the number.

componenttext: Yes. So this is Jack. I think that we had a very low quarter and we would very much like to see it continue to repeat. We have seen a reduction in problem assets as we think about working through the last several years in identification of criticized loans and the like. They were at modest level and we don't see a lot of new names, so we're encouraged by that. And there's 2 components of our provisioning, right, and the build. So one is to cover net charge-off activity and the other is to build the allowance as we grow the portfolio. So when you think about covering net charge-offs, we did have some very good recoveries this quarter, not too far out of normal range, but better than average. So that impacted the net charge-off of some as well. So.

componenttext: No. I think it's very fair, I feel very strongly that it has matured. componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitley and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our second quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice Pre
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our second quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice President; and Jeff Hoyt, our Controller. 
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate everyone joining us today. As I often do, I spend time during the quarter following on customers. These visits always provide me with a great sense of how well we are meeting their needs. The feed
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon, everyone. We appreciate everyone joining us today. As I often do, I spend time during the quarter following on customers. These visits always provide me with a great sense of how well we are meeting their needs. The feedback I continually receive from customers is how our approach to relationship banking differentiates us in the market. In fact, we recently were recognized with an excellence award by Greenwich Associates in delivering exceptional service quality to small and middle-market businesses. While our extensive suite of products is comparable to larger banks, we also have a long history of focusing on relationship management at the local level. This combination uniquely positions us in our large and attractive markets and resonates deeply with customers. This enables us to broaden existing relationships and foster new ones, hoping to generate momentum across the franchise. We look to sustain this momentum and not only continuing to invest in talent, products and services, but also by showcasing our strengths to a wider audience through our new marketing campaign. The know-how starts with knowing new campaigns starting at the end of June and focuses on our ability to understand the needs of customers and the breadth of products and service offered by our commercial, wealth management and consumer businesses. If you reside in one of our markets, I'm sure you've already seen one of our new television spots, billboards or print ads. 
Now turning to the overview of the quarter on Slide 2. Our performance in the second quarter reflects this continued momentum. We grew loans 9% on an annualized basis, marking the 19th consecutive quarter of growth while at the same time, maintaining excellent asset quality. In addition, we are pleased with the continued progress in gathering organic deposits as evidenced by the 5% annualized growth during the quarter. As we maintain emphasis on our franchise-wide cross-sell and deposit gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. Our continued focus on improving profitability drove a 6% increase in operating earnings from the prior year quarter. These results bring our operating earnings through the first half of the year to $127 million, a 9% increase from the same period in 2014. Revenues decreased slightly from the first quarter as a result of modestly lowered noninterest income, partially offset by higher net interest income. As discussed in the conference call in April, we expected noninterest income to moderate in subsequent quarters from a very strong first quarter results. In comparison to the prior year quarter, revenues on an operating basis increased 2%, driven by improvements in both net interest income and noninterest income. As expected, operating expenses improved from the first quarter, primarily resulting from lower compensation and benefits costs. On a year-over-year basis, operating expenses were slightly higher. However, we remain confident in our ability to control costs despite the ongoing impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance costs. 
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the first quarter. Strong originated loan growth and higher average balances and yields from the securities portfolio increased net interest in
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. 
On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the first quarter. Strong originated loan growth and higher average balances and yields from the securities portfolio increased net interest income by $1.7 million and $1.5 million, respectively. Net interest income also benefited by $1.7 million from an additional calendar day in the second quarter. The largest offset to these improvements was a $1.4 million reduction in net interest income from higher deposit costs and volumes. Additionally, a decline in accretion from runoffs in the acquired loan portfolio forward net interest income by $1 million. 
On Slide 4, net interest margin for the second quarter was 2.88%, a decline of 3 basis points from the first quarter. New loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 4 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. In addition, the margin was lowered by 2 basis points from higher deposit volumes and costs. Contributing to the slightly higher cost of funds in the quarter were successful CB campaigns in the retail bank that targeted new customers and drove increased foot traffic into the branches. Margin benefited by 2 basis points from an additional calendar day in the second quarter and 1 basis point from higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio. 
Turning to Slide 5. Loan portfolio grew $633 million or 9% annualized from the first quarter. Originated loan growth through the quarter totaled $691 million. As in prior quarters, growth was well-balanced from a product and geographic perspective. C&I contributed $375 million of the total originated loan growth, while commercial real estate contributed $149 million. Within C&I, we experienced strength across several categories, including traditional C&I, asset based lending and most notably, in our mortgage warehouse lending business. The portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages had another strong quarter with $151 million of originated loan growth. Similar with recent quarters, most of the newly-originated residential mortgages retained in our portfolio were hybrid adjustable-rate mortgages. The recent addition of a veteran sales manager and seasoned residential loan officers in our newer markets helped drive growth. This is another example of a targeted strategic investment in talent. We experienced acquired loan runoff of $58 million this quarter compared to $93 million in the first quarter. The remaining balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $900 million. 
Slide 6 shows the growth in deposits by segment from the first quarter. Deposits increased $285 million or 4% on an annualized basis. Commercial deposits grew $310 million and retail deposits, in line with historical second quarter patterns, declined slightly as expected. Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.6 billion, down $13 million from the end of the first quarter. As such, the deposit growth in the second quarter was once again organically driven. Overall, we are very pleased with the progress we are making gathering deposits. We firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships and we continue to focus on organic deposit growth. 
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income decreased 7% from the first quarter. As discussed on our conference call in April, we expected noninterest income would moderate in subsequent quarters. As such, commercial banking lending fees and customer interest rate swap income were down from very strong first quarter levels. Insurance revenues were also lower due to the seasonal nature of insurance renewals. In addition, as you will recall, the first quarter benefited from the sale of 1 acquired loan. These decreases in noninterest income were partially offset by higher gains on sales of residential mortgages as well as higher bank service charges. 
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes in noninterest expense during the quarter. Nonoperating expenses decreased $3 million from the first quarter which is mainly attributable to lower branch closure costs. Although branch closure costs were lower compared to last quarter, we did close 10 branches, bringing the year-to-date total to 18 as we continue to optimize our branch delivery channel. Since the beginning of 2011, we have closed 54 branches which were mostly traditional branches. During the same period, we opened 24 branches, most of which are more cost efficient in-store branches. In addition to optimizing the branch footprint, we have begun to install new technology in our branches to improve efficiencies and further reduce costs moving forward. From an operating perspective, expenses decreased $2.8 million from the first quarter. As expected, compensation and benefits decreased $5.1 million, resulting from lower payroll-related and benefit costs which are traditionally higher in the first quarter. In addition, the quarter benefited from nearly $2 million in lower occupancy and equipment costs. Largest offset to these improvements was a $1.5 million increase in professional and outside services, increases primarily related to costs associated with a number of initiatives focused on enhancing our product offerings and processes. As we have mentioned before, we continue to tightly control expenses while investing in revenue producing initiatives and covering the higher costs of regulatory compliance. 
Next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. Ratio improved from both the most recent quarter and the second quarter of 2014. An important area of focus for the organization is to continue to improve operating leverage with revenue growth and effective expense management. 
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Originated nonperforming assets as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 83 basis points remains below the peer group and top 50 banks, and has improved from 96 basis points in the second quarter of 2014.  Looking at Slide 11. Net charge-offs for the quarter were 5 basis points, an improvement from recent quarters and the lowest level in over 8 years. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets, and our view that conservative underwriting is vital for sustainable value creation. 
As shown on Slide 12, operating return on average assets decreased 1 basis point and 2 basis points, respectively, from last quarter and the second quarter of 2014. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses. 
Slide 13 illustrates our return on average tangible equity. While this metric is down slightly from recent quarters, as profitability improves, we expect to see continued progress over time as we have seen in previous quarters. 
Turning to Slide 14. We remain comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank continue to be strong, especially in light of our diversified business mix and the history of exceptional Credit Risk Management. 
Slide 15 displays our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we are a bit more asset-sensitive as compared to last quarter, primarily due to a loan mix trending towards floating rate loans. At June 30, 41% of the loan portfolio was either 1 month LIBOR or prime based, 70% of these loans being 1 month LIBOR-based. 
Now, I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we are optimistic we can sustain momentum by continuing to build and deepen relationships across our large and attractive markets. We remain committed to building the business for the long-ter
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we are optimistic we can sustain momentum by continuing to build and deepen relationships across our large and attractive markets. We remain committed to building the business for the long-term and well-positioned to deliver value to both customers and shareholders. 
This concludes our presentation. I will be happy to answer any questions that you may have. Operator, we are ready for questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Ramsey, FBR Capital Markets.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about the mix of retail versus in the store branches. I know you guys have continued, as you mentioned, to sort of shift that mix. What do you see is the optimal mix of retail versus or full service versus in
componenttext: I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about the mix of retail versus in the store branches. I know you guys have continued, as you mentioned, to sort of shift that mix. What do you see is the optimal mix of retail versus or full service versus in-store?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way to think about that, if you think about our Connecticut and New York franchises, that's where we have the in-store footprint with Stop & Shop. North of that in Massachusetts, in the northern pieces, we only have one, actually, to my
componenttext: Well, I think the way to think about that, if you think about our Connecticut and New York franchises, that's where we have the in-store footprint with Stop & Shop. North of that in Massachusetts, in the northern pieces, we only have one, actually, to my knowledge and recollection. So when you think about where we do have in-stores, we think of it in a watch traffic pattern, as many, many of our customers use both. So they'll use an in-store and a traditional. And so we like the idea of, sometimes we call it a hub and spoke kind of thing. But if you think about it, when somebody's taking advantage of the convenience of 7 days and extended hours, but at the same time, maybe whizz there the traditional branch and uses the drive-up and that kind of thing, it's really how they play together. And I don't know that we really think of it, say, as a percentage in terms of optimization as much as how are both types of branches working within a particular market. Naturally, the kind of geographic and access particulars are different, unique in each place. But what we do find very successful is the combined convenience of both.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Bob, it's also important to remind everyone that our in-store branches are full-service. They offer every product and service that the traditional branches do as well.

componenttext: Yes. We have not found the right opportunity. The Stop & Shop group has a relationship in the Massachusetts market with another bank and we'd be very interested in it if it were to be an opportunity. So we like it and actually, we get some information. I think the Massachusetts arrangement and relationship is very successful there as well.

componenttextpreview: I think that we will continue to keep working on it. I think David's remark, we laid out the number that we've done over the last few years. And as we continue to move ahead with that, we learn more and more about how to effectively retain the customers w
componenttext: I think that we will continue to keep working on it. I think David's remark, we laid out the number that we've done over the last few years. And as we continue to move ahead with that, we learn more and more about how to effectively retain the customers which we feel very good about our execution on that. And we also are kind of in that process, learning how -- again, looking at traffic patterns and how the customers interact with us, learning just how far we can go geographically with executing on that. And other thing is, the technology and the interaction, right, the engagement with the customer keeps changing and evolving and I'm sure that our take on how far we should go and what would be the, say, the next branch that would seem to make sense will be impacted by that as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in selling new technology in the branches in the prepared remarks, can you just elaborate a little bit on some of the technology you guys have been rolling out?
componenttext: You mentioned in selling new technology in the branches in the prepared remarks, can you just elaborate a little bit on some of the technology you guys have been rolling out?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So one of the key things that we're using is a machine called the cash recycler. So people can make deposits in cash and withdraw cash out of the same unit and it doesn't require a teller's involvement. And we're also using image-enabled ATMs that allow t
componenttext: So one of the key things that we're using is a machine called the cash recycler. So people can make deposits in cash and withdraw cash out of the same unit and it doesn't require a teller's involvement. And we're also using image-enabled ATMs that allow them to, again, kind of walk up to the ATM, place the check on the screen, make the deposit without needing assistance. So the technology is allowing us to reevaluate staffing needs and the time of staffing needs, and that's the gist of it.

componenttext: So I just want to touch on the loan growth outlook. Obviously, a nice quarter here. You guys are tracking nicely towards your guide on the year. Just curious, how is it looking in the second half of the year? Is any chance for acceleration based on pipeline strength at June 30? And where are you seeing the most -- where are the pipelines strongest by product?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes, we are. We're feeling very good about the second half and the pipelines are actually up in the second quarter compared to the first. And that's maybe the first indicator. The second is that our third and fourth quarters historically are stronger i
componenttext: So yes, we are. We're feeling very good about the second half and the pipelines are actually up in the second quarter compared to the first. And that's maybe the first indicator. The second is that our third and fourth quarters historically are stronger in terms of originations. And I would say, we continue to be most encouraged across the core C&I middle market activity and that's across the footprint. We're a little slower, but okay in the equipment finance business. And ABL is making nice progress. Mortgage warehouse has got some all time line utilization highs, and so that's very active. We don't see that moderating right away, although we certainly consider it something that could be volatile, depending on mortgage rates. And CRE is probably the area where it's slowest and pipelines are a little encouraging there, but that market has been slower than we anticipated the last few years. Mostly, a competitive situation, I think.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then, just lastly. On the asset sensitivity front. The broker deposits, $2.6 billion. If memory serves, I think that had an average term around 9 months which obviously gives you a nice lag on the funding side when rates rise. But I'm
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then, just lastly. On the asset sensitivity front. The broker deposits, $2.6 billion. If memory serves, I think that had an average term around 9 months which obviously gives you a nice lag on the funding side when rates rise. But I'm just curious, what would be your expectation for the simulation at that 9-month point? Meaning, once that market funding has to reprice, does the NII simulation face like a headwind where you become liability sensitive?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would say is that those broker deposits are a combination of money markets as well as CDs, and it's the CDs that have the term in them. But when we model and produce our interest rate risk result, we assume 100% sensitivity, 100% repricing of
componenttext: Well, what I would say is that those broker deposits are a combination of money markets as well as CDs, and it's the CDs that have the term in them. But when we model and produce our interest rate risk result, we assume 100% sensitivity, 100% repricing of the money markets immediately upon a change in the Fed target rate. And the CDs are also 100%, so it doesn't happen until -- it only happens as the book rolls. Both of those are all $2.6 billion broker deposits, there's 100% sensitivity assumed.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. I guess what I'm getting at is like, I know you guys are showing asset-sensitive for the first 12 months. My point is, at once you reach that 9-month mark, does the balance sheet become liability-sensitive?
componenttext: Okay, understood. I guess what I'm getting at is like, I know you guys are showing asset-sensitive for the first 12 months. My point is, at once you reach that 9-month mark, does the balance sheet become liability-sensitive?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. If we roll forward our models, we remain asset-sensitive.
componenttext: No. If we roll forward our models, we remain asset-sensitive.

componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with a few questions on the deposit costs. On Western's call this morning, they indicated other banks in their markets were pushing up market rates being paid for deposits. When we look at your deposit costs, they were up, particularly t
componenttext: I wanted to start with a few questions on the deposit costs. On Western's call this morning, they indicated other banks in their markets were pushing up market rates being paid for deposits. When we look at your deposit costs, they were up, particularly time deposits. Are you guys responding also to what other banks are doing where you're offering a better rate? Or are you one of the banks that's actually pushing up market rates, given you need to fund loan growth?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would definitely be the former and then -- and I wouldn't even necessarily say we're responding to what other banks are doing. We've done a couple of things. You saw our overall deposit costs go up 2 basis points. We did and we referenced it in my comm
componenttext: It would definitely be the former and then -- and I wouldn't even necessarily say we're responding to what other banks are doing. We've done a couple of things. You saw our overall deposit costs go up 2 basis points. We did and we referenced it in my comments. We have run a few CD port or CD campaigns over the course of the second quarter and we did a little in the first quarter as well. What we're trying to do is, a, lock in a little term money but also, to drive activity into the branches. One of the things that we hope is unique about us is that to open up a CD with us, you're required to open up a DDA relationship as well. And what we find is that we actually grow our DDA balances at a faster pace when we run those CD campaigns. And we're having -- we're driving the most growth in our newer markets of Mass and New York as well.

componenttext: Yes, it's on plan. And we weren't off -- we were not able to offer those to them before. So we're booking business and it'll start to show gradually over time.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: And then, can you just talk about new branch openings? componenttext: Yes, we definitely are thinking that way. And we happened to call our -- the use of the technology and the way we're modifying the in-store branches advantaged centers. We're just at the beginning of this deployment and that'll certainly -- those branches are 1/3 less costly, if you will, than the average branch. And this will make them even more cost-effective because of the staffing impact. And as we look to new markets and to expand into New York and Boston, in particular, we are thinking about smaller, traditional branches rather than kind of old-school.

componenttext: All right. I think what happened is we had a really strong first quarter. And we'd like to see that in the third and fourth quarter. But what we have, people with expertise in the markets and we're in front of folks in a more active way as we've described before, was looking to build that business. On the insurance side, we're looking for seasonal increases in insurance revenue in the third quarter. Again, that's historically been very consistent.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Collyn, I don't have an exact number but I will -- let me take sort of broad range around what I think it is. So that portfolio is almost exclusively hybrid ARMs. So the most popular products for us or the only products we offer are 5/1, 7/1 and 10/1. And
componenttext: Collyn, I don't have an exact number but I will -- let me take sort of broad range around what I think it is. So that portfolio is almost exclusively hybrid ARMs. So the most popular products for us or the only products we offer are 5/1, 7/1 and 10/1. And we've had those products for years now, so it's a very seasoned portfolio. The top of my head, I would think that the average duration of that portfolio is between 3 and 3.5 years. We also have about  between 600 million and 700 million of hybrid ARMs that, once they became floaters, they haven't pre-paid off which is contrary to what used to happen. It's just a function of how low rates are. So we have a large part of that portfolio that is also tied to either 1 year treasury or 1 year LIBOR as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and is that really what's driving sort of the justification of the thought to not have any, if I'm looking at it right, not having any long-term borrowings on the balance sheet?
componenttext: Okay, and is that really what's driving sort of the justification of the thought to not have any, if I'm looking at it right, not having any long-term borrowings on the balance sheet?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a couple of things. I mean, we have a little bit of long-term borrowings. And some of that is in the form of capital markets transactions, for instance. We have a $500 million, about 2.5-year old 10-year note that's outstanding as a holding
componenttext: Well, there's a couple of things. I mean, we have a little bit of long-term borrowings. And some of that is in the form of capital markets transactions, for instance. We have a $500 million, about 2.5-year old 10-year note that's outstanding as a holding company. But most of the liabilities in our treasury unit, meaning, excluding our retail CD deposit base, are fairly short. It's a function of short duration assets, pretty much across-the-board. Whether you look at our securities portfolio, our residential loan portfolio and the growing amount of floating rate assets that we've been generating. Meaning, growth in C&I, our mortgage warehouse business entirely and floats off 1 month LIBOR, our ABL is a 1 month LIBOR portfolio.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Equipment finances all short.
componenttext: Equipment finances all short.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Equipment finances, very short. Our home equity portfolio is all prime based. So we have a nice mismatch at the short end of the curve where we have quite a bit more assets than liabilities, and that's the big driver in our asset sensitivity. And w
componenttext: Right. Equipment finances, very short. Our home equity portfolio is all prime based. So we have a nice mismatch at the short end of the curve where we have quite a bit more assets than liabilities, and that's the big driver in our asset sensitivity. And we don't feel we need to increase the asset sensitivity by doing long-term borrowings at this point. And it's been the right decision for years now.

componenttext: Okay? Yes, that gap has come down -- no, it's come down because the originated portfolio, as you see, it has been coming down. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Collyn, it's Jack. We just happen to have a timing issue and some unique efforts that had caused that number to go up and we don't think it will continue. But we've had an effort and we used some outside consulting help to look at our sales force eff
componenttext: Yes. Collyn, it's Jack. We just happen to have a timing issue and some unique efforts that had caused that number to go up and we don't think it will continue. But we've had an effort and we used some outside consulting help to look at our sales force effectiveness and what tools we might use throughout the company to improve our ability to drive sales and drive revenue as we went forward, and we paid some fees for that service. And that's a one time event. And then, we also paid some outside fees in our payments space, so the same folks that helped us with the joint venture in the merchant service helped us evaluate several other aspects of our payments environment and some of the offerings we have there. So that trend and the uptick that you see should not continue as we go forward. We will -- we've got other things going on in terms of other outside professional service vendors that we continue to negotiate a contract with and we continue to increase utilization of. So it should be relatively in the range of spending shortly.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just one quick last question. I know you guys -- Dave talked about you spent some time on the retail deposit side. But if we could just go back to the commercial deposit initiative. I know that's been a big focus for you guys for thi
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one quick last question. I know you guys -- Dave talked about you spent some time on the retail deposit side. But if we could just go back to the commercial deposit initiative. I know that's been a big focus for you guys for this year. David, I think you said you had, was it $300 million in commercial deposits come in? If you could just sort of update us again on what the numbers were sort of commercial deposits and kind of what your goals are for the year on that front? And then I'll leave it there.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll see -- let me talk a little bit about what we're doing because I really think that's what's most important. And that's been -- our efforts have been in place for 2 years now or so, where we've really impressed upon our relationship managers the
componenttext: Sure. I'll see -- let me talk a little bit about what we're doing because I really think that's what's most important. And that's been -- our efforts have been in place for 2 years now or so, where we've really impressed upon our relationship managers the need to raise commercial deposits because we've been undersized in commercial deposits as an institution for a long period of time. And so we did a couple of things there. We increased incentives for deposits but more importantly, we put in profitability models that lenders need to submit with every loan request. So it's looking at the totality of the relationship, both the loan, all the fee income businesses as well as the deposits. And the deposits are a large component of the profitability. So we changed focus on that across the organization and that's what we're seeing flow through. The commercial growth in the quarter was $310 million, to give you the number.

componenttext: Okay. And the target for the year is something in the range of $300-and-some-odd million in the quarter. Is that how we should think about it?

componenttext: In that ballpark, there is -- what I would say is there's some seasonality across some of those businesses. So we actually had negative seasonality this quarter in our municipal business that we'll recover in the third quarter. But the success here is, we don't have a firm number around what we're trying to do each quarter. What we're trying to do is change behavior across the whole sales force. But we've been very pleased with what we've been able to do in the first 2 quarters of the year and would expect the behavior changes to last, not only this year, but into the future.

componenttext: Just going back to a prior question on preferred equity into 2016. I'm just trying to get a sense for the size or what you would estimate to be the size of that offering or what capital ratio you would be looking to maintain if and when that would come about.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, we haven't really sized it. It's going to be a function of the size of the balance sheet, as well as our sense of what growth from that point forward will be. I mean, the only color I can give you there is, I think it will be hard to believe that we
componenttext: Matt, we haven't really sized it. It's going to be a function of the size of the balance sheet, as well as our sense of what growth from that point forward will be. I mean, the only color I can give you there is, I think it will be hard to believe that we would issue up to what's allowable under Basel III which is 1.5% of risk-weighted assets. Today, our thought process would probably be about half of that or so. So at this point, that's about the best color I can give you.

componenttextpreview: And then, I just wanted to follow-up, charge-off levels this quarter were obviously very low and I wanted to get a sense for whether or not you thought that kind of level is sustainable and how that also factors into your provisioning expense.
componenttext: And then, I just wanted to follow-up, charge-off levels this quarter were obviously very low and I wanted to get a sense for whether or not you thought that kind of level is sustainable and how that also factors into your provisioning expense.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is Jack. I think that we had a very low quarter and we would very much like to see it continue to repeat. We have seen a reduction in problem assets as we think about working through the last several years in identification of criticized loan
componenttext: Yes. So this is Jack. I think that we had a very low quarter and we would very much like to see it continue to repeat. We have seen a reduction in problem assets as we think about working through the last several years in identification of criticized loans and the like. They were at modest levels and we don't see a lot of new names, so we're encouraged by that. And there's 2 components of our provisioning, right, and the build. So one is to cover net charge-off activity and the other is to build the allowance as we grow the portfolio. So when you think about covering net charge-offs, we did have some very good recoveries this quarter, not too far out of normal range, but better than average. So that impacted the net charge-off some as well.

componenttext: I think the provision has been in a fairly narrow range for quite some time and I -- if you're planning on it, we don't expect dramatic shifts. So that's probably the appropriate way to look at our history and we don't see anything moving.

componenttext: And the only thing I was going to add is when you're at these low levels, 1 credit or 2 credits can really bounce that number around. And a large part of the provision for this quarter, and it was in the press release, a little of over $4 million which was provisioned for growth going forward.

componenttext: Right. My last question's really around I want to get a sense for where are you, as a management team, stand on in terms of M&A and a desire to go out and transact and be a buyer?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think the way to describe the way we think about is, we're very focused on organic growth. We think we've got great opportunity to continue to grow organically at a very good pace to get back to what we've been doing in terms of the acquisitions that we
componenttext: I think the way to describe the way we think about is, we're very focused on organic growth. We think we've got great opportunity to continue to grow organically at a very good pace to get back to what we've been doing in terms of the acquisitions that we did in '10, '11 and '12 that got us into Boston and New York, and so that's the primary focus. We continue to build relationships and convey an interest with folks and at least dialoguing if it works mutually across the Northeast corridor. And so as I said in the past, those things, I think people understand that we're a successful acquirer, we're a successful company and we are very interested in being constructive about those things. And whether it happens or not, I find this very much on each individual partner's situation.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions. Just going back to the discussion about the relationship managers and how they're being charged with originating deposits as well and you've kind of -- you mentioned, I think, that you put the initiative in place maybe a coupl
componenttext: I had a couple of questions. Just going back to the discussion about the relationship managers and how they're being charged with originating deposits as well and you've kind of -- you mentioned, I think, that you put the initiative in place maybe a couple of years ago. And I think you alluded to the fact that maybe, a piece of the progress you've seen since the beginning of this year. But would you say, at this point, I mean, it sounds to me like you feel that those relationship managers still have some room to go in terms of adopting this philosophy of originating deposits. Or shouldn't they kind of have matured at this point in time in terms of what their capabilities are from that standpoint? I mean, how should we think about how much more room they have to move the needle in terms of raising deposits?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's very fair. I feel very strongly that it has matured. And naturally, whatever, we've got newer relationships coming on, hiring people, getting them oriented to our organization. But for the most, in terms of the program and our relationshi
componenttext: No. I think it's very fair. I feel very strongly that it has matured. And naturally, whatever, we've got newer relationships coming on, hiring people, getting them oriented to our organization. But for the most, in terms of the program and our relationship managers, we have specific goals for relationship managers built into their individual plans. We've got incentives around those that have been established at least for 2 years, probably longer. So what David, I think, was trying to describe is that we continue to see these relationships, new activity and we look at those returns that are coming from the profitability sheets. And we continue to encourage more progress all the time. So I think the maturity of the program is there. I think the issue is there's always opportunity and we continue to look for more progress. And so the vision, if you will, the business line has goals, the individuals within the business line have goals and everybody's working toward them.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then, just going back again to the issue of the efficiency ratio and thinking about that. I mean, it seems to me that maybe you've already made significant investments and sort of improving like upfront investments to try to improve operating efficien
componenttext: And then, just going back again to the issue of the efficiency ratio and thinking about that. I mean, it seems to me that maybe you've already made significant investments and sort of improving like upfront investments to try to improve operating efficiency and reaping the benefits of that. You've done a fair amount of it but then, people are talking about a lot of emphasis you put on mobile banking and in divesting more in that technology. You talked about some of your branches and enabling the deposit taking capability at tellers. So how should we think about your investments in the near term that could maybe help drive more operating efficiency over time, but will represent more initial investments upfront? Do you think that we'd see a meaningful lift in those investments? Are you pretty much done at this point with larger investments and will you see sort of some fairly even investment going forward?

componenttext: Well, I think the way to think about that is we have made a lot of progress on putting automation into our back room, on many functions and departments.
