headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitley and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recor
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Second Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Whitley and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our second quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice Pre
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our second quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice President; and Jeff Hoyt, our Controller. 
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. As I often do, I spend time during the quarter calling on customers. These visits always provide me with a great sense of how well we are meeting their needs. The feedback I conti
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. As I often do, I spend time during the quarter calling on customers. These visits always provide me with a great sense of how well we are meeting their needs. The feedback I continually receive from customers is how our approach to relationship banking differentiates us in the market. In fact, we recently were recognized with an excellence award by Greenwich Associates in delivering exceptional service quality to small and middle-market businesses. While our extensive suite of products is comparable to larger banks, we also have a long history of focusing on relationship management at the local level. This combination uniquely positions us in our large and attractive markets and resonates deeply with customers. This enables us to broaden existing relationships and foster new ones, helping to generate momentum across the franchise. We look to sustain this momentum and not only continuing to invest in talent, products and services, but also by showcasing our strengths to a wider audience through our new marketing campaign. The know-how starts with knowing new campaigns starting at the end of June and focuses on our ability to understand the needs of customers and the breadth of products and service offered by our commercial, wealth management and consumer businesses. If you reside in one of our markets, I'm sure you've already seen one of our new television spots, billboards or print ads. 
Now turning to the overview of the quarter on Slide 2. Our performance in the second quarter reflects this continued momentum. We grew loans 9% on an annualized basis, marking the 19th consecutive quarter of growth while at the same time, maintaining excellent asset quality. In addition, we are pleased with the continued progress in gathering organic deposits as evidenced by the 5% annualized growth during the quarter. As we maintain emphasis on our franchise-wide cross-sell and deposit gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. Our continued focus on improving profitability drove a 6% increase in operating earnings from the prior year quarter. These results bring our operating earnings through the first half of the year to $127 million, a 9% increase from the same period in 2014. Revenues decreased slightly from the first quarter as a result of modestly lower noninterest income, partially offset by higher net interest income. As discussed in the conference call in April, we expected noninterest income to moderate in subsequent quarters from a very strong first quarter results. In comparison to the prior year quarter, revenues on an operating basis increased 2%, driven by improvements in both net interest income and noninterest income. As expected, operating expenses improved from the first quarter, primarily resulting from lower compensation and benefits costs. On a year-over-year basis, operating expenses were slightly higher. However, we remain confident in our ability to control costs despite the ongoing impact of strategic investments and increasing regulatory compliance costs. 
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the first quarter. Strong originated loan growth and higher average balances and yields from the securities portfolio increased net interest in
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. 
On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the first quarter. Strong originated loan growth and higher average balances and yields from the securities portfolio increased net interest income by $1.7 million and $1.5 million, respectively. Net interest income also benefited by $1.7 million from an additional calendar day in the second quarter. The largest offset to these improvements was a $1.4 million reduction in net interest income from higher deposit costs and volumes. Additionally, a decline in accretion from runoffs in the acquired loan portfolio lowered net interest income by $1 million. 
On Slide 4, net interest margin for the second quarter was 2.88%, a decline of 3 basis points from the first quarter. New loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 4 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. In addition, the margin was lowered by 2 basis points from higher deposit volumes and costs. Contributing to the slightly higher cost of funds in the quarter were successful CB campaigns in the retail bank that targeted new customers and drove increased foot traffic into the branches. Margin benefited by 2 basis points from an additional calendar day in the second quarter and 1 basis point from higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio. 
Turning to Slide 5. Loan portfolio grew $633 million or 9% annualized from the first quarter. Originated loan growth through the quarter totaled $691 million. As in prior quarters, growth was well-balanced from a product and geographic perspective. C&I contributed $375 million of the total originated loan growth, while commercial real estate contributed $149 million. Within C&I, we experienced strength across several categories, including traditional C&I, asset based lending and most notably, in our mortgage warehouse lending business. The portfolio remains broadly diversified with respect to loan type, geography and industry. Residential mortgages had another strong quarter with $151 million of originated loan growth. Similar with recent quarters, most of the newly-originated residential mortgages retained in our portfolio were hybrid adjustable-rate mortgages. The recent addition of a veteran sales manager and seasoned residential loan officers in our newer markets helped drive growth. This is another example of a targeted strategic investment in talent. We experienced acquired loan runoff of $58 million this quarter compared to $93 million in the first quarter. The remaining balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $900 million. 
Slide 6 shows the growth in deposits by segment from the first quarter. Deposits increased $285 million or 4% on an annualized basis. Commercial deposits grew $310 million and retail deposits, in line with historical second quarter patterns, declined slightly as expected. Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.6 billion, down $13 million from the end of the first quarter. As such, the deposit growth in the second quarter was once again organically driven. Overall, we are very pleased with the progress we are making gathering deposits. We firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships and we continue to focus on organic deposit growth. 
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at noninterest income. Noninterest income decreased 7% from the first quarter. As discussed on our conference call in April, we expected noninterest income would moderate in subsequent quarters. As such, commercial banking lending fees and customer interest rate swap income were down from very strong first quarter levels. Insurance revenues were also lower due to the seasonal nature of insurance renewals. In addition, as you will recall, the first quarter benefited from the sale of 1 acquired loan. These decreases in noninterest income were partially offset by higher gains on sales of residential mortgages as well as higher bank service charges. 
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes in noninterest expense during the quarter. Nonoperating expenses decreased $3 million from the first quarter which is mainly attributable to lower branch closure costs. Although branch closure costs were lower compared to last quarter, we did close 10 branches, bringing the year-to-date total to 18 as we continue to optimize our branch delivery channel. Since the beginning of 2011, we have closed 54 branches which were mostly traditional branches. During the same period, we opened 24 branches, most of which are more cost efficient in-store branches. In addition to optimizing the branch footprint, we have begun to install new technology in our branches to improve efficiencies and further reduce costs moving forward. From an operating perspective, expenses decreased $2.8 million from the first quarter. As expected, compensation and benefits decreased $5.1 million, resulting from lower payroll-related and benefit costs which are traditionally higher in the first quarter. In addition, the quarter benefited from nearly $2 million in lower occupancy and equipment costs. The largest offset to these improvements was a $1.5 million increase in professional and outside services, increases primarily related to costs associated with a number of initiatives focused on enhancing our product offerings and processes. As we have mentioned before, we continue to tightly control expenses while investing in revenue producing initiatives and covering the higher costs of regulatory compliance. 
Next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. The ratio improved from both the most recent quarter and the second quarter of 2014. An important area of focus for the organization is to continue to improve operating leverage with revenue growth and effective expense management. 
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Originated nonperforming assets as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 83 basis points remains below the peer group and top 50 banks, and has improved from 96 basis points in the second quarter of 2014.  Looking at Slide 11. Net charge-offs for the quarter were 5 basis points, an improvement from recent quarters and the lowest level in over 8 years. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets, and our view that conservative underwriting is vital for sustainable value creation. 
As shown on Slide 12, operating return on average assets decreased 1 basis point and 2 basis points, respectively, from last quarter and the second quarter of 2014. Our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment. Progress will be driven by continued loan and deposit growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses. 
Slide 13 illustrates our return on average tangible equity. While this metric is down slightly from recent quarters, as profitability improves, we expect to see continued progress over time as we have seen in previous quarters. 
Turning to Slide 14. We remain comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank continue to be strong, especially in light of our diversified business mix and  history of exceptional Credit Risk Management. 
Slide 15 displays our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we are a bit more asset-sensitive as compared to last quarter, primarily due to a loan mix trending towards floating rate loans. At June 30, 41% of the loan portfolio was either 1 month LIBOR or prime based, 70% of these loans being 1 month LIBOR-based. 
Now, I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we are optimistic we can sustain momentum by continuing to build and deepen relationships across our large and attractive markets. We remain committed to building the business for the long-ter
componenttext:
Thanks, David. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we are optimistic we can sustain momentum by continuing to build and deepen relationships across our large and attractive markets. We remain committed to building the business for the long-term and well-positioned to deliver value to both customers and shareholders. 
This concludes our presentation. I will be happy to answer any questions that you may have. Operator, we are ready for questions.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Ramsey, FBR Capital Markets.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about the mix of retail versus in the store branches. I know you guys have continued, as you mentioned, to sort of shift that mix. What do you see is the optimal mix of retail versus or full service versus in
componenttext: I just wondered if you could talk a little bit about the mix of retail versus in the store branches. I know you guys have continued, as you mentioned, to sort of shift that mix. What do you see is the optimal mix of retail versus or full service versus in-store?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the way to -- there's two ways to think about that, if you think about our Connecticut and New York franchises, that's where we have the in-store footprint with Stop & Shop. North of that in Massachusetts, in the northern pieces, we only hav
componenttext: Well, I think the way to -- there's two ways to think about that, if you think about our Connecticut and New York franchises, that's where we have the in-store footprint with Stop & Shop. North of that in Massachusetts, in the northern pieces, we only have one, actually, to my knowledge and recollection. So when you think about where we do have in-stores, we think of it in a watch traffic pattern, as many, many of our customers use both. So they'll use an in-store and a traditional. And so we like the idea of, sometimes we call it a hub and spoke kind of thing. But if you think about it, when somebody's taking advantage of the convenience of 7 days and extended hours, but at the same time, maybe lives there, near the traditional branch and uses the drive-up and that kind of thing, it's really how they play together. And I don't know that we really think of it, say, as a percentage in terms of optimization as much as how are both types of branches working within a particular market. Naturally, the kind of geographic and access particulars are different, unique in each place. But what we do find very successful is the combined convenience of both.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's also important to remind everyone that our in-store branches are full-service. They offer every product and service that the traditional branches do as well.
componenttext: Bob, it's also important to remind everyone that our in-store branches are full-service. They offer every product and service that the traditional branches do as well.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I know you mentioned the in-store are really your focus on the Connecticut and New York franchises. Is it not in other markets because that model doesn't work as well in those markets? Or is it really just you haven't found the right partn
componenttext: Okay. And then, I know you mentioned the in-store are really your focus on the Connecticut and New York franchises. Is it not in other markets because that model doesn't work as well in those markets? Or is it really just you haven't found the right partnership locations to offer that?

componenttext: Yes. We have not found the right opportunity. The Stop & Shop group has a relationship in the Massachusetts market with another bank and we'd be very interested in it if it were to be an opportunity. So we like it and actually, we get some information. I think the Massachusetts arrangement and relationship is very successful there as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, last question on it. But is there much more opportunity to consolidate the standalone branches? Or as you see the footprint today, are you more or less where you want to be?
componenttext: Okay. And then, last question on it. But is there much more opportunity to consolidate the standalone branches? Or as you see the footprint today, are you more or less where you want to be?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that we will continue to keep working on it. I think David's remark, we laid out the number that we've done over the last few years. And as we continue to move ahead with that, we learn more and more about how to effectively retain the customers w
componenttext: I think that we will continue to keep working on it. I think David's remark, we laid out the number that we've done over the last few years. And as we continue to move ahead with that, we learn more and more about how to effectively retain the customers which we feel very good about our execution on that. And we also are kind of in that process, learning how -- again, looking at traffic patterns and how the customers interact with us, learning just how far we can go geographically with executing on that. And the other thing is, the technology and the interaction, right, the engagement with the customer keeps changing and evolving and I'm sure that our take on how far we should go and what would be the, say, the next branch that would seem to make sense will be impacted by that as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned in selling new technology in the branches in the prepared remarks, can you just elaborate a little bit on some of the technology you guys have been rolling out?
componenttext: You mentioned in selling new technology in the branches in the prepared remarks, can you just elaborate a little bit on some of the technology you guys have been rolling out?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So one of the key things that we're using is a machine called the cash recycler. So people can make deposits in cash and withdraw cash out of the same unit and it doesn't require a teller's involvement. And we're also using image-enabled ATMs that allow t
componenttext: So one of the key things that we're using is a machine called the cash recycler. So people can make deposits in cash and withdraw cash out of the same unit and it doesn't require a teller's involvement. And we're also using image-enabled ATMs that allow them to, again, kind of walk up to the ATM, place the check on the screen, make the deposit, while, without needing assistance. So the technology is allowing us to reevaluate staffing needs and the time of staffing needs, and that's the gist of it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Casey Haire with Jefferies.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I just want to touch on the loan growth outlook. Obviously, a nice quarter here. You guys are tracking nicely towards your guide on the year. Just curious, how is it looking in the second half of the year? Is any chance for acceleration based on pipeli
componenttext: So I just want to touch on the loan growth outlook. Obviously, a nice quarter here. You guys are tracking nicely towards your guide on the year. Just curious, how is it looking in the second half of the year? Is any chance for acceleration based on pipeline strength at June 30? And where are you seeing the most -- where are the pipelines strongest by product?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: So yes, we are. We're feeling very good about the second half and the pipelines are actually up in the second quarter compared to the first. And that's maybe the first indicator. The second is that our third and fourth quarters historically are stronger i
componenttext: So yes, we are. We're feeling very good about the second half and the pipelines are actually up in the second quarter compared to the first. And that's maybe the first indicator. The second is that our third and fourth quarters historically are stronger in terms of originations. And I would say, we continue to be most encouraged across the core C&I middle market activity and that's across the footprint. We're a little slower, but okay in the equipment finance business. And ABL is making nice progress. Mortgage warehouse has got some all time line utilization highs, and so that's very active. We don't see that moderating right away, although we certainly consider it something that could be volatile, depending on mortgage rates. And CRE is probably the area where it's slowest and pipelines are a little encouraging there, but that market has been slower than we anticipated the last few years. Mostly, a competitive situation, I think.

componenttext: The advertising was up in the quarter in conjunction with the campaign that Jack talked about at the beginning of his comments. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then, just lastly. On the asset sensitivity front. The broker deposits, $2.6 billion. If memory serves, I think that had an average term around 9 months which obviously gives you a nice lag on the funding side when rates rise. But I'm
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then, just lastly. On the asset sensitivity front. The broker deposits, $2.6 billion. If memory serves, I think that had an average term around 9 months which obviously gives you a nice lag on the funding side when rates rise. But I'm just curious, what would be your expectation for the simulation at that 9-month point? Meaning, once that market funding has to reprice, does the NII simulation face like a headwind where you become liability sensitive?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, what I would say is that those broker deposits are a combination of money markets as well as CDs, and it's the CDs that have the term in them. But when we model that and produce our interest rate risk results, we assume 100% sensitivity, 100% repric
componenttext: Well, what I would say is that those broker deposits are a combination of money markets as well as CDs, and it's the CDs that have the term in them. But when we model that and produce our interest rate risk results, we assume 100% sensitivity, 100% repricing of the money markets immediately upon a change in the Fed target rate. And the CDs are also 100%, though it doesn't happen until -- it only happens as the book rolls. But it's for -- -- --  both of those are all $2.6 billion broker deposits, there's 100% sensitivity assumed.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. I guess what I'm getting at is like, I know you guys are showing asset-sensitive for the first 12 months. My point is, at once you reach that 9-month mark, does the balance sheet become liability-sensitive?
componenttext: Okay, understood. I guess what I'm getting at is like, I know you guys are showing asset-sensitive for the first 12 months. My point is, at once you reach that 9-month mark, does the balance sheet become liability-sensitive?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. If we roll forward our models, we remain asset-sensitive.
componenttext: No. If we roll forward our models, we remain asset-sensitive.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to start with a few questions on the deposit costs. On Webster's call this morning, they indicated other banks in their markets were pushing up market rates being paid for deposits. When we look at your deposit costs, they were up, particularly t
componenttext: I wanted to start with a few questions on the deposit costs. On Webster's call this morning, they indicated other banks in their markets were pushing up market rates being paid for deposits. When we look at your deposit costs, they were up, particularly time deposits. Are you guys responding also to what other banks are doing? Either you're offering a better rate? Or are you one of the banks that's actually pushing up market rates, given you need to fund loan growth?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would definitely be the former and then -- and I wouldn't even necessarily say we're responding to what other banks are doing. We've done a couple of things. You saw our overall deposit costs go up 2 basis points. We did and we referenced it in my comm
componenttext: It would definitely be the former and then -- and I wouldn't even necessarily say we're responding to what other banks are doing. We've done a couple of things. You saw our overall deposit costs go up 2 basis points. We did and we referenced it in my comments. We have run a few CD port or CD campaigns over the course of the second quarter and we did a little in the first quarter as well. What we're trying to do is, a, lock in a little term money but also, to drive activity into the branches. One of the things that we hope is unique about us is that to open up a CD with us, you're required to open up a DDA relationship as well. And what we find is that we actually grow our DDA balances at a faster pace when we run those CD campaigns. And we're having -- we're driving the most growth in our newer markets of Mass and New York as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is there a target, David, in terms of how much you're expecting to raise the campaigns?
componenttext: Okay. Is there a target, David, in terms of how much you're expecting to raise the campaigns?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. There's not a number that we have out there.
componenttext: No. There's not a number that we have out there.

componenttext: Okay. To shift gears, looking at the efficiency ratio which you have on Slide 9. It's down modestly over the past year I would call it essentially flat. X any benefit from rates, should we basically just continue to assume that stays to be pretty flat in this range?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think that's probably fair, Steve but I also -- if you think about continued growth and growing net interest income, we're certainly trying to grow the fee businesses. So I think we can -- we're working to continue to make progress. I think x a movement
componenttext: I think that's probably fair, Steve but I also -- if you think about continued growth and growing net interest income, we're certainly trying to grow the fee businesses. So I think we can -- we're working to continue to make progress. I think x a movement in rates, it's going to be hard to make any dramatic steps forward for sure. But I'd like to think that we can incrementally continue to make steps, small steps forward.

componenttext: Sure. Well, the comment was in general, across all of those portfolios, in the second quarter, we saw loan spreads stabilize. And then, that statement really holds true for most of our portfolios as well, at least the major portfolios. When you think about C&I, commercial real estate, our mortgage warehouse business, as well as from the retail side as well, our residential mortgage portfolio.

componenttext: Yes, it is. It kind of slow, steady progress. Right now, I think the way to characterize it on an annual basis is, it's about where we were before we went into the joint venture. But we're very encouraged by the progress we're making on the sales side. So we do expect some slow, steady momentum to build there but certainly had not seen any dramatic change in a historical kind of contribution from that business.

componenttext: Yes, it's on plan. But I think the biggest thing and I know we've mentioned it before, we're having some success with larger merchants, larger customers of ours that appreciate Vantiv's capabilities. And we weren't off -- we were not able to offer those to them before. So we're booking business and it'll start to show gradually over time.

componenttext: And then, can you just talk about new branch openings? headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Yes, we definitely are thinking that way. And we happened to call our -- the use of the technology and the way we're modifying the in-store branches advantaged centers. We're just at the beginning of this deployment and that'll certainly -- those branches are 1/3 less costly, if you will, than the average branch. And this will make them even more cost-effective because of the staffing impact. And as we look to new markets and to expand into New York and Boston, in particular, we are thinking about smaller, traditional branches rather than kind of old-school.

componenttext: All right. I think what happened is we had a really strong first quarter. And we'd like to see that in the third and fourth quarter and going forward. We, as you know, I mean, those businesses depend on the customers' appetites. I think we're not planning in terms of kind of perspective, we're not planning on it. But what we have, people with expertise in the markets and we're in front of folks in a more active way as we've described before, was looking to build that business. On the insurance side, we're looking for seasonal increases in insurance revenue in the third quarter. Again, that's historically been very consistent.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015

componenttext: Just to quickly follow-up on the last question, so that's -- you indicated, obviously, was tied to 1 month LIBOR but what's the duration of your residential mortgage portfolio?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Collyn, I don't have an exact number but I will -- let me take sort of broad range around what I think it is. So that portfolio is almost exclusively hybrid ARMs. So the most popular products for us or the only products we offer are 5/1, 7/1 and 10/1. And
componenttext: Collyn, I don't have an exact number but I will -- let me take sort of broad range around what I think it is. So that portfolio is almost exclusively hybrid ARMs. So the most popular products for us or the only products we offer are 5/1, 7/1 and 10/1. And we've had those products for years now, so it's a very seasoned portfolio. The top of my head, I would think that the average duration of that portfolio is between 3 and 3.5 years. We also have about  between 600 million and 700 million of hybrid ARMs that, once they became floaters, they haven't pre-paid off which is contrary to what used to happen. It's just a function of how low rates are. So we have a large part of that portfolio that is also tied to either 1 year treasury or 1 year LIBOR as well.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, and is that really what's driving sort of the justification of the thought to not have any, if I'm looking at it right, not having any long-term borrowings on the balance sheet?
componenttext: Okay, and is that really what's driving sort of the justification of the thought to not have any, if I'm looking at it right, not having any long-term borrowings on the balance sheet?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's a couple of things. I mean, we have a little bit of long-term borrowings. And some of that is in the form of capital markets transactions, for instance. We have a $500 million, about 2.5-year old 10-year note that's outstanding as a holding
componenttext: Well, there's a couple of things. I mean, we have a little bit of long-term borrowings. And some of that is in the form of capital markets transactions, for instance. We have a $500 million, about 2.5-year old 10-year note that's outstanding as a holding company. But most of the liabilities in our treasury unit, meaning, excluding our retail CD deposit base, are fairly short. It's a function of short duration assets, pretty much across-the-board. Whether you look at our securities portfolio, our residential loan portfolio and the growing amount of floating rate assets that we've been generating. Meaning, growth in C&I, our mortgage warehouse business entirely and floats off 1 month LIBOR, our ABL is a 1 month LIBOR portfolio.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Equipment finances all short.
componenttext: Equipment finances all short.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Equipment finances, very short. Our home equity portfolio is all prime based. So we have a nice mismatch at the short end of the curve where we have quite a bit more assets than liabilities, and that's the big driver in our asset sensitivity. And w
componenttext: Right. Equipment finances, very short. Our home equity portfolio is all prime based. So we have a nice mismatch at the short end of the curve where we have quite a bit more assets than liabilities, and that's the big driver in our asset sensitivity. And we don't feel we need to increase the asset sensitivity by doing long-term borrowings at this point. And it's been the right decision for years now.

componenttext: Okay? Yes, that gap has come down -- no, it's come down because the originated portfolio, as you see, it has been coming down. If you look over a long period of time, there's definitely been a trend toward convergence, we're not there yet. And it's hard to predict exactly when that might occur. So the only thought or color I could really give you is we are seeing a convergence.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, just on your comments to about the uptick in professional fees this quarter and talked about kind of looking at different product offering. Can you just talk a little more detail on exactly what's going on there? It just seems like a prett
componenttext: Okay. And then, just on your comments to about the uptick in professional fees this quarter and talked about kind of looking at different product offering. Can you just talk a little more detail on exactly what's going on there? It just seems like a pretty big number of an increase, just trying to understand that and maybe what the trend we should expect going forward?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Collyn, this is Jack. We just happen to have a timing issue and some unique efforts that had caused that number to go up and we don't think it will continue. But we've had an effort and we used some outside consulting help to look at our sales force
componenttext: Yes. Collyn, this is Jack. We just happen to have a timing issue and some unique efforts that had caused that number to go up and we don't think it will continue. But we've had an effort and we used some outside consulting help to look at our sales force effectiveness and what tools we might use throughout the company to improve our ability to drive sales and drive revenue as we went forward, and we paid some fees for that service. And that's a one time event. And then, we also paid some outside fees in our payments space, those same folks that helped us with the joint venture in the merchant service helped us evaluate several other aspects of our payments environment and some of the offerings we have there. So that trend and the uptick that you see should not continue as we go forward. We will -- we've got other things going on in terms of other outside professional service vendors that we continue to negotiate a contract with and we continue to increase utilization of. So it should be relatively in the range of spending shortly.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then just one quick last question. I know you guys -- Dave talked about you spent some time on the retail deposit side. But if we could just go back to the commercial deposit initiative. I know that's been a big focus for you guys for thi
componenttext: Okay, great. And then just one quick last question. I know you guys -- Dave talked about you spent some time on the retail deposit side. But if we could just go back to the commercial deposit initiative. I know that's been a big focus for you guys for this year. David, I think you said you had, was it $300 million in commercial deposits come in? If you could just sort of update us again on what the numbers were for the commercial deposits and kind of what your goals are for the year on that front? And then I'll leave it there.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll see -- let me talk a little bit about what we're doing because I really think that's what's most important. And that's been -- our efforts have been in place for 2 years now or so, where we've really impressed upon our relationship managers the
componenttext: Sure. I'll see -- let me talk a little bit about what we're doing because I really think that's what's most important. And that's been -- our efforts have been in place for 2 years now or so, where we've really impressed upon our relationship managers the need to raise commercial deposits because we've been undersized in commercial deposits as an institution for a long period of time. And so we did a couple of things there. We increased incentives for deposits but more importantly, we put in profitability models that lenders need to submit with every loan request. So it's looking at the totality of the relationship, both the loan, all the fee income businesses as well as the deposits. And the deposits are a large component of the profitability. So we changed focus on that across the organization and that's what we're seeing flow through. The commercial growth in the quarter was $310 million, to give you the number.

componenttext: In that ballpark, there is -- what I would say is there's some seasonality across some of those businesses. So we actually had negative seasonality this quarter in our municipal business that we'll recover in the third quarter. But the success here is, we don't have a firm number around what we're trying to do each quarter. What we're trying to do is change behavior across the whole sales force. But we've been very pleased with what we've been able to do in the first 2 quarters of the year and would expect the behavior changes to last, not only this year, but into the future.

componenttext: Just going back to a prior question on preferred equity into 2016. I'm just trying to get a sense for the size or what you would estimate to be the size of that offering or what capital ratio you would be looking to maintain if and when that were to come about.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 16, 2015
componenttextpreview: Matt, we haven't really sized it. It's going to be a function of the size of the balance sheet, as well as our sense of what growth from that point forward will be. I mean, the only color I can give you there is, I think it will be hard to believe that we
componenttext: Matt, we haven't really sized it. It's going to be a function of the size of the balance sheet, as well as our sense of what growth from that point forward will be. I mean, the only color I can give you there is, I think it will be hard to believe that we would issue up to what's allowable under Basel III which is 1.5% of risk-weighted assets. Today, our thought process would probably be about half of that or so. So at this point, that's about the best color I can give you.

componenttext: Yes. So this is Jack. I think that we had a very low quarter and we would very much like to see it continue to repeat. We have seen a reduction in problem assets as we think about working through the last several years in identification of criticized loans and the like. They were at modest levels and we don't see a lot of new names, so we're encouraged by that. And there's 2 components of our provisioning, right, and the build. So one is to cover net charge-off activity and the other is to build the allowance as we grow the portfolio. So when you think about covering net charge-offs, we did have some very good recoveries this quarter, not too far out of normal range, but better than average. So that impacted the net charge-off some as well.

componenttext: I think the way to describe the way we think about is, we're very focused on organic growth. We think we've got great opportunity to continue to grow organically at a very good pace to get back to what we've been doing in terms of the acquisitions that we did in '10, '11 and '12 that got us into Boston and New York, and so that's the primary focus. We continue to build relationships and convey an interest with folks and at least dialoguing if it works mutually across the Northeast corridor. And so as I said in the past, those things, I think people understand that we're a successful acquirer, we're a successful company and we are very interested in being constructive about those things. And whether it happens or not, I find this very much on each individual partner's situation.

componenttext: I had a couple of questions. Just going back to the discussion about the relationship managers and how they're being charged with originating deposits as well and you've kind of -- you mentioned, I think, that you put the initiative in place maybe a couple of years ago. And I think you alluded to the fact that maybe, you've been pleased with the progress you've seen since the beginning of this year. But would you say, at this point, I mean, it sounds to me like you feel that those relationship managers still have some room to go in terms of adopting this philosophy of originating deposits. Or shouldn't they kind of have matured at this point in time in terms of what their capabilities are from that standpoint? I mean, how should we think about how much more room they have to move the needle in terms of raising deposits?

componenttext: No. I think it's very fair. I feel very strongly that it has matured. And naturally, whatever, we've got newer relationships coming on, hiring people, getting them oriented to our organization. But for the most, in terms of the program and our relationship managers, we have specific goals for relationship managers built into their individual plans. We've got incentives around those that have been established at least for 2 years, probably longer. So what David, I think, was trying to describe is that we continue to see these relationships, new activity and we look at those returns that are coming from the profitability sheets. And we continue to encourage more progress all the time. So I think the maturity of the program is there. I think the issue is there's always opportunity and we continue to look for more progress. And so the vision, if you will, the business line has goals, the individuals within the business line have goals and everybody's working toward them.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Amanda, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being record
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Amanda, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amanda. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our third quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive V
componenttext:
Thank you, Amanda. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our third quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice President; and Jeff Hoyt, our Controller. 
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. The results this quarter reflect our unwavering commitment to further improve profitability, which remains our most important objective. While we are proud of our accomplishments
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. The results this quarter reflect our unwavering commitment to further improve profitability, which remains our most important objective. While we are proud of our accomplishments over recent years, particularly given the persistently low interest rate environment, we must continue to drive forward further execute on the significant opportunities that exist across our large and attractive markets. 
Given the breadth of our products and services, we provide the exceptional talent we continue to attract and our strong focus on relationship banking, we are confident in our ability to deliver consistent quality earnings growth for our shareholders. 
Now turning to the overview of the third quarter on Slide 2. Operating earnings of $68.4 million or $0.23 per share represent a 9% increase from the prior year quarter or a 10% increase on a per share basis. Revenues increased 3% on both a linked-quarter and a year-over-year basis, driven by higher net interest income and higher fee revenues. 
It's important to note the pace of net interest margin decline continued to moderate in the third quarter. Net interest margin was 2.87%, a decrease of only 1 basis point from the second quarter. 
Expenses were up modestly on both a linked quarter and a year-over-year basis, primarily reflecting higher compensation and benefits cost. However, we remain confident in our ability to control costs despite the ongoing impact of strategic investments and higher regulatory compliance costs. 
Loans grew for the 20th consecutive quarter, although the 2% annualized growth rate is a slower pace than recent quarters. The portfolio was primarily impacted by lower line utilizations and volumes within our mortgage warehouse lending business. 
Loan outstandings within this business tend to be more volatile than our other businesses. Excluding mortgage warehouse lending, loans grew over 6% on an annualized basis, driven by strong residential mortgage and commercial real estate results. 
Highlighting the importance of our diversified business mix. Our progress gathering deposits continued during the quarter as evidenced by annualized growth of 12% from the end of the second quarter. As we maintain emphasis on franchise-wide cross-sell and deposit gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. 
Recently released FDIC data show we either increased or maintained our deposit market share rank in each state we operate in and we are particularly pleased with our continued #1 market share position within the Fairfield County, Connecticut in the state of Vermont. 
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked-quarter increase in net interest income from the second quarter. Our ongoing loan growth as well as higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio each increased net interest
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked-quarter increase in net interest income from the second quarter. Our ongoing loan growth as well as higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio each increased net interest income by $2.2 million. Net interest income also increased $1.7 million from an additional calendar day in the third quarter. 
The largest offset to these improvements was a $1 million reduction in net interest income due to a decline in accretion from runoff in the acquired loan portfolio. 
On Slide 4, net interest margin of 2.87% was lower by only 1 basis point compared to the second quarter as the pace of decline continued to moderate. As such, this result is the smallest linked-quarter decline in over 3 years. 
New loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 2 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. In addition, the margin decreased a basis point from higher deposit volumes and costs, which primarily resulted from the successful CD campaigns discussed last quarter. These declines were largely offset by a 2 basis point increase from an additional calendar day in the third quarter. 
Through 9 months, the net interest margin is 2.89%. Given these results, we expect the full year margin will be within the range of 2.85% to 2.95% we outlined in January. 
Turning to Slide 5, the loan portfolio grew $110 million or 2% annualized from the second quarter. Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $169 million. 
Retail contributed $208 million of originated loan growth, which was almost entirely driven by strong residential mortgage growth of $201 million. As is our practice, most of the newly originated residential mortgages retained in our portfolio were hybrid arms. 
Originated loans in the commercial portfolio were down $39 million from the second quarter due to a $248 million reduction in C&I. As Jack discussed earlier, this result was entirely driven by lower volumes and utilization rates in our mortgage warehouse lending business. 
The period end balance for this business was $839 million, down $312 million from June 30. However, the quarterly average balance decline for mortgage warehouse lending was only $45 million. 
Commercial real estate contributed solid originated growth of $209 million, marking the second consecutive quarter the pace of originated commercial real estate growth has increased. 
We experienced acquired loan runoff of $59 million this quarter compared to $58 million in the second quarter. The remaining balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter end was $841 million. 
The fourth quarter historically has been our strongest quarter in terms of loan originations and our current view is for this trend to continue this year. However, with annualized loan growth of 5% through 9 months, achieving the lower end of the range we outlined in January will be challenging. 
Slide 6 shows the change in deposits by segment from the second quarter. Total deposits increased $845 million or 12% on an annualized basis, primarily due to continued progress gathering commercial deposits. Commercial grew $883 million in the quarter compared to a $39 million reduction in retail. 
The seasonality of our municipal business had a favorable $486 million impact on commercial deposits, while the third quarter represents a seasonal low point for retail deposits with growth expected in the fourth quarter. 
Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.7 billion, an increase of $60 million. This small increase does not change our expectation that broker deposits will represent a decrease in percentage of our deposit base as we continue to grow organically. 
It is also worth noting that our loan-to-deposit ratio is 28% at the end of the quarter. Overall, we are very pleased with our progress gathering deposits and firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships. 
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at the 3% increase in non-interest income from the second quarter. As seasonal nature of insurance renewals increase noninterest income by $2.6 million while the continued success of our customer interest rates swap business contributed an additional $1.2 million compared to the second quarter. 
In addition, bank service charges improved $1 million, primarily as a result of 1 more business day in the third quarter and higher cash management fees, which have benefited from efforts to grow commercial deposits. 
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes in non-interest expenses on a linked-quarter basis. Nonoperating expenses decreased $2.9 million, primarily resulting from no branch closures in the third quarter. 
As you will recall, we closed 10 branches in the second quarter. From an operating perspective, expenses were up $5.3 million from the second quarter due in large part to a $4.3 million increase in compensation and benefits, primarily reflecting an additional work day and higher medical-related cost in the third quarter. 
While operating expenses were modestly higher than recent quarters, we remain confident our proactive approach to expense management will continue to control costs. 
Next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. While the ratio ticked up slightly in the third quarter, the results were still generally consistent with recent quarters. 
As we have mentioned before, continuing to improve operating leverage through revenue growth and effective expense management remains a highly important commitment of the company. 
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Originated nonperforming assets as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 78 basis points remains below our peer group in top 50 banks and has improved from 92 basis points in the third quarter of 2014. 
Looking at Slide 11. Net charge-offs for the quarter remained at a very low level. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets as well as our conservative and well-defined underlining philosophy that has served us so well for many years. 
As shown on Slide 12, operating return on average assets increased 3 basis points from the second quarter. Notwithstanding this improvement, our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment. 
Further progress will be achieved by balance sheet growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses. 
Looking at Slide 13, our return on average tangible equity was 10.5% for the third quarter, an improvement of 70 basis points on a linked-quarter basis. 
As we continue to focus on our most important objective, improving profitability, we expect to see further progress in this metric over time. 
Turning to Slide 14. We remain comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank continue to be strong, especially in light of our diversified business mix and history of exceptional credit risk management. 
Slide 15 displays our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we remain asset-sensitive though slightly less so than last quarter. However, we remain well positioned for an eventual rise in interest rates. 
Now I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. As we have mentioned many times before, we remain committed to investing strategically and building the business for the long term. As such, we are pleased to announce today the acquisition of Kesten-Brown, a Bridgeport, Connecticut-base
componenttext:
Thank you, David. As we have mentioned many times before, we remain committed to investing strategically and building the business for the long term. As such, we are pleased to announce today the acquisition of Kesten-Brown, a Bridgeport, Connecticut-based insurance brokerage firm focused on commercial lines and employee benefit. This acquisition will further diversify revenues through additional noninterest income as well as both our insurance business, which already placed People's United has the 12th largest bank in terms of insurance brokerage fee income for recent industry report. 
This concludes our presentation. I will be happy to answer any questions that you have. Operator, we're ready for questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, this is Jack. Well, a couple of things. I think very positive news in mortgage warehouse, if you look back over the last 3 or 4 years is the level of commitments that they have had outstanding has steadily increased. They've continued to build the b
componenttext: Well, this is Jack. Well, a couple of things. I think very positive news in mortgage warehouse, if you look back over the last 3 or 4 years is the level of commitments that they have had outstanding has steadily increased. They've continued to build the business. And so the peak that we had in line utilization in the second quarter has proved to be -- and right at the end of the period, proved to be more than we expected in. And in hindsight now, it kind of feels that a lot of the discussion about the change and the regulatory disclosure was pushing volume and are pulling it through ahead of that transition and certainly our customer base on a display that. If you look where the third quarter is and then go back to the first and the fourth quarter, the line utilization has kind of come back to the range where it's been. So very, very much in line with those other quarters. So kind of forecasting forward into the fourth quarter is difficult. There's certainly some discussion out there that mortgage bankers and then Freddie, people expect things to slow and we're evaluating that, especially as we think about fourth quarter, but also the plan for next year. I would say our folks on the ground are cautiously expecting some continued reduction, but I don't see it as being dramatic right now. It's just like interest rate, how do you predict it?

But the -- we would expect in the fourth quarter for our health care costs probably to recede a little bit than what we saw in the third /3 quarter.

componenttext: Okay, fair enough. I just ask one other question, at about. Credit quality is obviously always very strong for you guys, always has been. componenttext: I think as we laid out in the past, the way we think about provisioning is twofold. First is hovering net charge-offs during a period and then looking at growth in the portfolios and building the allowance accordingly based on loan type and our analysis about the provisioning that would be required for that. So it's net charge-offs and then loan growth in the period.

componenttext: Sure, Mark. It's David. As you saw, we had a very modest change in capital ratios, either did not -- regulatory ratios, for the most part, did not change Tier 1 leverage. It was only down 10 basis points. So we're very comfortable based on the risk in our balance sheet with our capital addition. We have discussed in the past from questions we've received our thoughts around future capital actions. And on the call last quarter, we talked about a midyear facility about midyear preferred transaction in midyear 2016 really based on 2 factors. One was going to be loan growth this year as well as our sense around loan growth next year. So as we sit here today, we wouldn't change that assessment that we gave 3 months ago.

componenttext: Okay, perfect. I want to follow-up on Jack's comments about the most important objective being profitability. I know in past calls, you guys have indicated that without the help of rate is going to be tough to make dramatic steps forward in the efficiency ratio in terms of improvements. But given maybe some uncertainty on the rate front, is there Plan B to move the efficiency ratio down or does it just fit at 62% so long as the Fed's is 0?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think if granted it will be slow progress depending on the rate of growth in the loan portfolio. But moving the businesses forward through the initiatives that we've undertaken to grow the various business lines and take on talent to do that, we w
componenttext: Well, I think if granted it will be slow progress depending on the rate of growth in the loan portfolio. But moving the businesses forward through the initiatives that we've undertaken to grow the various business lines and take on talent to do that, we would expect to move our revenue front forward without the benefit of a rate rise by growing our businesses, both in the interest income categories and the fee businesses. And we are steadily doing that and we will continue to do that. And we are -- we think managing expense levels despite those investments in a pretty darn tight range. So we don't have a Plan B that calls for dramatically changing the expense structure. We manage it very tightly. We find opportunities to reduce expenses and we've referenced in the past our ability to find and close branches effectively in the past. We mentioned our process. So we built pretty considerable risk management compliance structure and hired a lot of people in Boston, in New York and in ABL business, in the mortgage warehouse business and the wealth business. And we've maintained expense levels while we've done that. So I would call that Plan A. And I think we're working very hard controlling the efficiency ratio that way.

componenttext: Understood. But reasonably something less than $3 million annual benefit. Okay. Okay. Perfect. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the biggest headwind that we've had and actually, had in prior period has been commercial real estate portfolio with our largest portfolio. And really, over the last several years, maybe 3 or 4 now, it feels like it's become very, very competitive. The
componenttext: So the biggest headwind that we've had and actually, had in prior period has been commercial real estate portfolio with our largest portfolio. And really, over the last several years, maybe 3 or 4 now, it feels like it's become very, very competitive. There are more players that have come back into the business, and it's a very difficult competitively, really, in every market and every type of lending that we do. So we're pleased with the progress that we had in that area at this quarter and prior. But overall, when we think about our guidance and our plan for this year, commercial real estate was the largest portion that disappointed us. We also have seen a slowdown in our PCLC equipment finance area, which really is more dynamic about some prior relationships that we had that fundamentally changed. We shared exposure with a couple of other parties, and those relationships changed because there are circumstances we're changing. So we are originating actively and we're focused on getting that back on a better growth trajectory. In the meantime, that has not grown at the same rate that it did in the prior really 3 years, probably beyond that.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Understood. Okay. Then just lastly, the provision expect to making in the past, you said literally change more has been running in past ballpark, say, roughly $10 million, but it's come down the last few quarters. I understood them very, ver

componenttext: Well, I think if you look at our net charge-offs, say, over the last 8 quarters or so, it operates in a range that is very low. I think if you look at that range over those 8 quarters, we don't expect that to change as far as we can see at this time going forward.

componenttextpreview: So there's couple of things. I mean,, in terms of kind of the overall budget, we obviously have a large core processing contract with FIS, that is the most significant commitment we have on the technology side. It's a pretty deep relationship. Meaning, we
componenttext: So there's couple of things. I mean,, in terms of kind of the overall budget, we obviously have a large core processing contract with FIS, that is the most significant commitment we have on the technology side. It's a pretty deep relationship. Meaning, we use a lot of their products and services, applications that we run. And I would say maybe a way to think about overall our spend rather than kind of go into specific projects, I mean, we can talk about that, but -- and I'll give you a little color on that. I would say as we look back on our capital spending over the last 4, 5 years, we generally are continuing to invest in our products and try to improve our offering -- strengthen our offering to technology. And that's been fairly steady commitment and we don't see that changing in the near future. We have an IT project staff that we run pretty hard and you can only load so much on the process. So we've kind of managed to a level of work and activity annually based on our priorities. So we are investing now and project -- we have projects that will run to strengthen our commercial product set in cash management international services, in particular. And we're also enhancing our loan system environment to help us improve our servicing capabilities and our large corporate area. And so we have those types of projects active and on the board. And of course, we invest in compliance and other types of activity to keep us in the right spot on the regulatory front.

componenttext: No. The only reason we mentioned the broker deposits was that they ticked up $60 million in the quarter and it's just a timing issue. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015

componenttext: If I could just go back to your comments about loan growth. So obviously, it's going to come in a little bit lower in the fourth quarter and that 8 -- I think you guys had guided 8% to 12% at the beginner view your, so low that. So but just trying to reconcile that with your comments, David, still thinking there be a need to fund midyear preferred issue, as you guys kind of look at your landscape and you're talking your customers and you're going to the accrediting process and all -- globally. Is your expectation that loan growth could rebound in '16? I mean, how are you just thinking about it kind of in a broader sense?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just broader, just talk about preferred for a minute. So if you want to get really minute on it, we have slower growth in the third quarter than we thought we would have, right? So you could take that preferred deal and push it out, let's say, 3 mon
componenttext: Sure. Just broader, just talk about preferred for a minute. So if you want to get really minute on it, we have slower growth in the third quarter than we thought we would have, right? So you could take that preferred deal and push it out, let's say, 3 months. But -- and that conceivably could happen. But today, as we sit here, there's an expectation that we'll have reasonable loan growth in the fourth quarter. And as we start working through the budget process, there's no reason to think that the momentum and the people that we have in the field and the customer relationship are -- there's a fundamental change in our ability to grow loan. So with all that said at a high level, we -- I can see a need for capital sometime in the back half of 2016. Whether it's midyear or whether it's sometime in the third quarter or the beginning of the fourth quarter, it's an open question at this point.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Certainly have a lot of confidence in the various business lines and the people that are running and active in those businesses and building customer relationships that that will continue. And I think that's at the heart of -- on the loan growth side of i
componenttext: Certainly have a lot of confidence in the various business lines and the people that are running and active in those businesses and building customer relationships that that will continue. And I think that's at the heart of -- on the loan growth side of it, on the balance sheet side of it. We've got a very good track record. If you look back over the last 3 years, we've got an average probably 9%, 10% growth and we continue to build those businesses and expect to make progress. It is, I agree, 2% GDP economic growth environment is not 4%, which would benefit us greatly. But we're -- we continue to build relationships.

componenttext: Sure. So what we said on the call last time was that people back into an issuance size of somewhere between $150 million to $250 million issuance. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015

componenttext: Right. Okay. And then just touching on the potential preferred equity raise. Can you walk us through the thought process of going down that avenue versus taking potentially some other capital strategies, such as sub debt or maybe potentially changing the payout ratio, which is a lot higher than a lot of your peers?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The -- well, I would start with -- our job is to manage capital ratios both at the back and holding company level. And I'd remind you that we did do a $400 million bank sub debt issuance in the second quarter -- towards the end of the second quarter
componenttext: Sure. The -- well, I would start with -- our job is to manage capital ratios both at the back and holding company level. And I'd remind you that we did do a $400 million bank sub debt issuance in the second quarter -- towards the end of the second quarter of 2014. As you can see, some of the residual effects of that were at the bank, we have higher total risk-based capital currently and you can see the changes over time. So the -- we go back to -- there's been a long evolution of capital management at this company going back to being grossly over capitalized, coming out of the Tier 2  second step conversion and there's been a series of acquisitions. There's -- we bought back 25% of the stock that was issued in that transaction to a bunch of buybacks. And we've also had a nice and strong dividend payout to shareholders. So the capital rose under Basel III are pretty clear about what an efficient capital structure is. And that the most efficient capital structure does include preferred. And our job is to create that efficient capital structure, the most efficient capital structure we can for shareholders. And that's the simple logic behind the need to add preferred at some point and into the capital structure. If you look at our peer group, you'll see many of them, not all of them, but many of them do have preferred in the -- in their capital structure.

componenttext: Well, we actually -- we've been talking about that for a couple of years and we've actually continued to work at it on kind of the multiple fronts and trying to understand what it would mean and trying to -- our view is that we should gradually make the investments needed to be ready, and that's the longer-term view that we've been taking. So there are -- there is a lot of different angles on kind of the management of data being prepared to deal big data being understanding what a CCAR filing is in detail and then examining your data for that type of thing and examining other components of it. So multiple fronts, we spent time and we give folks assignments and we also work with others in the industry to try to understand from their experiences what that means and then we make preparation as we don't want to get there eventually and start when it's too late.
