componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial, Inc., Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Amanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. 
I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Andrew Hersom, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial, Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amanda. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our third quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive V
componenttext:
Thank you, Amanda. Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us today. Here with me to review our third quarter of 2015 results are Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; David Rosato, Chief Financial Officer; Kirk Walters, Senior Executive Vice President; and Jeff Hoyt, our Controller. 
Please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of this presentation, which is posted on our website, peoples.com, under Investor Relations. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. The results of this quarter reflect our unwavering commitment to further improve profitability, which remains our most important objective. While we are proud of our accomplishmen
componenttext:
Thank you, Andrew. Good afternoon. We appreciate everyone joining us today. The results of this quarter reflect our unwavering commitment to further improve profitability, which remains our most important objective. While we are proud of our accomplishments over recent years, particularly given the persistently low interest rate environment, we must continue to drive forward, further execute on the significant opportunities that exist across our large and attractive markets. 
Given the breadth of our products and services we provide, the exceptional talent we continue to attract and our strong focus on relationship banking, we are confident in our ability to deliver consistent quality earnings growth for our shareholders. 
Now turning to the overview of the third quarter on Slide 2. Operating earnings of $68.4 million or $0.23 per share represent a 9% increase from the prior year quarter or a 10% increase on a per-share basis. Revenues increased 3% on both a linked quarter and a year-over-year basis, driven by higher net interest income and higher fee revenues. 
It's important to note the pace of net interest margin decline continued to moderate in the third quarter. Net interest margin was 2.87%, a decrease of only 1 basis point from the second quarter. 
Expenses were up modestly on both a linked quarter and a year-over-year basis primarily reflecting higher compensation and benefits costs. However, we remain confident in our ability to control costs despite the ongoing impact of strategic investments and higher regulatory compliance costs. 
Loans grew for the 20th consecutive quarter, although the 2% annualized growth rate is a slower pace than recent quarters. The portfolio was primarily impacted by lower line utilizations and volumes within our mortgage warehouse lending business. 
Loan outstandings within this business tend to be more volatile than our other businesses. Excluding mortgage warehouse lending, loans grew over 6% on an annualized basis driven by strong residential mortgage and commercial real estate results, highlighting the importance of our diversified business mix. Our progress gathering deposits continued during the quarter as evidenced by annualized growth of 12% from the end of the second quarter. As we maintain emphasis on franchise-wide cross-sell and deposit gathering efforts, the deposit base will continue to see growth. 
Recently released FDIC data show we either increased or maintained our deposit market share rank in each state we operate in, and we are particularly pleased with our continued #1 market share position within Fairfield County, Connecticut, and the state of Vermont. 
With that, I'll pass it to David to discuss the quarter in more detail.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the second quarter. Our ongoing loan growth as well as higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio each increased net interest
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack. On Slide 3, we provide detail behind the linked quarter increase in net interest income from the second quarter. Our ongoing loan growth as well as higher average balances and yields in the securities portfolio each increased net interest income by $2.2 million. Net interest income also increased $1.7 million from an additional calendar day in the third quarter. 
The largest offset to these improvements was a $1 million reduction in net interest income due to a decline in accretion from runoff in the acquired loan portfolio. 
On Slide 4, net interest margin of 2.87% was lower by only 1 basis point compared to the second quarter as the pace of decline continued to moderate. As such, this result is the smallest linked quarter decline in over 3 years. 
New loan volume negatively impacted the margin by 2 basis points as new business yields remained lower than the total loan portfolio yield. In addition, the margin decreased 1 basis point from higher deposit volumes and costs, which primarily resulted from the successful CD campaigns discussed last quarter. These declines were largely offset by a 2 basis point increase from an additional calendar day in the third quarter. 
Through 9 months, the net interest margin is 2.89%. Given these results, we expect the full year margin will be within the range of 2.85% to 2.95% we outlined in January. 
Turning to Slide 5, the loan portfolio grew $110 million or 2% annualized from the second quarter. Originated loan growth for the quarter totaled $169 million. 
Retail contributed $208 million of originated loan growth, which was almost entirely driven by strong residential mortgage growth of $201 million. As is our practice, most of the newly originated residential mortgages retained in our portfolio were hybrid arms. 
Originated loans in the commercial portfolio were down $39 million from the second quarter due to a $248 million reduction in C&I. As Jack discussed earlier, this result was entirely driven by lower volumes and utilization rates in our mortgage warehouse lending business. 
The period end balance for this business was $839 million, down $312 million from June 30. However, the quarterly average balance decline for mortgage warehouse lending was only $45 million. 
Commercial real estate contributed solid originated growth of $209 million, marking the second consecutive quarter the pace of originated commercial real estate growth has increased. 
We experienced acquired loan runoff of $59 million this quarter compared to $58 million in the second quarter. The remaining balance of the acquired portfolio at quarter-end was $841 million. 
The fourth quarter historically has been our strongest quarter in terms of loan originations, and our current view is for this trend to continue this year. However, with annualized loan growth of 5% through 9 months, achieving the lower end of the range we outlined in January will be challenging. 
Slide 6 shows the change in deposits by segment from the second quarter. Total deposits increased $845 million or 12% on an annualized basis primarily due to continued progress gathering commercial deposits. Commercial grew $883 million in the quarter compared to a $39 million (sic) [ $38 million ] reduction in retail. 
The seasonality of our municipal business had a favorable $486 million impact on commercial deposits, while the third quarter represents a seasonal low point for retail deposits with growth expected in the fourth quarter. 
Broker deposits ended the quarter at $2.7 billion, an increase of $60 million. This small increase does not change our expectation that broker deposits will represent a decreasing percentage of our deposit base as we continue to grow organically. 
It is also worth noting that our loan-to-deposit ratio was 98% at the end of the quarter. Overall, we are very pleased with our progress gathering deposits and firmly believe that deposits are an integral part of customer relationships. 
On Slide 7, we take a closer look at the 3% increase in noninterest income from the second quarter. The seasonal nature of insurance renewals increased noninterest income by $2.6 million while the continued success of our customer interest rate swap business contributed an additional $1.2 million compared to the second quarter. 
In addition, bank service charges improved $1 million primarily as a result of 1 more business day in the third quarter and higher cash management fees which have benefited from efforts to grow commercial deposits. 
On Slide 8, we illustrate the key components of changes in noninterest expenses on a linked quarter basis. Nonoperating expenses decreased $2.9 million primarily resulting from no branch closures in the third quarter. 
As you will recall, we closed 10 branches in the second quarter. From an operating perspective, expenses were up $5.3 million from the second quarter due in large part to a $4.3 million increase in compensation and benefits primarily reflecting an additional work day and higher medical-related costs in the third quarter. 
While operating expenses were modestly higher than recent quarters, we remain confident our proactive approach to expense management will continue to control costs. 
The next slide details our efficiency ratio over the last 5 quarters. While the ratio ticked up slightly in the third quarter, the results were still generally consistent with recent quarters. 
As we have mentioned before, continuing to improve operating leverage through revenue growth and effective expense management remains a highly important commitment of the company. 
Slides 10 and 11 are a reminder of our excellent credit quality. Originated nonperforming assets as a percentage of originated loans and REO at 78 basis points remains below our peer group and top 50 banks and has improved from 92 basis points in the third quarter of 2014. 
Looking at Slide 11. Net charge-offs for the quarter remained at a very low level. These levels reflect the minimal loss content in our nonperforming assets as well as our conservative and well-defined underwriting philosophy that has served us so well for many years. 
As shown on Slide 12, operating return on average assets increased 3 basis points from the second quarter. Notwithstanding this improvement, our return on average assets continues to be impacted by the persistently low interest rate environment. 
Further progress will be achieved by balance sheet growth, fee income growth and an ongoing disciplined approach to expenses. 
Looking at Slide 13, our return on average tangible equity was 10.5% for the third quarter, an improvement of 70 basis points on a linked quarter basis. 
As we continue to focus on our most important objective -- improving profitability -- we expect to see further progress in this metric over time. 
Turning to Slide 14. We remain comfortable with our capital structure and balance sheet strength. Capital levels at the holding company and the bank continue to be strong, especially in light of our diversified business mix and history of exceptional credit risk management. 
Slide 15 displays our interest rate risk profile for both parallel rate changes and yield curve twist. As you can see, we remain asset-sensitive, though slightly less so than last quarter. However, we remain well positioned for an eventual rise in interest rates. 
Now I'd like to pass it back to Jack to wrap up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, David. As we have mentioned many times before, we remain committed to investing strategically and building the business for the long term. As such, we are pleased to announce today the acquisition of Kesten-Brown, a Bridgeport, Connecticut-base
componenttext:
Thank you, David. As we have mentioned many times before, we remain committed to investing strategically and building the business for the long term. As such, we are pleased to announce today the acquisition of Kesten-Brown, a Bridgeport, Connecticut-based insurance brokerage firm focused on commercial lines and employee benefits. This acquisition will further diversify revenues through additional noninterest income as well as bolster our insurance business, which already placed People's United as the 12th largest bank in terms of insurance brokerage fee income per a recent industry report. 
This concludes our presentation, and I will be happy to answer any questions that you have. Operator, we're ready for questions.

componenttext: What I would say is we had a couple of onetimers in the third quarter. We called out the day count on comp and also the health-care expenses. So at this point, we're still comfortable -- we still have comfort that we will hit our operating expense range that we set out at the beginning of the year of $835 million to $845 million.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then on the mortgage warehouse, obviously, that can be volatile, and it clearly went against you this quarter. It sounds like, on an average basis, it's -- there's still some attrition on the comp. I was just wondering for that -- from th
componenttext: Okay, great. And then on the mortgage warehouse, obviously, that can be volatile, and it clearly went against you this quarter. It sounds like, on an average basis, it's -- there's still some attrition on the comp. I was just wondering for that -- from that $839 million level, do you expect it to settle from here on a period-end basis? And what are the yields on mortgage warehouse?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Casey, it's Jack. Well, a couple of things. I think the very positive news in mortgage warehouse, if you look back over the last 3 or 4 years is the level of commitments that they have had outstanding has steadily increased. They've continued to bui
componenttext: Well, Casey, it's Jack. Well, a couple of things. I think the very positive news in mortgage warehouse, if you look back over the last 3 or 4 years is the level of commitments that they have had outstanding has steadily increased. They've continued to build the business. And so the peak that we had in line utilization in the second quarter has proved to be -- and right at the end of the period, proved to be more than we expected. And in hindsight now, it kind of feels like a lot of the discussion about the change in the regulatory disclosure was pushing volume, kind of pulling it through ahead of that transition, and certainly our customer base kind of displayed that. If you look where the third quarter is and then go back to the first and the fourth quarter, the line utilization has kind of come back to the range where it's been. So very, very much in line with those other quarters. So kind of forecasting forward into the fourth quarter is difficult. There's certainly some discussion out there that mortgage bankers and Fannie and Freddie, people expect things to slow, and we're evaluating that, especially as we think about fourth quarter but also the plan for next year. I would say our folks on the ground are cautiously expecting some continued reduction, but I don't see it as being dramatic right now. It's just -- it's like interest rates. How do you predict it?

componenttext: Sure, Bob. It's David. The health-care expenses were up $1.7 million in the quarter. We can clearly identify $700,000 that is nonreoccurring. We also -- if you look at health-care costs year-over-year by quarter, you normally see an uptick in health-care costs in the third or the fourth quarter as employees start to meet their deductibles and there's a higher percentage share on the company. But the -- we would expect in the fourth quarter for our health-care costs probably to recede a little bit from what we saw in the third quarter.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think as we have kind of laid out in the past, the way we think about provisioning is twofold. First is covering net charge-offs during a period and then looking at growth in the portfolios and building the allowance accordingly based on loan type and o
componenttext: I think as we have kind of laid out in the past, the way we think about provisioning is twofold. First is covering net charge-offs during a period and then looking at growth in the portfolios and building the allowance accordingly based on loan type and our analysis about the provisioning that would be required for that. So it's net charge-offs and then loan growth in the period.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Mark. It's David. As you saw, we had a very modest change in capital ratios, either did not -- regulatory ratios, for the most part, did not change Tier 1 leverage. It was only down 10 basis points. So we're very comfortable based on the risk in our
componenttext: Sure, Mark. It's David. As you saw, we had a very modest change in capital ratios, either did not -- regulatory ratios, for the most part, did not change Tier 1 leverage. It was only down 10 basis points. So we're very comfortable based on the risk in our balance sheet with our capital position. We have discussed in the past from questions we've received our thoughts around future capital actions. And on the call last quarter, we talked about a midyear -- the possibility of a midyear preferred transaction in midyear 2016 really based on 2 factors. One was going to be loan growth this year as well as our sense around loan growth next year. So as we sit here today, we wouldn't change that assessment that we gave 3 months ago.

componenttext: Yes, this is Jack, Mark. Yes, absolutely, we do. We -- I mean, on kind of multiple levels. And if we look across our markets, there remains considerable opportunity for us to continue to augment our presence in the markets. And we'll -- we are and we'll continue to look for those opportunities, but we definitely feel prepared to do so.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, perfect. I want to follow up on Jack's comments about the most important objective being to improve profitability. I know in past calls, you guys have indicated that without the help of rates, it's going to be tough to make dramatic steps forward in
componenttext: Okay, perfect. I want to follow up on Jack's comments about the most important objective being to improve profitability. I know in past calls, you guys have indicated that without the help of rates, it's going to be tough to make dramatic steps forward in the efficiency ratio in terms of improvements. But given maybe some uncertainty on the rate front, is there a Plan B to move the efficiency ratio down? Or does it just sit at 62% so long as the Fed's a 0?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it -- granted, it will be slow progress depending on the rate of growth in the loan portfolio. But moving the businesses forward through the initiatives that we've undertaken to grow the various business lines and take on talent to do that,
componenttext: Well, I think it -- granted, it will be slow progress depending on the rate of growth in the loan portfolio. But moving the businesses forward through the initiatives that we've undertaken to grow the various business lines and take on talent to do that, we would expect to move our revenue front forwards without the benefit of a rate rise by growing our businesses both in the interest income categories and the fee businesses. And we are steadily doing that, and we would continue to do that. And we are -- we think managing expense levels despite those investments in a pretty darn tight range. So we don't have a Plan B that calls for dramatically changing the expense structure. We manage it very tightly. We find opportunities to reduce expenses. We've referenced in the past our ability to find and close branches effectively in the past. We mentioned our e-mark [ph] process. So we've built pretty considerable risk management compliance structure and hired a lot of people in Boston, in New York and in the ABL business, in the mortgage warehouse business and the wealth business. And we've maintained expense levels while we've done that. So I would call that Plan A. And I think we're working very hard at improving the efficiency ratio that way.

componenttext: Fair enough. And maybe if I guess, just one final on the tax rate. It looked like the lower tax rate added maybe $0.01 to the quarter. Were there any onetimers in there? Or for some reason, should we be thinking about a lower tax rate going forward?

componenttext: Okay. But it reasonably would be something less than the $3 million annual benefit. Okay. Okay. Perfect. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the biggest headwind that we've had and actually, we've had in prior periods has been commercial real estate portfolio, which is our largest portfolio. And really, over the last several years, maybe 3 or 4 now, it feels like it's become very, very comp
componenttext: So the biggest headwind that we've had and actually, we've had in prior periods has been commercial real estate portfolio, which is our largest portfolio. And really, over the last several years, maybe 3 or 4 now, it feels like it's become very, very competitive. There are more players that have come back into the business, and it's very difficult competitively, really, in every market and every type of lending that we do. So we're pleased with the progress that we had in that area this quarter and prior. But overall, when we think about our guidance and our plan for this year, commercial real estate was the largest portion that has disappointed us. We also have seen a slowdown in our PCLC equipment finance area, which really is more dynamic about some prior relationships that we had that fundamentally changed. We shared exposure with a couple of other parties, and those relationships changed because their circumstances were changing. So we're originating actively, and we're focused on getting that back on a better growth trajectory. In the meantime, that has not grown at the same rate that it did in the prior really 3 years and probably beyond that.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015

componenttext: So there's a couple of things. I mean, in terms of kind of the overall budget, we obviously have a large core processing contract with FIS that is the most significant commitment we have on the technology side. It's a pretty deep relationship, meaning, we use a lot of their products and services, applications that we run. And I would say maybe a way to think about overall our spend rather than kind of go into specific projects, I mean, we could talk about that, but -- and I'll give you a little color on that. I would say, as we look back on our capital spending over the last 4, 5 years, we generally are continuing to invest in our products and try to improve our offering -- strengthen our offerings through technology. And that's been a fairly steady commitment, and we don't see that changing in the near future. We have an IT project staff that we run pretty hard, and you can only load so much on the process. So we've kind of managed to a level of work and activity annually based on our priorities. So we are investing now and project -- we have projects that are run to strengthen our commercial product set in cash management, international services, in particular. And we're also enhancing our loan system environment to help us improve our servicing capabilities in our large corporate area. And so we have those types of projects active and on the board. And of course, we invest in compliance and other types of activity to keep us in the right spot on the regulatory front.

componenttextpreview: If I could just go back to your comments about loan growth. So obviously, it's going to come in a little bit lower in the fourth quarter, and that 8 -- I think you guys had guided 8% to 12% at the beginning of the year, so below that. But just trying to r
componenttext: If I could just go back to your comments about loan growth. So obviously, it's going to come in a little bit lower in the fourth quarter, and that 8 -- I think you guys had guided 8% to 12% at the beginning of the year, so below that. But just trying to reconcile that with your comments, David, about still thinking there'd be a need for a midyear preferred issue, as you guys kind of look at your landscape and you're talking to your customers and you go into the budgeting process for the fall, is your -- and everything that's happening globally, is your expectation that loan growth could rebound in '16? I mean, how are you just thinking about it kind of in a broader sense?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. Just broader, just talk about the preferred for a minute. So if you want to get really minute on it, we had slower growth in the third quarter than we thought we would have, right. So you could take that preferred deal and push it out, let's say, 3
componenttext: Sure. Just broader, just talk about the preferred for a minute. So if you want to get really minute on it, we had slower growth in the third quarter than we thought we would have, right. So you could take that preferred deal and push it out, let's say, 3 months. But -- and that conceivably could happen. But today, as we sit here, there's an expectation that we'll have reasonable loan growth in the fourth quarter. And as we start working through the budget process, there's no reason to think that the momentum and the people that we have in the field and the customer relationships are -- there's a fundamental change in our ability to grow loans. So with all that said at a high level, we -- I can see a need for capital sometime in the back half of 2016. Whether it's midyear or whether it's sometime in the third quarter or the beginning of the fourth quarter, it's an open question at this point.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: We certainly have a lot of confidence in the various business lines and the people that are running and active in those businesses and building customer relationships that, that will continue. And I think that's at the heart of -- on the loan growth side
componenttext: We certainly have a lot of confidence in the various business lines and the people that are running and active in those businesses and building customer relationships that, that will continue. And I think that's at the heart of -- on the loan growth side of that, on the balance sheet side of it. We've got a very good track record. If you look back over the last 3 years, we've got an average of probably 9%, 10% growth, and we continue to build those businesses and expect to make progress. It is, I agree, 2% -- GDP economic growth environment is not 4%, which would benefit us greatly. But we're -- we continue to build relationships.

componenttext: So my point is -- there are a lot of potential partners for us that across our Northeast corridor that some that are very attractive at $2 billion and some at $10 billion. And so we are -- we have a very good track record in terms of acquisitions and moving through integrations and conversions. We have a great playbook that we have used in the past that we continue to update and be prepared when the right opportunity comes. And we're also very disciplined and thoughtful about what we do. And we'll continue on that track. And that's -- so my reference to being prepared is just that, that we look at our history and moving through, whether for this organization, it was the Chittenden acquisition at the time, which was a significant undertaking. componenttext: Okay. Okay. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's David, Matt. And first of all, I would say it was a very modest decrease in asset sensitivity. Really, driven -- if you'll notice, we -- the securities portfolio grew in the quarter. And so that was the #1 driver of the decrease in asset sensit
componenttext: Sure. It's David, Matt. And first of all, I would say it was a very modest decrease in asset sensitivity. Really, driven -- if you'll notice, we -- the securities portfolio grew in the quarter. And so that was the #1 driver of the decrease in asset sensitivity. And then I would also just say that if you pick the 5-year point on the swaps curve, quarter-over-quarter, 5-year swaps were down about 40 basis points. So you're starting from a lower interest rate level when you run your models, and that also had a modest impact.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay. And then just touching on the potential preferred equity raise. Can you walk us through the thought process of going down that avenue versus taking potentially some other capital strategies, such as subdebt or maybe even potentially changing
componenttext: Right. Okay. And then just touching on the potential preferred equity raise. Can you walk us through the thought process of going down that avenue versus taking potentially some other capital strategies, such as subdebt or maybe even potentially changing the payout ratio, which is a lot higher than a lot of your peers?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The -- well, I would start with -- our job is to manage capital ratios both at the bank and at the holding company level. And I'd remind you that we did do a $400 million bank subdebt issuance in the second -- towards the end of the second quarter o
componenttext: Sure. The -- well, I would start with -- our job is to manage capital ratios both at the bank and at the holding company level. And I'd remind you that we did do a $400 million bank subdebt issuance in the second -- towards the end of the second quarter of 2014. As you can see, some of the residual effects of that were at the bank, we have higher total risk-based capital currently, and you can see the changes over time. So the -- we go back to -- there's been a long evolution of capital management at this company going back to being grossly overcapitalized coming out of the Tier 2 second-step conversion and there's been a series of acquisitions. There's -- we bought back 25% of the stock that was issued in that transaction through a bunch of buybacks. And we've also had a nice and strong dividend payout to shareholders. So the capital rules under Basel III are pretty clear about what an efficient capital structure is. And that the most efficient capital structure does include preferred. And our job is to create that efficient capital structure, the most efficient capital structure we can for shareholders. And that's the simple logic behind the need to add preferred at some point and into the capital structure. If you look at our peer group, you'll see many of them, not all of them, but many of them do have preferred in the -- in their capital structure.

componenttext: Okay. Okay. Great. That's helpful. And then just back on capital quickly. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, 2 questions there. The first is what is the most limiting capital ratio for us? I would say is total risk-based capital. The -- where our commercial bank, we generate a large amount of 100% risk-weighted assets over time. That was the reason that we
componenttext: Well, 2 questions there. The first is what is the most limiting capital ratio for us? I would say is total risk-based capital. The -- where our commercial bank, we generate a large amount of 100% risk-weighted assets over time. That was the reason that we had the bank level subdebt issuance last year. The -- I mean, you threw out a hypothetical 6% TCE ratio.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Or just a 6% handle, not a...
componenttext: Or just a 6% handle, not a...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: A 6% handle and then couch that with issues with regulators. I -- what we have talked about is our TCE will probably end up the year at about a 7.20-or-so rate, dependent on growth. We've said last quarter that that's about where our long-term preference
componenttext: A 6% handle and then couch that with issues with regulators. I -- what we have talked about is our TCE will probably end up the year at about a 7.20-or-so rate, dependent on growth. We've said last quarter that that's about where our long-term preference is. In the short term, in this interest rate environment, we would have a tolerance to let it slip below that for a short period of time. But we also believe that there will be some rate relief at some point that will help us create more  internal capital generation even with our dividend payout ratio. So it's in the internal comfort level much more than a discussion with our regulators.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's good color. And then just lastly -- this is a long-term question here. But since you guys are still below $40 billion, you don't need to worry about this, this year or probably even next year, but I do have you crossing through $40 billion in
componenttext: Okay, that's good color. And then just lastly -- this is a long-term question here. But since you guys are still below $40 billion, you don't need to worry about this, this year or probably even next year, but I do have you crossing through $40 billion in assets at some point over the next couple years. Just wondering at what point you actually have to start that glide path to crossing the $50 billion threshold and discussing that with your regulators and getting your systems ready? At what point do you start having to do that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we actually -- we've been talking about that for a couple of years, and we've actually continued to work at it on kind of the multiple fronts and trying to understand what it would mean and tried to -- our view is that we should gradually make the i
componenttext: Well, we actually -- we've been talking about that for a couple of years, and we've actually continued to work at it on kind of the multiple fronts and trying to understand what it would mean and tried to -- our view is that we should gradually make the investments needed to be ready, and that's the longer-term view that we've been taking. So there are -- there is a lot of different angles on kind of the management of data being prepared to deal with big data being -- understanding what a CCAR filing is in detail and then examining your data for that type of thing and examining other components of it. So multiple fronts, we spend time and we give folks assignments, and we also work with others in the industry to try to understand from their experiences what that means, and then we make a preparation as we don't want to get there eventually and start at the -- when it's too late.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015

componenttextpreview: Dave, the only thing I was going to add to that is we're a good DFAST bank, and we got there in the same approach that Jack is talking about. We got ahead of it early. We built out a team over time and improved our capabilities, and it was all just built
componenttext: Dave, the only thing I was going to add to that is we're a good DFAST bank, and we got there in the same approach that Jack is talking about. We got ahead of it early. We built out a team over time and improved our capabilities, and it was all just built into the run rate.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. So I guess, as you're kind of in the process of thinking through this, do you think that it might be not until maybe 2017 that you start seeing some accelerated expense in this area in terms of building out for this? Or would you expect that to b
componenttext: Got you. So I guess, as you're kind of in the process of thinking through this, do you think that it might be not until maybe 2017 that you start seeing some accelerated expense in this area in terms of building out for this? Or would you expect that to be pushed even more into the future?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, at this point, we're not expecting any accelerated expenses to hit us, but we don't have all the answers either. So we are making the incremental investments. As David's DFAST point is a real good one, we've built that staff over the last number of
componenttext: Well, at this point, we're not expecting any accelerated expenses to hit us, but we don't have all the answers either. So we are making the incremental investments. As David's DFAST point is a real good one, we've built that staff over the last number of years, and it came into our run rate. And those are the kinds of things that we are doing incrementally to be compliant with DFAST and the requirements and successfully meet that requirement. So when we talk about expenses and say that we're managing expenses at a level while we're also meeting increased regulatory compliance demands and making the investments in the businesses, those are the references we're talking about.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015

componenttext: Our next question is from Steven Alexopoulos with JPMorgan.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I thought on the second shot, you might get it right. Just one follow-up on all this commentary around the larger M&A and CCAR. Jack, you threw out 2 asset sizes that would each keep you below the CCAR line. I'm not sure if that was intentional or not. Bu
componenttext: I thought on the second shot, you might get it right. Just one follow-up on all this commentary around the larger M&A and CCAR. Jack, you threw out 2 asset sizes that would each keep you below the CCAR line. I'm not sure if that was intentional or not. But do you have an appetite to do a deal large enough that it would make you a CCAR bank sooner than later?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would say it would depend on -- kind of the -- plus the answer I just gave about preparedness and the time it takes. I don't think that we are clear yet about that, and we continue to work at it. So I guess the right kind of response would be we don't k
componenttext: I would say it would depend on -- kind of the -- plus the answer I just gave about preparedness and the time it takes. I don't think that we are clear yet about that, and we continue to work at it. So I guess the right kind of response would be we don't know enough yet to know exactly what those requirements are. So we're not prepared to undertake that without that understanding.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 15, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I also ask just given that you have a dividend payout ratio that's significantly higher than the other CCAR banks, which I would guess would also be a consideration for you.
componenttext: Right. I also ask just given that you have a dividend payout ratio that's significantly higher than the other CCAR banks, which I would guess would also be a consideration for you.
